story:
A World First Crossing of Antarctica 

 

"Support our campaign, help us cross Antarctica, make a significant contribution to combating climate change and inspire a generation to protect this fragile wilderness into the future." 

 

Imagine skiing 2600km, the same distance as from London to Moscow!

Now imagine the journey is across snow and ice, up glaciers and through unexplored mountains. The temperature around you will average from -10°C to -60°C with wind chill. Storms are frequent and dangerous with wind speeds that can exceed 150km/hr, lasting for days.

The sled you drag behind you is your life raft, packed full of all the gear and food needed to survive this 110 day expedition. It weighs over 200kg. To make it you must average a distance of 24km per day. Bad weather or storms cannot hold you up, or the food will run out. There are no rest days!

That is what doctors Gareth Andrews and Richard Stephenson from The Last Great First, will be doing. They are planning to change polar history by being the first to ski unsupported acrossAntarctica from coast to coast, in the same way the great Sir Ernest Shackleton wanted to do.

Our aims are to complete the crossing, support our community and undertake scientific climate change research for the benefit of all humanity – and we need your help to fund this historic world first.

In exchange for your pledges, we are offering you a broad range of ways in which you can support the expedition, including:

  •       Having your photographs printed on our sleds
  •       Adding your smile to The Last Great First Expedition flag
  •      Wearing the Expedition patch and pins
  •       Owning a unique Expedition coin and planning map
  •       Enjoying a limited-edition Expedition photobook
  •       Framing prints by polar artists
  •       Drinking Exploration inspired coffee
  •       Displaying a sculpture of a Emperor Penguin cast in silver

 

It is hard to imagine, but we can actually call ten generous supporters from the South Pole!

The Last Great First team wants to achieve far more than the first unsupported ski crossing of Antarctica.

Through our work with the Antarctic Science Foundation and Scouts Australia we will make a significant contribution to Antarctic climate change science and conservation while  inspiring  and educating the next generation of leaders and adventurers.

This expedition will further our knowledge of rarely traversed sections of Antarctica; how humans perform in extreme conditions and our continuing impact on this most pristine of environments.

It will bring the future into focus for a new generation, underlining the importance, majesty and fragility of Antarctica and its pivotal role in our survival on this planet.

The Last Great First Expedition will be the ultimate test of resilience, tenacity, meticulous planning and risk management while highlighting the urgent need to protect the fragile, pristine wilderness of Antarctica now and into the future.

Along with your pledge we invite you to become a part of our network and community, receiving constant expedition updates and information as the expedition progresses. 

You will also receive links to our documentary film and web-based reality series focusing on our Crossing of Antarctica as they become available.

If during this campaign we are successful in reaching our target, we ask that you keep supporting us as long as slots are available, and the campaign is live.

We look forward to you joining our Expedition family, thank you for your support.

___________________________________

Previous Expeditions

 

2019: Iceland Expedition 

The team successfully completed the first unsupported ski and raft crossing of Iceland. Skiing across the vast Vatnajokull Icecap then rafting through the wild and desolate high volcanic interior of this harsh and desolate land. A truly multidisciplinary expedition, it involved skiing pulling sledges, load carrying huge 50kg packs, and rafting wild uncharted glacial rivers. Success was a testament to toughness, adaptability and determination.

Please Follow the link to see video content: #TLGFiceland

 

2016: Greenland Expedition

 
Over 26 days the team skied from Tassilaq on the East Coast of Greenland to Kangerlussuaq on the West Coast unsupported, following the line of the Arctic Circle. In doing so they crossed the vast expanse of the Greenland Ice Sheet, facing huge crevasse fields and fierce polar storms. The team also witnessed the impact of climate change first-hand, negotiating meltwater rivers and huge meltwater lakes very early in the Arctic Spring season.
 

Please Follow the link to see video content: #TLGFgreenland

To View the daily vlogs from this expedition please follow the link: #TLGFgreenlandVlog



 

2014: Magnetic North Pole Expedition 

Battling polar storms with temperatures down to minus 60 deg centigrade and dodging hunting polar bears, the team skied for over three weeks across the frozen Arctic Ocean to reach the 1996 Magnetic North Pole. This remarkable location marks the point of confluence of the Earth’s magnetic field out on the pack ice of the Arctic Ocean.

Unfortunately we were unable to produce any video based content around this expedition, but please feel free to click on the link to see our images on our Instagram page: #TLGFmagneticnorth 
 
 
 

___________________________________

Expedition Updates on Indiegogo

 

Through out this fund raiser we will be posting links to blogs, images and various video series from our social media channels to the UPDATE section of our Indiegogo Campaign.


If you do not know where to find this please click here to navigate to it UPDATE LINK

___________________________________
Risks and challenges

We have been training and planning for this expedition since 2019. Currently the greatest challenge we face is the global restriction on travel. As discussed with our partners and sponsors, in the instance of the COVID-19 pandemic restricting our travel, the expedition will be postponed to the following Antarctic Season (Oct-Feb) and will not be cancelled. We are wholeheartedly committed to completing this 110 day, 2600km coast to coast crossing of the "White Desert" and we thank you for your continued support.

story:
Intro

Baboon Outdoors have always done environmental stewardships and humanitarian projects in order to #DiversifyTheOutdoors. Because we are a for-profit start-up business, we've had extreme difficulties getting grants and funding our projects. A lot of the efforts have come from our own pocket and time, but this isn't sustainable. So, we want to start a non-profit!

This crowdfunding campaign contributes to future aid to protect our nature and our sport. This will be a turning point in helping our community.

What We Need & What You Get

We need funds to register for the official 501(c)3 non-profit.  Becoming a 501(c)3 non-profit will allow us to make every donation tax deductible, including this fundraiser! We also want to register for the higher-prestigious 501(c)3 application because that'll give us more merit when it comes to applying for grants.

Helping us with this campaign will get you some awesome perks!

  • First, all of your donation will become tax-deductible!
  • You can join us for a private tour on climbing areas that we are developing
  • Send you a customized apparel that shows off your support for us.
  • Etc.

The Impact

This campaign allows us to create a 501(c)3 that can leave a lasting impact for our future generations. We've already done some work, and we want to do more and make sure that work has a lasting impression.

  • We've partnered with City of Riverside's Parks & Recreation to allow rock climbing at Mt. Rubidoux.
  • Worked with the San Bernardino National Forest to help create and maintain trails.
  • We've done graffiti removal with the High Desert Climbers and TrailMothers to protect nature's beauty while preserving the friction on the rock climbing routes.
  • We are currently developing several climbing areas but we need financial help to make the development high quality.
  • We want to work with the Fish & Wildlife to protecting several endangered species like the Delhi Sands flower-loving fly and the Mountain Yellow-Legged Frog.
  • We want to create grants that allow underserved communities a chance to experience the outdoors and get better at their sport of choice; ie. rock climbing or trail running.
  • And we want to do much more!

Risks & Challenges

The risk we have to face is that we don't end up getting grants. This is a fear of ours but we don't want fear to hold us back any longer. That's why we want the more prestige application for 501(c)3 to give us a better chance. We also are looking for grant writers that can help us, and the position will have a competitive compensation.

Other Ways You Can Help

You may not able to help us financially but there are plenty of other ways.

  • Please spread the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools! This is the easiest way to help.
  • And don't forget to mention to others that the funds will be tax-deductible!

story:
Legal Challenge?


Save Beeliar Wetlands is taking our campaign to the Supreme Court. We know that Roe 8/Perth Freight Link is bad policy and the wrong decision for Western Australia's future. Wetlands are fragile and delicate, and the Beeliar Wetlands can't recover from clearing 100ha - approx 1/4 of the total. There is no way that a freeway through a wetland can be anything other than an environmental disaster.

The community doesn't want this road and the cost is unacceptably high when there are better alternatives which haven't been considered. The safety of our community, our schools, our park and our homes are all under imminent threat by the Perth Freight Link.
We need to raise funds to challenge the poor decision making about Roe 8 and the Perth Freight Link. We have the support of local councils and local members of parliament both at the State and Federal level. Thousands of supporters have joined us already and given their support, time and energy. Working together we can be a powerful voice for the community. We know that the government have more legal muscle and access to funds beyond our wildest dreams - but we have people power and support beyond their fathoming! 

But we need your help! We need to raise at least $50,000, giving what you can will help us get there!

We are ordinary citizens doing extraordinary things, join us to help protect the environment, our local park, walkways, community amenity and the proper use of public money.

We urgently need you to donate to our legal fighting fund.
STOP PRESS - we have been having  some real technical difficulties with the PayPal service - if you can't get on for some reason you can make a bank transfer - if you are in Australia. 
Bendigo Bank
BSB 633-000
Account: 144 881 521
Please don't miss out on perks email: sbwcrowdfunding@gmail.com for deets of how we can get perks to you.

we are passionate, we are creative, we have fun - join us!


What is the Save Beeliar Wetlands Campaign?

The Save Beeliar Wetlands campaign is all about local community. We appreciate the ecological value and beauty of the Beeliar Wetlands, a series of swamps, wetlands and lakes across the southern corridor of Perth forming part of the Beeliar Regional Park. Local people have been involved in activity and community awareness to halt road building through this fragile environment for more than 30 years. Our campaign has grown so much in the last 2 years that it is hard to describe us. The campaign takes in all facets of the local community from the committee who meet every fortnight to the people who sit on stalls, organise fundraisers, write to the papers, take photos, play music, make soup, put up signs and contribute by making a noise and remind the government that not only do we not wan the road but we think that planning in flawed! we are passionate about our wetlands, we have been campaigning relentlessly, we are willing to put in huge effort to stop this Road to Nowhere.

More than anything though we are local people who want to stop the government building 5.5km of highway through a wetland. The current system takes truck to the Leach highway, the proposal takes trucks to the Leach highway! We think that this is madness and want to hold the government to account for poor planning and environmental recklessness.

Images from our recent rally 


What We Need & What You Get

We have an incredible team of volunteer lawyers and community members who are giving their time for this legal challenge but we need to meet their generosity by contributing funds to pay for the on going costs. While the team give their time we need to be able to pay for things like office space, research, electricity and administration costs, telephone, FOI requests and many more incidentals. The team have estimated that this will come to about $50,000. Without this money the campaign cannot continue.

This money will go directly to the legal challenge.

There will be no third parties accessing these funds.


The Impact

It is not difficult to imagine how much protecting this last remaining wetland could give our community- we enjoy it now and will do everything we can to avoid having it destroyed by an unnecessary freeway development. If we can win this we can secure a future nature space for generations of wildlife and people. Losing this precious wetlands and adjacent bushland will impact upon us all.

The biggest impacts are:

  • protecting Aboriginal and non Aboriginal culture and heritage
  • protection of habitat for threatened species such as the Carnaby's Cockatoo, Graceful Sun Moth and Southern Bandicoot.
  • continuity of the wetlands to ensure biodiversity and species survival of both animal and plant species.
  • keeping Bibra Lake and North Lake as spaces for our kids and community to enjoy
  • alerting the government to the need to listen to the people: they do not have a mandate to build this road
  • clean air
  • clean water
  • keep our homes and bush safe



Risks & Challenges

There are risks involved in the Save Beeliar Wetlands Campaign, we are putting our community organisation on the line by going to court however we believe that this is a risk that we can and should take for the good of all. Many people in the southern and western suburbs of Perth are relying on us to stop the Perth Freight Link at Roe 8. It is the best way of keeping the Government accountable and asking them to properly consider the development needs of the state, in particular the Kwinana Outer Harbour.


Our Campaign has grown from humble beginnings 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate there are so many ways to help with this campaign. Get on the websites www.savebeeliarwetlands.com  and www.rethinkthelink.com.au

story:
Short Summary

Executive Services was founded in the beginning of 2015, after I have moved back to my home country, spending nearly 5 years studying and working abroad.

I have spent 3 years in one of the oil-countries in the Middle East, with access to many oil production facilities, and have expereinced that how polluting the convetional fuel is, from the production stage all the way up, by using it by the end users, the motorists.

We provide VIP passenger transport and security services in Hungary and Europe.

In this industry most of the service providers do not care about the environment. They use big fancy cars with big engines and high fuel consumption.

This means high CO2 emission and noise pollution.

We think differently. We still wish to provide high quality of service and do something about the environment at the same time.

How??? By using environment friendly vehicles and reducing the CO2 emmission and the noise pollution.

But, we do not want to stop here. We do not only wish to use environment friendly cars, but also wish to use renewable energy to charge these cars, to make the entire project as green as possible.

I am not only asking you to support my campaign, but I encourage everyone to take steps towards saving our environment, and find the way to do business by reducing our carbon footprint.

 This way we all can contribute to our environment, for the sake of our and our children's future.

Please, help us to make our dream come true, to provide high quality service and save our environment at the same time.

What We Need & What You Get

The actual plan:

For every $100.000 we collect we are able to purchse a brand new Tesla Model S, that we can use in our limousine service.

As many times we meet this target as many electronic cars we can purchase, and do more and more about reducing our carbon footprint, by replacing a vehicle using diesel or petrol.

Step 2:

If, we can manage to have 2 or 3 electronic vehicles, we are going to install a solar power plant, to provide renewable energy for our vehicles, to reduce the need of nucler energy as much as possible.

What you get:

As for the reward, we do not want your support for free.

For each $50 support we receive we can give you a voucher equivalent of 10.000 Hungarian forints that can be redeemed for any of our services.

As more you support us with, as more vouchers you get.

Whether you need an airport transfer to and from Hungary, or just would like a joyride with a Tesla Model S, or you need security services, you can use your gift voucher to pay for our services.

You can use our vouchers as a valuable gift to your friends, family members or business partners for Christmas or any other occasions.

The list of our services and the developement of this campaign can be tracked at www.executiveservices.hu


The Impact

If, we can make this dream come true via crowdfunding we can offer our services for a very competitve price, which means that more and more people can afford to use environment friendly solutions to travel.

What else we do

We do not only care about orselves. We welcome every other initiatives that aim to protect and save our environment. Therefore we contribute to other green projects as well. Just like we did with 100% renewable by 2050 and Sustainable travel and green tourism.

Because we really think that we can make this world a better place altogether.

Risks & Challenges

What, if....

Alternatively, if we won't be able to meet our inital target of $100.000, (that would make me very said, because it means that not many people care about the environment) which we can buy our first Tesla of, we could use the collected funds to lease one, to start our green business and demonstrate that we really take this mission seriously. In this case we keep continue with our campaign in order to make enough funds to cover the leasing cost of the car, which is around $25.000 per year.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spead the word about this campaign, to reach out every environmentally concious people and help us to make our dream come true.

contribute to our environment, for the sake of our and our children's future.
Please, help us to make our dream come true, to provide high
quality service and save our environment at the same time.
   What We Need & What You Get 
The
actual plan:
For every $100.000 we collect we are able to purchse a brand
new Tesla Model S, that we can use in our limousine service.
As many times we meet this target as many electronic cars we
can purchase, and do more and more about reducing our carbon footprint, by
replacing a vehicle using diesel or petrol.
Step 2:
If, we can manage to have 2 or 3 electronic vehicles, we are
going to install a solar power plant, to provide renewable energy for our
vehicles, to reduce the need of nucler energy as much as possible.

What you get:
As for the reward, we do not want your support for free. 
For each $50 support we receive we can give you a voucher
equivalent of 10.000 Hungarian forints that can be redeemed for any of our
services.
As more you support us with, as more vouchers you get.
Whether you need an airport transfer to and from Hungary, or
just would like a joyride with a Tesla Model S, or you need security services,
you can use your gift voucher to pay for our services. 
You can use our vouchers as a valuable gift to your friends,
family members or business partners for Christmas or any other occasions.
The list of our services and the developement of this
campaign can be tracked at www.executiveservices.hu
   The Impact If, we can make this dream come true via crowdfunding we can offer our services for a very competitve price, which means that more and more people can afford to use environment friendly solutions to travel. 
What else
we do
We do not only care
about orselves. We welcome every other initiatives that aim to protect and save
our environment. Therefore we contribute to other green projects as well. Just
like we did with 100%
renewable by 2050 and Sustainable
travel and green tourism. 
Because we really think that we can make this world a
better place altogether.
  Risks & Challenges  
What,
if....
Alternatively, if we won't be able to meet our inital target
of $100.000, (that would make me very said, because it means that not many
people care about the environment) which we can buy our first Tesla of, we
could use the collected funds to lease one, to start our green business and
demonstrate that we really take this mission seriously. In this case we keep
continue with our campaign in order to make enough funds to cover the leasing
cost of the car, which is around $25.000 per year.   Other Ways You Can Help Please spead the word about this campaign, to reach out every environmentally concious people and help us to make our dream come true.

story:
The Issue

As human population continues to grow there is an increasing loss of natural habitats as human settlements invade the wilderness areas forcing wildlife to congregate in smaller ones and the human-wildlife conflict increases. Additionally the sudden rise of economies in South East Asia has caused a great demand for perceived luxury goods such as Ivory ornaments, wild animal artifacts (Lion bones, pangolin scales, gorilla hands) and alternative medicines (rhino horns) which has fuelled the illegal wildlife trade.

The loss of habitat, the increase of human-wildlife conflict and the growing wildlife trade are the major threats facing Africa's iconic wildlife species.

  • It's estimated that an elephant is shot for ivory every 15 minutes
  • Lions now only occupy 8% of their historic natural range and overall population has decreased by 43%. 
  • Mountain Gorillas are classified as critically endangered with an approximate total population less than 1000 individuals. 

New reports have recently shocked the scientific communities with the extent of the loss of giraffes and cheetahs throughout Africa.

These headlines are becoming much too frequent and the future is ominous for African wildlife if current trends don't change.

We believe there is hope for a brighter future for Africa's wildlife but we need to make a change now in whichever way possible. Africa Conservation Adventure is our way to make this change.

The Team

We are Andrea Pompele and Rebecca Phillips and together we created Africa Conservation Adventure. Andrea has an advanced academic background in biology and wildlife behavior studies as well as being a fully trained safari guide. Whilst Rebecca has a lifetime of experience of living in the African bush. We are passionate about African wilderness and its wildlife and we take our roles as conservation ambassadors very seriously. Africa Conservation Adventure combines conservation awareness, educational pursuits and photographic projects, aiming to promote key species conservation by building international awareness around ivory trade, lion’s protection and other local-level conservation projects across the African Continent

What we want

We want to ignite another global movement towards conserving Africa's iconic wildlife. By collaborating with various organisations working directly IN THE FIELD to protect wildlife and raising awareness we make a change. Some of the organisations we work with are PAMS Foundation, Virunga National Park, WildAid East Africa and many others. We will make short interviews and videos of them to share on the social media. Social Media is powerful tool for reaching a wide international audience and we want to make the most of this. We will also use photos we will take from the expedition for releasing a limited edition photo-book. Sales from the photo book will provide further funding for the organisations we partner with and their work.

We will collect informations, highlight human-wildlife conflicts issues, poaching crisis and seek to understand more about the major challenges and difficulties these organisations are facing every day. These dedicated conservationists are the ones that work hard and risk their lives to protect the African wilderness. Without them the future is bleak so we want to underline the importance of these organisations and their essential work. Community involvement, education, and direct financial benefits are needed. 

We want to give them something back by broadcasting their importance and hard work to a larger public and finding opportunities to make their work more sustainable and expanding their direct impact.

How

The funds we will raise will go directly into conservation: such as paying park fees and permits (an important source of income for the national parks to continue to protect and conserve ecosystems). We will also manage conservation initiatives together with the organisations we will visit, supporting them with funding to help them directly and also by spreading their work in social media and through our photos released in a photo book.

Sales from the photobook will help them concretely: all the profits from the publication of the book will go directly to sustain their field work and help them day by day to carry on. 

Why

Losing iconic African species such as Elephants, Lions and Gorillas will not just be a major loss and disruption to natural habitats but also a big loss to humanity as they are part of our heritage  - so this something that affects us all!

We believe in education and development and we think that sharing accurate information is a powerful tool to change the world.

Everybody can do something important and help make a change they want to see, a small action can lead to a powerful impact. The magnitude of your contribution will help our conservation project to take off the ground and help protect wildlife concretely and directly.

 

What We Need & What You Get

This project is estimated and budgeted to an amount of $15,000 where we will cover any other non-budgeted costs privately. Besides supporting conservation initiatives we need funds to cover the costs of travelling, photographing, filming and editing.

The money will be divided to cover;

  • Travelling costs such as fuel and visas,
  • Money directly put in conservation: Permits, Park fees,
  • Conservation initiatives directly managed by us 
  • Production costs of editing and printing the photobook
  • Accommodation
  • Additional equipment required after our previous trip such as vehicle spares, solar lights, waterproofing for our cameras etc. 

The Photobook

Composed of a combination of both of our top wildlife and landscape photographs from the trip. These are all taken with a professional photographic approach (of course we are wildlife photographers) and our own personal photographic styles evident throughout the book. Top quality materials will be used to do our pictures justice and to guarantee quality. 

Example extract from our previous book: 

The Perks

Our perks are designed to make you happy, they are personal, direct, unique and of course ethical! The greatest perk for anyone who contributes at any amount is the knowledge and assurance that you will be informing the world about the real dangers wildlife are facing and supporting solutions to save them from extinction in the wild.

The Impact

To clarify: we don’t have a definitive solution to save the wildlife, but we can act to do something and sustain the projects that are making a difference. Wildlife is a human heritage and we are responsible for them!

The more funds we can raise the more we will be able to do for sustainable conservation which will have a bigger impact on our end goal. Everybody can make an impact and be a part of making the changes our planet needs!

Whether or not you support our expedition is up to you. If you do, it's something you do for protecting wildlife. Not for anyone else. Not for us but for them . We are proud of you!

Every dollar we raise for this campaign is not just money, it is a vote of confidence, you will help a small conservation project get off the ground and help in an practical way to protect wildlife.

Thank you for all your support we are looking forward to starting the adventure and being part of a long term impact on creating a better and more sustainable world.

Our previous expedition

Africa Conservation Adventure was created a year ago and we did our first expedition in March and April 2016 as a means of contributing to the cause of ending wildlife crime.

We released a photo-book showcasing the fascinating natural reserves and the abundant wildlife we encountered throughout our expedition in Southern Africa going through Tanzania, Malawi, Zambia, Zimbabwe, Botswana and Namibia. Along our journey we met with members of PAMS Foundation, Lilongwe Wildlife Trust and Game Rangers International and heard about the different challenges they faced in fighting wildlife crime in their respective countries. It became clear to us that fighting against wildlife crime requires an international network and cooperation that exceeds the geographical borders. We learnt that education and information shared on an International level is a key factor in turning the tide on wildlife crime and that is what we are striving to do.

Our last expedition was a success and a start of something bigger which now we would like to make it even better. We can't stop exploring and acting for conservation, it's our mission. 

AMAZON BOOK AFRICA CONSERVATION ADVENTURE 2016

Preview: http://www.blurb.com/books/7441522-africa-conservation-adventure-2016

To buy: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1366919513

Risks & Challenges

Risks for us

We are going to travel during the rainy season from end of March till the end of May 2017 which can cause difficult driving conditions. We will camp in a basic tent in savannahs, tropical forests and mountain areas. 
Hiking and tracking Gorillas, Chimpanzees and visiting Volcanoes (in Virunga) above 3000 m altitude through thick rainforest during the rains will provide challenging.  When it decides to rain in East Africa it seriously pours! But if there is no challenge, then where is the fun?

Don’t worry we will travel safe, we are used to the wilderness. We have a plan... And it’s a good one!

Risks for Conservation

This is a flexible campaign meaning that we will go ahead with our trip even if we don't reach full amount. However if our target funding is not achieved this will bring less money to conservation, limit the awareness we can raise and reduce the length and duration of the expedition – more money gained is more money supporting the real action against threats of wildlife. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign with your friends and family.

Make some noise about this project and help us spread our vision! Follow us on social media and share the message of our expedition. Every effort you make is important for us and you can easily follow, like and share our posts to reach a wider audience.

Follow us on FACEBOOK: https://www.facebook.com/africaconservationadve...

Follow us on INSTAGRAM: https://www.instagram.com/africaconservationadventure/

Follow us on TWITTER: https://twitter.com/AdventureLifePr

You can also use the Indiegogo Tools to share this campaign.

 

Organisations we promote and help

 

 

They are speaking about us

 

 

Sources

For more information visit these websites:

  • https://yearoftheelephant.org/
  • http://iworry.org/crisis/
  • http://march4elephantsandrhinos.org/crisis-2/
  • http://letlionslive.org/
  • http://www.awf.org/wildlife-conservation/mounta...
  • http://huffingtonpost.com/entry/giraffe-endanged-species_us_584954d8e4b064104145d749 
  • http://telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/12/27/cheetahs-facing-extinction-amid-dramatic-decline-numbers/

Or watch these films:

  • THE IVORY GAME - https://theivorygame.com/
  • BEFORE THE FLOOD - https://www.beforetheflood.com/
  • BLOOD LIONS - http://www.bloodlions.org/

story:
Check out the story and details for campaign here please.

https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/road-of-comp...

https://www.facebook.com/Road-of-Compassion-250...

I ride for all humans and all animals and the entire planet because we are all connected.

Read below how veganism could end world hunger.

http://www.cowspiracy.com/facts/

http://gentleworld.org/could-veganism-end-world...

What happened in the last few months:

We just raised enough money to pay for the trike. All other costs like flying to Austria and transport it from A to C so to speak I paid out of own pocket. Which is why all my savings are gone and I'm pretty much broke right now.

On the way from Oslo to L.A the trike got left behind because the guys who check special equipment for drugs and stuff weren't fast enough.

So on December 3rd I arrived at Vancouver Airport not knowing about the whereabouts of my 'Red Racer'. After a week on the phone to find out were the trike currently is and how it's gonna be delivered it finally was brought to Elisabeth and Stephen's house.

Elisabeth and Stephen were so nice to store it for me for a while because it doesn't fit through my apartment door. Talking about things that can make what's a normal day to day activity for most difficult for me. It's not the disability itself that is a problem it's the environment and that it's just not really accessible and sometimes people who think that the disability would be a problem for me, that makes it hard for me. 

I have interests and a passion to liberate animals and save humans and the planet. I would rather talk about that with people than repeat for the millions time why I use a wheelchair. 'Wheelchairs are just indoor bikes.'

The Red Racer and I were eagerly awaiting better weather so I could start to go on training rides. Until Wednesday there was ice on the streets around their house.

On January 20, was my birthday, today (January 23) is Richard Dean Anderson's birthday and on January 28, is my mom's birthday. So finally on January 27 or January 28 to celebrate these 3 special days, I will go on my first training ride. YEAH. It's gonna be soooooo awesome. 

If you would have time to go on a training ride with me, please let me know. It would really help a lot. I can't take the wheelchair with me when I ride, so just to be on the safe side it's better if someone rides with me especially for the first few weeks. You can help and get your exercise done at the same time. :)

As we don't have any funds right now we are depending on volunteers and schedules of possible drivers and people who help out. That means it looks like we will start the trip at the beginning of May or end of May.

We have a volunteer driver who has time next spring.

We also have a trailer that we can borrow from a very helpful supporter. That is so awesome!!!

As it is a trailer not a motorhome we now are looking for someone who would be willing to lent us his jeep or truck to pull our home on four wheels.

I also need to pay people to accompany and assist me on the road as well as the camera person for 9-10 weeks plus gas, food and traveling insurance for them. Depending on if we have volunteers or not this can cost up $10, 000

The indiegogo, credit cards and paypal fees take 10% from whatever we raise.

Any money donated above what we need to get on the road we can use to rescue animals, donate to the sanctuaries.

Any donation people can make within the next 14 days will make my birthday. :)

We will go on the road as soon as financially possible.

We really appreciate your help.

Thanks 

Alex

story:
Hello! My name is Maddy and I am currently pursuing my Master of Science in primate conservation at Oxford Brookes University. My research focuses on conserving orangutans and as such I will be traveling to Indonesia for three months to conduct of a behavioral study on juveniles living together in captivity at a rehabilitation center.  I will be looking specifically at Bornean orangutans (Pongo pygmaeus.) This species is listed as endangered on the IUCN red list and the Sumatran orangutan (Pongo abelii) is listed as critically endangered. With the expansion of the ever efficient oil palm plantations, we are losing habitat fast so these animals are arriving in rehab centers at a rapid pace. I believe that understanding species specific behavior and development is vital for successfully rehabilitating primates and reintroducing them back into the wild. Furthermore, I believe that rehab and reintroduction critical to the conservation of these animals. 


(Untitled by Madeline Thaler)

I have been working with primate rehabilitation for the last five years. In this time, I have seen first hand what monkeys and apes are up against in their wild homes. Infants and babies are brought into these centers on a daily basis and since they are so much like us, they need a mother to survive and cannot just be mended and sent right back into the wild. This means there is a huge amount of time invested in trying to get these animals back to their homes in the wild. 

(Contemplation by S. Yume. Used under CC BY 2.0)

More than 1200 orang-utans reside in rehabilitation centres in Kalimantan, Indonesia. Though the ultimate goal is for these animals to be reintroduced into protected forests, they often spend their entire infancy or longer (5-10 years) in captivity where they learn how to be an orang-utan from humans and the many other orphaned orang-utans they are housed with. Orang-utans in captive environments like this have an increased opportunity for social interactions than they do in the wild. As such, they have been observed to engage in social play at greater rates. The role of play in mammalian development is still a greatly debated topic.  Play is often described as a "luxury" or "opportunity" behavior that will only be observed when the costs of play are low because all proximate needs are met or as a behavior critical for learning socially appropriate behaviors specific to living in large groups.  However, the overall functions and role in development of social play in orangutan development can be more difficult to understand given the relatively solitary habits of orangutans in the wild and there are many questions raised by this variation in rates of social play seen in captive orang-utans as opposed to wild ones.  

(Mother and Infant by Helen Buckland. Used under CC BY 2.0)

Since play is both used as an indicator of adequate welfare and believed to be critical for primate development, my research aims to further understand the function of play in captive orang-utan development by observing individual variation in play types and frequencies of juvenile orang-utans housed together at International Animal Rescue's (IAR) orang-utan rehabilitation centre near Ketapang in West Kalimantan, Indonesia.  You can learn more about IAR here: http://www.internationalanimalrescue.org/orangu...

All my data and results will be made available to IAR who I will be collaborating with and an official report will be given to them with any recommendations that this research results in. This is to ensure that my research will not simply be a theoretical document, but a practical piece of literature that will be available to the people working closest with these animals to keep them safe. 

(Young Orangutan Sitting By Mom by Erik Kilby. Used under CC BY 2.0)

I am aiming to raise these funds to pay for my transportation, accommodation, vaccines, visas,  and  some gear that I will be taking into the field with me. In return I can promise email updates to anyone who is interested in hearing about my trip. Every bit helps so please give even a buck if you can! If not, that's cool! But please please share this with anyone and everyone! 


(Other images used: Baby Orangutan by Ellen Munro  and baby orang oetan by belgianchocolate. Both used under CC BY 2.0)
story_txt:
Hello! My name is Maddy and I am currently pursuing my Master of Science in primate conservation at Oxford Brookes University. My research focuses on conserving orangutans and as such I will be traveling to Indonesia for three months to conduct of a behavioral study on juveniles living together in captivity at a rehabilitation center.  I will be looking specifically at Bornean orangutans (Pongo pygmaeus.) This species is listed as endangered on the IUCN red list and the Sumatran orangutan (Pongo abelii) is listed as critically endangered. With the expansion of the ever efficient oil palm plantations, we are losing habitat fast so these animals are arriving in rehab centers at a rapid pace. I believe that understanding species specific behavior and development is vital for successfully rehabilitating primates and reintroducing them back into the wild. Furthermore, I believe that rehab and reintroduction critical to the conservation of these animals. (Untitled by Madeline Thaler)I have been working with primate rehabilitation for the last five years. In this time, I have seen first hand what monkeys and apes are up against in their wild homes. Infants and babies are brought into these centers on a daily basis and since they are so much like us, they need a mother to survive and cannot just be mended and sent right back into the wild. This means there is a huge amount of time invested in trying to get these animals back to their homes in the wild. (Contemplation by S. Yume. Used under CC BY 2.0)
