story:
Luke, Dean, and Mark love our embroidered beanies and caps.

What Is Our Future Footprint?

Our Future Footprint aims to use comfortable clothing as a vehicle for combating climate change. By contributing to preservation, conservation, and education initiatives, Our Future Footprint is determined to make a difference in our community, and leave a positive impact on the Earth we love.

Our Future Footprint t-shirts use only sustainable materials, including bamboo, hemp, and organic cotton. They are responsibly made by a carbon-neutral manufacturer. We also offer a lifetime guarantee on our shirts; if it isn’t the most comfortable shirt you’ve worn, or you want to return it for any reason, you can send it right back.

Megan and Keil are wearing our silk screened bamboo shirts.

We can also offer the guarantee of feeling good about your purchase with Our Future Footprint. By buying with us, you can reduce your carbon footprint in three different ways:       

Preservation: Our Future Footprint has teamed up with OneTreePlanted to turn our carbon-neutral apparel into a carbon-reduction movement. For every t-shirt that you purchase with Our Future Footprint, we will plant three trees. 

Conservation: The Earth is beautiful as it is...let's keep it that way. Our Future Footprint is dedicating 3% of top-line revenue to conservation initiatives. 

Education: We want a greener Earth to pass on to our children, but the work doesn't stop with us. Education is key for keeping our Earth alive for many generations to come. Our Future Footprint will also donate 3% of top-line revenue to education initiatives; the reality of climate change, and what we can do to keep our planet healthy, will be passed on to our neighbors, friends, and children.

Our Future Footprint is proudly based in Austin, Texas. Megan is wearing our embroidered baseball cap.

Why Indiegogo? Why Now?

Our Future Footprint shirts and apparel are only available through our Indiegogo campaign (for now.) If Our Future Footprint was a tree, it would still be a seedling. In order to give our company a proper launch, we want to do something big. That’s where Indiegogo comes in.

With roughly $50,000, Our Future Footprint can get our feet off the ground, and approximately 5,000 trees in the ground. By planting 5,000 trees, we will be able to absorb over 160,000 pounds of carbon dioxide, and produce over 800,000 pounds of oxygen each year. Over the trees's lifetime, we can absorb 6.4 million pounds of carbon dioxide and produce 32 million pounds of oxygen.

Indiegogo is just the beginning for Our Future Footprint. After our launch, we will expand our business to include different types of apparel, more designs, and eventually buying materials to produce apparel ourselves, in the United States. The more we raise through Indiegogo, the more we donate to conservation and education initiatives. The more shirts that are purchased, the more trees that are planted.

After our campaign has finished, you can purchase apparel and learn more about our movement on our website.

Your donation is your vote for a company that will give back to its community through preservation, conservation, and education. Your donation is a vote for company that believes sustainability should be a top priority for any business, and that each of us can make a difference.

Want to donate? Thank you so much!

We appreciate every dollar. If you want to take advantage of exclusive apparel for Indiegogo backers, consider claiming one of our perks: 

Plant a Tree with OneTreePlanted:

In April, we helped to plant trees with OneTreePlanted in Boulder, Colorado. Megan is pictured wearing our Embroidered Baseball Cap and Embroidered Hemp T-shirt! 

Exclusive Hats and Beanies: 

Exclusive Our Future Footprint Silk Screened T-Shirts: 

Megan is wearing our bamboo t-shirt. Keil is wearing our hemp t-shirt. Both shirts are available in men's and women's sizes. These two scenes are exclusive for Indiegogo backers...you won't get them anywhere else! Some day this will be worth as much as your old band or festival t-shirts.

 

This design is also available for our hemp or bamboo t-shirts. Long sleeved shirts are only available in bamboo.

Love these designs? Grab them now! These designs will only be available for backers who support our Indiegogo campaign.

Custom Our Future Footprint Shirts for Your Business:

Keil is wearing a custom logo bamboo shirt for Austin Electric Vehicles.

In addition to these cool, comfortable products, you will get the satisfaction of knowing that you are planting trees, that a part of your donation is going to conservation initiatives, and part of your donation is going to education initiatives. By backing Our Future Footprint, you are giving water and sunshine to a small seedling of a company that hopes to grow into a forest.

How Carbon Affects the Environment

We are proud to say that Our Future Footprint is a carbon-reduction movement…but what exactly does that mean?

We breathe in oxygen. We breathe out carbon dioxide, a combination of carbon and oxygen. Carbon dioxide is “inhaled” by plants and trees to produce oxygen. Oxygen and carbon dioxide, when balanced in an ecosystem, help to keep plants, trees, animals, and humans alive.

Sounds great, right? But carbon, and carbon dioxide, isn't just produced when we breathe. Let’s talk about fossil fuels. We use fossil fuels to power almost everything: electricity, gas for our cars and planes, heating for our homes, etc. When we burn fossil fuels, carbon is released into the air. And with more people, more houses, and more industry than ever before, we are burning tons and tons of carbon dioxide. Our plants and trees can’t keep up. Trees are also being cut down at high rates to make room for growing populations, the agriculture industry, infrastructure, and more. That's too much work for our trees!

Carbon dioxide is beneficial when it is being used to nourish plants and trees, but in such high quantities, it can be disastrous for our planet. It is a “greenhouse gas;” when greenhouse gases are stuck in the environment with nowhere to go, they trap heat that would normally be leaving the Earth. This heat is what’s causing global warming and climate change.

Global warming is melting polar ice caps and glaciers, increasing sea levels, increasing the risk of wildfires and droughts, and causing extreme weather changes and events. If we don’t step up and reduce our carbon footprints, global warming will continue to have a catastrophic effect on our earth.

We need to reduce our carbon emissions, and we need to do it now. That’s why Sustainability Initiatives has launched Our Future Footprint; if one person, and one t-shirt, can reduce 100 pounds of carbon dioxide and produce 500 pounds of oxygen in one year, we can make a change and reduce our carbon footprint. 

We love this place. Dean is wearing an Our Future Footprint silk screened shirt and embroidered cap.

Other Ways You Can Help Reduce Our Future Footprint

Even if you do not have the money to donate today, we appreciate your efforts in reducing Our Future Footprint. Here are some of the ways you can help to reduce the amount of carbon the atmosphere:

  • Drive a car with high fuel economy…or take alternative transportation (biking, public transportation, carpooling)
  • Turn off your lights and unplug appliances when you’re not using them. Reducing your energy bill also helps to reduce your carbon footprint!
  • Install solar paneling where possible
  • Eat food that is locally produced
  • Cut down on meat and dairy products
  • Reduce, reuse, recycle!
  • Support carbon neutral businesses and businesses that integrate sustainable practices

Want to make some noise about Our Future Footprint? Sounds great! Here’s what you can do:

  • Like and Follow Our Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram Accounts
  • Connect With Us on LinkedIn
  • Share Our Message On Your Social Media Pages
  • Visit Our Website And Sign Up for Our Mailing List
  • Talk To Your Friends and Family About Reducing Your Carbon Footprint

We love this place. Help us by saying, “Thank You” to the Earth by taking the steps to reduce Our Future Footprint.

story:
Your Impact on Us

  • Will help us complete the journey to Save more pets 
  • Continue to find better ways to serve rescues around the globe
  • Provide a fun and productive working environment 

Ways You Can Help

We recognize some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please pass the word about this wonderful opportunity to all your friends, relatives, and anyone you think wants to help us be a voice for pets.
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Our Thanks to All

story:
Today's waste problem in Central America

In many countries in Central America waste has become over the past years a real problem and threat to destabilize the environment. Recycling activities on local country level do exist, but mainly focused on few materials and also focused on exporting these materials for further processing in other countries.

Many wastes land either on landfills/city dumps, are burned or simply end up along roads, in rivers, lakes and through rivers in the oceans. Contamination of valuable and exquisite flora and fauna within the countries, within the water systems and alongside coastal areas where they are washed up has become a real threat to natural and economical structures of each country.

Roughly, following solid wastes are being recycled and/or collected:

-  Metals, non-ferrous (f.e. copper, tin, precious metals, hard-metals, etc.) and ferrous (HMS 1, HMS 2, etc.)

-  Paper and cardboard

-  Plastics (mainly PET, some Poleolefines (HDPE, LDPE & PP))

Metals:  both ferrous and non-ferrous metals are mainly exported to other countries for recycling purposes. Local recycling plants are either non-existent, or capacities are too little or materials involved cannot be recycled properly due to missing technology. Exports are to Guatemala, Colombia, Chile but mainly to Mexico, USA, India and China

Paper and Cardboard:  The capacities of existing paper mills for recycling purposes cannot cover by far the volumes collected of both paper and cardboard. Most volumes are exported to Colombia and mainly overseas

Plastics:  PET recycling as such is well developed in most countries. This due to the fact that PET bottles are by far the largest volume of post-consumer plastic scrap occurring in all markets. PET recycling can be split into following segments:

o  Collecting and pressing into bales for export within Central America and export to overseas

o  Cold washing into PET flakes for export overseas

o  Hot washing into PET flakes for local use and mainly export overseas

o  Bottle2Bottle by few large breweries

Poleolefines (Polyethylene/PE & Polypropylene/PP)

PE and PP related materials are partially collected and some are recycled locally. “Partially” has following meaning:

o  Post Industrial waste is normally “rather” clean. Many of the post industrial wastes are collected and recycled. Nevertheless, many post industrial plastic wastes don’t have proper ways currently to re-enter the recycling circle (especially Styrofoam/EPS and engineering/technical plastics)

o  Post consumer waste of PE & PP is the vast majority of plastic wastes next to PET bottles. Here substantial volumes are collected and prepared for recycling, but also substantial volumes still remain a problem for disposal and especially the environment

Plastics from dismantled cars

Most plastics from dismantled cars are currently not collected and simply disposed of. Many plastics are technical plastics of which almost no know how exists how to handle them properly.

Technical plastics

Many technical plastics also originate from electrical appliances and computers and TV’s/Flat screens. While some specialized companies are dismantling such products to gather the metal components from it (copper & precious metals) the plastics are mainly disposed of after dismantling

Other plastics in general

Many other commonly used plastics like CD’s, Covers of CD’s and DVD’s, Styrofoam, Polystyrol from cups and dairy products are landing in the landfill or are simply disposed of, again harming the environment.

The main problems we see and have encountered in many countries is that very few plastic materials are well known, but most of them are unknown how to handle them. The missing know how on plastics and the ways how to handle and recycle them is a main reason that too many plastics end up either in landfills or simply next to the streets, rivers, lakes and oceans.

Our project

Our project focusses initially on plastics only. By bringing know how and technology to various countries we decrease the littering of plastic wastes into the natural and populated areas and environment and also decreasing the air pollution since lots of plastics are burned too.

Only with financial incentives this goal can be achieved and by doing so many positive effects are generated. Here a small listing

-  Increase recycling volumes of plastics with effect of substantially lowering littering of plastics into the nature

-  Creating new jobs for low income and barely educated parts of the population in each country, thus lowering unemployment. We aim especially at a workforce of up to 80% of women. On one hand it is a great chance for women originating from poorer/low income parts of the society. Many are uneducated, illerate and have little chances to find stable work opportunities. On the other hand income generated by women are of great importance to support themselves and their family as this income is not wasted on non-day2day expenditures in general. Women also bring the better qualities for our venture as precision and accuracy in the selection/grading process of plastics is most important.

-  Assisting governmental institutions/municipalities to implement and realize new waste regulations (f.e. Costa Rica)

-  Increased protection of the natural habitat and at the same time preventing waste to spoil into natural areas important for the tourism industries

-  Sustainable development of recycling awareness and implementation on country level

Current activities

The main principle of our project is to work with local partners on country level. The local partner has to be already active in some kind of recycling activity and provide the initial infrastructure and network with the market to become operational on short notice.

Guatemala

Our carefully chosen partner is located in Guatemala City. They are currently operating 5 warehouses – 3 in GC, 2 in the country side – to collect and grade various grades of paper & cardboard. Their total monthly volume handled today is approx. 4000t. Our partner has a supplier network of approx. 500 small to medium sized companies who now also start to collect all kinds of plastics for our processing plant.

At this moment we have provided following know how and first technology:

-  Plastic grinder with capacity of approx. 700 kg output per hour

-  We have started educating the staff on material level

-  Periphery machines have been acquired locally and have been installed (running belt to feed the grinder, blower&cyclones to automatically collect the grinded material, washing line to wash the plastics after being grinded)

-  Manual classification has started and a special bunker system for intermediate storage for each classified material is being prepared and installed at this moment

Honduras

Our carefully chosen partner is located in San Pedro Sula. His current business focusses only on metal scrap collection, grading, compacting and exporting the metals to smelters. The owner and CEO of the company has a long history within PET recycling and brings lots of experience on the equipment side to handle plastics.

At this moment we have provided following know how and technology

-  2 plastic grinders with a capacity of approx. 700kg and 400 kg output per hour

-  We have started educating the staff on material level

-  Periphery machines have been acquired locally and have been installed (running belt to feed the grinder, blower & cyclones to automatically collect the grinded material, washing line to wash the plastics after being grinded)

-  A large conveyor belt for classification is currently being built so overall efficiency and volumes to be processed can be increased

-  Manual classification has started and a special bunker system for intermediate storage for each classified material is being prepared and installed at this moment

Sales channels

-  Local sales for producers of various products

-  Export within Latin America, North America, Europe and Asia

Milestones

1.  Establish supply channels of raw materials to be able to collect and process min 200-300t or raw materials per month till the end of this year

2.  Establish contact to municipalities and various organizations to setup up with assistance of the government/municipalities own collection points for various materials

3.  Further development and installation of technical equipment for collection and processing (min 1 fully integrated processing lines encompassing all steps of processing after classification by end of this year per country)

4.  Installing other technical equipment to enlarge the scope of handling waste plastics like Styrofoam

5.  Increase staff headcount and educating both staff and supply side to increase awareness of all plastics we can handle

6.  Establishing different processing points in each country, thus enlarging the geographical collection nation wide

Vision and goals of our project

1.  Reduce environmental pollution !

2.  Increase recycling cycle for currently wasted plastics by bringing them back into the world of raw materials

3.  New job opportunities directly at own processing plants and many on side of small to medium size collectors. Main job opportunities will be for women due to their work quality, reliability and sustainability of income generation for their families

4.  Clean and environmentally friendly process of making waste into raw material

5.  Establish new till today undeveloped areas of recycling, thus further collecting other materials for clean and proper recycling (possible chemical wastes, batteries, organic waste for bio-gas manufacturing, etc.)

Investments till today

Till today, we have personally invested substantially in our first established setup of operational activities. All current investments have been based with own equity without being supported by any local or international government or institution.

Investments planned

The investments needed/planned are to further develop our activities in each country on technological side and collection side of the raw materials.

Collection points within the country side:

-  Establishing collection centers within the country side of each country. This to enable local small to medium size providers of raw materials to supply their locally collected materials without having to worry about logistics within the country. Since loose material as of weight cannot be economically be transported efficiently, also lack of transportation possibilities prevent many small to medium size providers to collect and supply materials to us.

-  On the other hand it also does not make sense to use many trucks to drive all over the country and collect loose material due to weight inefficiencies and pollution factors

-  It is planned to setup small baling machines in easy accessible locations through the country. Local providers will be able to deliver with little efforts the volumes to our collection yards, this enlarging the collection areas and reducing littering at the same time countrywide

-  Once the material is received, a first classification will be done and then goods will be compacted by baling machines for efficient onward transportation on the road to our central operational center in each country.

-  The decentralized collection structure enables a sustainable supply and at the same time brings the biggest effect on creating new jobs in many parts of the countries involved – indirect new jobs for people working for the small to medium sized providers/suppliers and also direct new jobs at our collection centers where materials will be classified and pressed into bales.

Central operational center

Since we do expect overall volume to grow very fast, also due to the fact of setting up local collection points within each country, new fully integrated processing lines will be required to be able to handle the upcoming volumes. Fully integrated lines encompass

-  Shredder (downsize big sized material for the grinder)

-  Grinder

-  Washing line

-  Drying line

-  Packaging line

ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION WITH SOCIAL RESPOSIBILITY

Support our project for a sustainable recycling concept in Central America
story_txt:
Today's waste problem in Central AmericaIn many
countries in Central America waste has become over the past years a real
problem and threat to destabilize the environment. Recycling activities on
local country level do exist, but mainly focused on few materials and also
focused on exporting these materials for further processing in other countries.
Many wastes
land either on landfills/city dumps, are burned or simply end up along roads,
in rivers, lakes and through rivers in the oceans. Contamination of valuable
and exquisite flora and fauna within the countries, within the water systems
and alongside coastal areas where they are washed up has become a real threat
to natural and economical structures of each country.
Roughly,
following solid wastes are being recycled and/or collected:
- 
Metals,
non-ferrous (f.e. copper, tin, precious metals, hard-metals, etc.) and ferrous
(HMS 1, HMS 2, etc.)
- 
Paper
and cardboard
- 
Plastics
(mainly PET, some Poleolefines (HDPE, LDPE & PP))
Metals:  both
ferrous and non-ferrous metals are mainly exported to other countries for
recycling purposes. Local recycling plants are either non-existent, or
capacities are too little or materials involved cannot be recycled properly due
to missing technology. Exports are to Guatemala, Colombia, Chile but mainly to
Mexico, USA, India and China
Paper and Cardboard:  The
capacities of existing paper mills for recycling purposes cannot cover by far
the volumes collected of both paper and cardboard. Most volumes are exported to
Colombia and mainly overseas
Plastics:  PET
recycling as such is well developed in most countries. This due to the fact
that PET bottles are by far the largest volume of post-consumer plastic scrap
occurring in all markets. PET recycling can be split into following segments:
o 
Collecting
and pressing into bales for export within Central America and export to
overseas
o 
Cold
washing into PET flakes for export overseas
o 
Hot
washing into PET flakes for local use and mainly export overseas
o 
Bottle2Bottle
by few large breweries
Poleolefines (Polyethylene/PE &
Polypropylene/PP)
PE and PP related materials are partially
collected and some are recycled locally. “Partially” has following meaning:
o 
Post
Industrial waste is normally “rather” clean. Many of the post industrial wastes
are collected and recycled. Nevertheless, many post industrial plastic wastes
don’t have proper ways currently to re-enter the recycling circle (especially
Styrofoam/EPS and engineering/technical plastics)
o 
Post
consumer waste of PE & PP is the vast majority of plastic wastes next to
PET bottles. Here substantial volumes are collected and prepared for recycling,
but also substantial volumes still remain a problem for disposal and especially
the environment
Plastics from dismantled cars
Most plastics from dismantled cars are
currently not collected and simply disposed of. Many plastics are technical
plastics of which almost no know how exists how to handle them properly.
Technical plastics
Many technical plastics also originate from
electrical appliances and computers and TV’s/Flat screens. While some
specialized companies are dismantling such products to gather the metal
components from it (copper & precious metals) the plastics are mainly
disposed of after dismantling
Other plastics in general
Many other commonly used plastics like CD’s,
Covers of CD’s and DVD’s, Styrofoam, Polystyrol from cups and dairy products
are landing in the landfill or are simply disposed of, again harming the
environment.
The main
problems we see and have encountered in many countries is that very few plastic
materials are well known, but most of them are unknown how to handle them. The
missing know how on plastics and the ways how to handle and recycle them is a
main reason that too many plastics end up either in landfills or simply next to
the streets, rivers, lakes and oceans. 
Our project
Our project
focusses initially on plastics only. By bringing know how and technology to
various countries we decrease the littering of plastic wastes into the natural
and populated areas and environment and also decreasing the air pollution since
lots of plastics are burned too.
Only with
financial incentives this goal can be achieved and by doing so many positive
effects are generated. Here a small listing
- 
Increase
recycling volumes of plastics with effect of substantially lowering littering
of plastics into the nature
- 
Creating
new jobs for low income and barely educated parts of the population in each
country, thus lowering unemployment. We aim especially at a workforce of up to
80% of women. On one hand it is a great chance for women originating from poorer/low
income parts of the society. Many are uneducated, illerate and have little
chances to find stable work opportunities. On the other hand income generated
by women are of great importance to support themselves and their family as this
income is not wasted on non-day2day expenditures in general. Women also bring
the better qualities for our venture as precision and accuracy in the
selection/grading process of plastics is most important. 
-

governmental institutions/municipalities to implement and realize new waste
regulations (f.e. Costa Rica)
-

-

story:
LETS CLIMB TOGETHER FOR PEACE!

                  SUPPORT YOUNG ACTIVISTS FOR K-PROJECT FOR PEACE  

K-PROJECT FOR PEACE has since grown from an appeal to an international campaign bringing on board 30 young activists from all over the world with a vision to see 'Africa Free of Uranium Mining, and the World Free of Nuclear Weapons'. If you are wondering, Uranium is the raw material used to manufacture nuclear weapons, the most dangerous weapons known to man, and the explosion of which would put TWO BILLION lives at risk. 
This is a 'first of its kind' campaign from Africa. As 30 young activists, we are climbing Mt. Kilimanjaro (30th June-4th July, 2015) which is the highest free standing mountain in the world to demonstrate that its possible to achieve such a lofty goal as a nuclear free planet and halt Uranium mining in THIS GENERATION.
We are also organizing the '1ST K-PROJECT FOR PEACE Conference' that will bring together 100 people representing civil society organizations that address issues of Uranium mining to create a 'Network of Young U-BAN Campaign Activists' that will continue to advocate for the ban on Uranium mining post-Kilimanjaro climb.

JOIN US!
Your donation will go a long way to do the following:
1) Support a young activist climber (USD 1089)
2) Make it possible for a young activist to attend the '1ST K-PROJECT FOR PEACE Conference' (USD 200)
3) Subsidize transportation costs for the young activists outside of East Africa to reach Moshi, Tanzania (USD 500)

NB:
 K-PROJECT FOR PEACE is hosted by IPPNW Africa 

For further details go to our website www.ippnwafrica.org

Twitter: http://goo.gl/5CiGa7; Facebook page: http://goo.gl/RZiOQ6 

 Every individual or organization that donates will have their name published on our website in recognition of their support.

story:
ABOUT I AM WATER and Project Ecuador:
I AM WATER Ocean Conservation is a global non-profit founded by freediver Hanli Prinsloo and a group of ocean-loving proffessionals. Having experienced the magnificence and fragility of the ocean and her creatures, the I AM WATER team believes in ocean conservation through human experience. Getting kids in the water, excited, engaged, inspired - they protect what they love! We run workshops for preteens in coastal communities around the world. 
We are in Ecuador working on our pilot project together with our local partners:

Marine Megafauna Foundation/ Proyecto Mantas Ecuador 

For more updates about the program, follow I AM WATER Ocean Conservation Trust on Facebook.

To all our supporters THANK YOU - you will be receiving some updates and perks soon!

Thank you for helping secure OCEANS FOR ALL!

Remember to like us on facebook and follow us on Twitter and Instagram.

I AM WATER Ocean Conservation is proud to be a MISSION BLUE partner. With thanks to Kip Evans and Dr. Sylvia Earle for your support and use of the interview on the rocks. Campaign video edit: Steven Michelsen.

Project Ecuador in partnership with the Marine Megafauna Foundation.

story:
Help Divers for Sharks get its camera back!

We are a Divers for Sharks. A little about our work can be seen at our facebook page here: www.facebook.com/diversforsharks

Our co founder were robbed in action at Rio, Brazil, and now we need another camera, lens and tripod. It was a Canon T4i.

Please help us get a new one, so we can keep on fighting for the oceans, seas, sharks and all marine life!

If you can't help us donating, please spread this page so your friends can help us too!

We count on you!

Paulo Guilherme "Penguin"

Divers for Sharks precisa de uma nova câmera!

Nosso co fundador foi assaltado no centro do Rio e levaram nossa câmera, tripé e lente.

Por favor nos ajude a continuar lutando e registrando nossas ações pela preservação dos mares, oceanos, tubarões e toda vida mainha contribuindo com a quantidade que vc puder!

Mais sobre o projeto Divers for Sharks pode ser conhecido no link: facebook.com/diversforsharks

Se você não puder contribuir, por favor nos ajude ainda assim a compartilhar esta página.

Contamos com a sua ajuda e vamos que vamos!

Paulo Guilherme "Pingüim"

story:
What We Need & What You Get

Climate Action is a project of advocacy and awareness.

  • We need resources to send 5 volunteers to the Climate Change Conference during 2 weeks.
  • The team will work 14 days continuously doing interviews, videos, writing notes and sharing on social media important details to make this negotiations more understandable, Also, we will be advocating in Side Events for the relevance of education and awareness in the fight on climate change.
  • We need $8.000 usd to fund this actions in order to cover the accommodation, materials and transportation.
  • You will be able to follow us day to day in this activities and get a unique glimpse on the highest level of climate negotiations.
  • Also, by supporting us with your donation you will help Latin Americans have access to easy to understand and insightful information to motivate them to participate in climate change governance locally and internationally.  

Short Summary

Climate change conferences are the heart of decision-making. We aim to bring Latin America closer to this process. Our team is ready to participate in the United Nations Climate Change Conference COP23 to provide easy to understand and insightful information for Spanish speakers everywhere.

We are a volunteer based NGO: our team has lots of experience, having participated in the past 3 conferences with innovative media campaigns and events.  That is why La Ruta del Clima is soliciting donations to make it real this year for it´s project Climate Action - COP23.

Your donation will help us send a team of journalists and environmental professionals to this year's conference COP23, where we will work hard to report on advancements on the fight to stop climate change.

We will carry out interviews to important stakeholders, share information in social media, create videos,  participate in side events and specially, our team will dialogue with countries to promote education as a key action to face climate change.

 

    This is important

    In Latin America we are very vulnerable climate change but this is not our only worry, issues such as poverty, disasters and poor access to education are always in the agenda.

    This makes it harder for  climate change to be in the top agenda of politicians, NGOs and the public. La Ruta del Clima works hard to show the links between climate change and sustainable development. We know is important and want the public to help us. 

    Public participation is key to maintain this issue at the top agendas of government and the private sector. If citizens participate we can make make the right decisions and speed up the actions needed to secure a sustainable, adaptable and low carbon society.

    Climate Action  COP23 is a project to boost awareness and provide more information to Latin American public on Climate Change.  

      The Impact

      We will produce insightful and interesting awareness and education multimedia material for Latin Americans on climate change negotiations:

      • This is very important because few Latin American NGOs participate in this spaces and most news and information are not in spanish.
      • The spanish speaking public will have access to videos, notes, infographics and day to day social media content to follow the most important event in climate change governance.
      • The impact and results of these actions can be asses through our previous work:
        • Video interviews from international events.
        • Notes and articles for awareness and education.
        • Members and partnerships.
        • Participation in international conferences.
        • Side Event during COP22 and COP21.
        • Climate Change Radio program.
        • Webinars on climate change.
        • Organization of public participation activities.

      Global Context

      The Paris Agreement represents a turning point in global climate policy. In December 2015, nearly 200 nations signed the Paris Agreement to keep global temperature rise below 2℃.  This

      November in Germany, the Island Nation of Fiji will host the 23th Climate Change Conference to keep the process moving forward.  As President Michelle Bachelet of Chile remarked, “Paris is not the end of a climate change process but a beginning” and for Latin America this is essential. Climate change is a threat to our well being, specially in central america. Poverty, conflict and now climate change are some of the many challenges we face ahead.

      Education and innovation can helps us overcome this obstacles. We are working to create a more sustainable and resilient society.

      Risks & Challenges

      This project is a challenge for a small NGO from Latin America. Participation from our region in Climate Change Conferences is always small due to high cost and complicated access. However, this are the same challenges the Latin American public faces to know more about this issue. And, that is why we believe are work is important and as volunteers we know it can make a positive impact in our communities. 

      • We overcome this obstacle 3 times for the  past Climate Change Conferences.
      • This has made us experts in using small budget to make big actions.
      • To solve the high cost we volunteer for 2 weeks of non stop work, find the lowest cost accommodation and travel arrangements, look for partnerships, and try to generate the best material that we can. 
      • We know it matters and that it can be done together with your support.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      We want you to get involved.

      • Share with your friends our story.
      • Visit our website and please share our work in social media.
      • Let everyone know about the relevance of climate change and get involved in your community in this issue.

      Thank you a lot for your support!

      Spanish website: www.LaRutadelClima.org

      English website: www.Climate4Change.org
story_txt:
What We Need & What You Get
Climate Action is a project of advocacy and awareness.

We need resources to send 5 volunteers to the Climate Change Conference during 2 weeks.
The team will work 14 days continuously doing interviews, videos, writing notes and sharing on social media important details to make this negotiations more understandable, Also, we will be advocating in Side Events for the relevance of education and awareness in the fight on climate change.
We need $8.000 usd to fund this actions in order to cover the accommodation, materials and transportation.
You will be able to follow us day to day in this activities and get a unique glimpse on the highest level of climate negotiations.
Also, by supporting us with your donation you will help Latin Americans have access to easy to understand and insightful information to motivate them to participate in climate change governance locally and internationally.  


Short Summary
Climate change conferences are the heart of decision-making. We aim to bring Latin America closer to this process. Our team is ready to participate in the United Nations Climate Change Conference COP23 to provide easy to understand and insightful information for Spanish speakers everywhere.
We are a volunteer based NGO: our team has lots of experience, having participated in the past 3 conferences with innovative media campaigns and events.  That is why La Ruta del Clima is soliciting donations to make it real this year for it´s project Climate Action - COP23.
Your donation will help us send a team of journalists and environmental professionals to this year's conference COP23, where we will work hard to report on advancements on the fight to stop climate change.
We will carry out interviews to important stakeholders, share information in social media, create videos,  participate in side events and specially, our team will dialogue with countries to promote education as a key action to face climate change.
 


This is important
In Latin America we are very vulnerable climate change but this is not our only worry, issues such as poverty, disasters and poor access to education are always in the agenda.
This makes it harder for  climate change to be in the top agenda of politicians, NGOs and the public. La Ruta del Clima works hard to show the links between climate change and sustainable development. We know is important and want the public to help us. 
Public participation is key to maintain this issue at the top agendas of government and the private sector. If citizens participate we can make make the right decisions and speed up the actions needed to secure a sustainable, adaptable and low carbon society.
Climate Action  COP23 is a project to boost awareness and provide more information to Latin American public on Climate Change.  




The Impact
We will produce insightful and interesting awareness and education multimedia material for Latin Americans on climate change negotiations:

This is very important because few Latin American NGOs participate in this spaces and most news and information are not in spanish.
The spanish speaking public will have access to videos, notes, infographics and day to day social media content to follow the most important event in climate change governance.
The impact and results of these actions can be asses through our previous work:

Video interviews from international events.

Notes and articles for awareness and education.

Members and partnerships.

Participation in international conferences.

Side Event during COP22 and COP21.

Climate Change Radio program.
Webinars on climate change.
Organization of public participation activities.




Global Context
The Paris Agreement represents a turning point in global climate policy. In December 2015, nearly 200 nations signed the Paris Agreement to keep global temperature rise below 2℃.  This
November in Germany, the Island Nation of Fiji will host the 23th Climate Change Conference to keep the process moving forward.  As President Michelle Bachelet of Chile remarked, “Paris is not the end of a climate change process but a beginning” and for Latin America this is essential. Climate change is a threat to our well being, specially in central america. Poverty, conflict and now climate change are some of the many challenges we face ahead.
Education and innovation can helps us overcome this obstacles. We are working to create a more sustainable and resilient society.


Risks & Challenges
This project is a challenge for a small NGO from Latin America. Participation from our region in Climate Change Conferences is always small due to high cost and complicated access. However, this are the same challenges the Latin American public faces to know more about this issue. And, that is why we believe are work is important and as volunteers we know it can make a positive impact in our communities. 

We overcome this obstacle 3 times for the  past Climate Change Conferences.
This has made us experts in using small budget to make big actions.
To solve the high cost we volunteer for 2 weeks of non stop work, find the lowest cost accommodation and travel arrangements, look for partnerships, and try to generate the best material that we can. 
We know it matters and that it can be done together with your support.



Other Ways You Can Help
We want you to get involved.

Share with your friends our story.
Visit our website and please share our work in social media.
Let everyone know about the relevance of climate change and get involved in your community in this issue.

Thank you a lot for your support!Spanish website: www.LaRutadelClima.orgEnglish website: www.Climate4Change.org

story:
Expedition Angano: In Brief

  • An international biodiversity research expedition to Northern Madagascar.
  • Raising funds to buy fieldwork equipment for local students.
  • Aiming to leave a lasting legacy by helping students to gain experience.
  • Madagascar's wildlife is poorly known, we would love to build a story of optimism and hope with support from you!

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

The Full Story: Supporting Conservation In Madagascar

Madagascar has lost somewhere between 80-90% of it's rainforest. What remains supports thousands of species found nowhere else in the world; but it is under threat.

Ultimately, the only way to protect the forest for the future, is to build capacity within local communities and train the next generation of Malagasy students to be the conservationists of tomorrow - and this is what we aim to do.

In December 2015, we are leading an international expedition to Northern Madagascar to work with Malagasy scientists and students in the field, studying rare reptiles and amphibians.

We aim to develop new science, to understand and help preserve Madagascar's surviving forests.  With your support, we can give young Malagasy students skills and experience, to allow them to build a future in conservation.

We would love your support to help us reach our goal!


With your support, we can engage more students and supply them with better equipment.

We want to supply our local students with the following things:

  • A student bursary and materials to help them write up and publish their research dissertations and gain their degrees at university - the start of a bright conservation career!
  • Transport costs to get them from their home village to our research site.
  • A small daily stipend to support their work, this is stipulated by the government field research organisation.
  • Head torches and flashlights (most of our work will be at night!).
  • Tents and sleeping bags.
  • Extra science equipment such as calipers and scales (we use these to measure the animals).

Our existing funding means we can supply all of the food and expensive research equipment that we need, so anything pledged will go directly to the items above. In addition, these items will be donated at the end of the expedition to the local university, so that hopefully many other students can benefit too.


The good news is that we have enough funding to launch the expedition.

Fortunately, our research is already being supported several highly respected organisations: The Royal Geographical Society, the Scientific Exploration Society and the Zoological Society of London.

This not only means that a panel of scientists thinks that our research is very worthwhile, but also that many of the logistics, admin and permit costs have already been covered. Every international member of the team has also contributed £1000 of their own money to cover flights and costs, as well as their own equipment and time to help make this expedition a reality.

So the good news is that the expedition WILL take place! But we have an opportunity to reach more students, and that is why we need your help.


The Science

What is our research all about, here is an outline:

One of the problems of deforestation is that it doesn't just reduce the total area of surviving forest, it also drastically increases the proportion of forest edges (see photo below).

This is a problem, because edges are a very different habitat. Edges are hotter and drier (as the tree canopy provides less protection), there is also greater human disturbance, hunting, wind damage and more. All in all, edges are very different, but we don't know how that affects the species that live in the forest, and we don't know how 'deep' edge effects occur: a.k.a. how bad the effect is.

In a country where 90% of the forest is within 1 kilometer of an 'edge' then this is critically important research.

We aim to study these edges, in order to find out which species are resilient, and which are not. Species that can't survive on edges could be at far greater risk of extinction than we realise (and some may still be unknown to science!).

In a practical sense, with much conservation attention now focused on forest regeneration and habitat corridors, we hope to be able to assess the value of smaller fragments which have large proportions of edge habitat. Thus, we could prioritize those fragments which have the potential to support viable relict populations of rare species.


Our Team

Our team has a wealth of experience on expeditions around the world, so we're very hopeful for a successful expedition.

Expedition Leader: James Borrell (UK)

Deputy Leader: Marius Rakotondratsima (Madagascar)

Logistics Officer: Lawrence Ball

Science Officer: Mark Scherz

Scientist/Photographer: Duncan Parker

GIS and Data Specialist: Thom Starnes

Chief in-country Collaborators: Jeanneney Rabearivony & John Zaonarivelo

We're also benefiting from the experience and knowledge of several Malagasy conservationists who have incredible knowledge of the local wildlife and many contacts to help us overcome the inevitable hurdles of working in such a remote region.


If We Exceed Our Target

We really want to be successful - we want the whole process of conservation, education and expeditions in Madagascar to feel 'successful'.

So, hopefully we have aimed at an achievable target. We know that £2200 would make a huge difference, but if we exceeded our target then we would continue investing the money in training as many students as our camp could support.


Other Ways You Can Help

We totally understand that lots of people can't help us financially. We really appreciate you reading this far, so thank you!

One of the biggest reasons that conservation is such a struggle in Madagascar is simply that not enough people know about it's wonderful wildlife (some think it's just a film!).

If you could help us spread the word about what a wonderful country it is, and perhaps encourage people to follow our expedition online then that would be a fantastic help, thank you!

* * * * *

Footage originates from two extremely worthwhile projects in Madagascar: Association Mitsinjo, Reforestation and Feedback Madagascar, Wild Silk Project. These projects are not affiliated with Expedition Angano.

All rights from footage used in this video are under the "fair use" act...Music from Ben Sound and royalty free.

story:
*Click in configuración para subtítulos en español 
    *Click in settings for video subtitles

Click aquí para Español

                                Short Summary

 

Earthship Biotecture is teaming up with a local NGO, called Tagma, in Jaureguiberry, Uruguay, to build the FIRST SELF-SUSTAINABLE PUBLIC SCHOOL in all LATIN AMERICA the next february 2016... AND I WANT TO DOCUMENT IT!!  


                                            


My name is Ismael Romero, I'm an uruguayan citizen living in Colombia and I've been always passionate about green energies and recycling. I have an  Associate's Degree in the  solar energy field as designer and installer of photovoltaic and thermal  systems and a good general knowledge on other renewable energies.

The Earthships are the most self-sustainable buildings on earth today. They maximize the recycling by employing used tires, bottles, cans, plastic bottles and metal harvested parts from all kinds of appliances that are found in dumps and also produce their own food in a sustainable way and reuse water up to four times.

                                    

  

 The aim of this campaign is to raise funds to join the Earthship Academy to learn  the construction process. I will make a documentary that not only will show my learning days but will analyze what it entails in terms of social, environmental and educationally.

I will be interviewing the Tagma staff as well as the Earthship team, volunteers and students and bring all that experience and information back to Colombia to fund a NGO and recreate the project to build a new self-sustainable public school. 


 

              

                                      


                                  The Breakdown

                       Basically, these are the expenses that I need to cover:

  • $ 1500 - The price of the course
  • $ 800  - Flying tickets
  • $ 525   - Lodging
  • $ 282 - Some accessories needed to do the best job with my  Nikon D3200 which I break down here:                                                                                                        $   85 -  Shotgun microphone with Deadcat.                                                                   $  197 -  Wireless Lavalier microphone for interviews.
  • $  273 -  Campaign's fee and third parties fees.
With your help to start this path, I believe that great things can be achieved.     In the near future we could be building public libraries, recreational                and community centers, etc, and educate the people about living in a carbon zero way.

 Why I'm Doing This and Other Ways You Can Help



* Click en configuración para subtítulos en español

Quiero ser parte de la construcción de la primer escuela pública autosustentable de toda Latinoamérica

Español             Breve Resumen 

 

Earthship Biotecture se ha asociado con una ONG local llamada Tagma, en Jaureguiberry, Uruguay, para construir la PRIMERA ESCUELA PUBLICA AUTOSUSTENTABLE DE TODA LATINOAMERICA el próximo febrero 2016... Y YO QUIERO DOCUMENTARLO!!  


                                             


My nombre es Ismael Romero, soy un ciudadano uruguayo viviendo en Colombia y siempre he sido un apasionado de las energías verdes y el reciclaje. Tengo un título técnico en el campo de la energía solar como diseñador e instalador de sistemas fotovoltaicos y térmicos y un buen conocimiento general sobre otras energías renovables.

Los Earthships son las edificaciones más autosustentables sobre la tierra actualmente. Maximizan el reciclaje mediante el empleo de neumáticos usados, botellas, latas, botellas plásticas y partes métalicas recolectadas de todo tipo de aparatos encontrados en vertederos, además producen sus propios alimentos de una manera sustentable y resan el agua hasta cuatro veces.



 El objetivo de esta campaña es recaudar fondos para asistir a la Academia Earthship y así aprender el proceso de construcción. Realizaré un documental que no solo va a mostrar mis días de aprendizaje, sino que además va a analizar lo que implica en términos de desarrollo social, ambiental y educativo.

Estaré entrevistando al equipo de Tagma, así como al equipo de Earthship, a los voluntarios y a los estudiantes para llevar toda esa experiencia e información de vuelta a Colombia y fundar una ONG para recrear el proyecto de construcción de una nueva escuela auto sustentable. 



 

                                       


                                      El Desglose

   Básicamente estos son los costos que necesito cubrir              

  • USD 1500 - El costo del curso.
  • USD 800  - Pasajes de avión.
  • USD 525   - Alojamiento.
  • USD 282- Algunos accesorios que necesito para hacer un buen trabajo con mi  Nikon D3200 los cuales detallo aquí:                                                                                                        USD  85 -  Micrófono de condensador con filtro anti viento.                                        USD  197 -  Micrófono inalámbrico Lavalier para entrevistas. 
  • USD  273 -  Pago  de la campaña y terceras partes.  
Con tu ayuda paa comenzar este camino, creo que se pueden lograr grandes cosas. En un futuro próximo podríamos estar construyendo bibliotecas públicas, centros recreacionales y comunales y educar a la gente acerca de como vivir una vida con cero emisiones de carbono.


Porqué estoy haciendo esto y otras maneras de ayudar

story:
Current State of Waste Management In India

 

Composting offers an innovative way of managing this ever growing problem of waste management in Delhi

 

Who We Are?

We are a  professionally managed Company  dedicated to fighting urban pollution by creating circular economies. Our solution combines sustainable waste management practices for Indian cities with improving agricultural productivity through use of compost.

We have set up a compost plant in the Okhla area of Delhi as a pioneering project focusing on processing of municipal solid waste into Compost. We ensure that the Compost produced by the plant is of high quality, meeting the norms defined by the Government and is safe for agricultural use. The Compost rejuvenates the soil that has been depleted of micro-nutrients and soil carbon through overuse of chemical fertilizers. 

The plant was set up at a cost of ~US$5.6M and has a capacity to process 200 tons of Municipal Solid Waste per day. It costs US$0.6M annually to run the plant and provides jobs to ~40 full time employees who are mostly migrated rural labor dependent on part-time work or rag-picking.

The plant has the distinction of being the first municipal composting plant in the world to receive carbon credits.

 

So how does a Composting Plant work ?

PRE-SORTING

The process starts with pre-sorting where Municipal Solid Waste is fed into the hopper with the help of grab and passes through 100 mm trommel  to separate (+) 100 mm and (-) 100 mm fractions. Manual segregation of large inorganic material and recyclables is also done by helpers on the conveyors itself before going to trommel.

 

WINDROW COMPOSTING

(-) 100 mm fraction received at pre-sorting contains more than 70 % biodegradable waste. This material is mixed with microbial culture (in a ratio 1 ltr per MT of waste) and moisture of material is maintained to about 50% w/w after which windrow (a trapezoidal structure) is formed of dimension max. 3m base width, max. 2.5m height, max. 2.5m top width and length according to quantity of material.

Weekly turning of windrow is done to maintain the aerobic condition inside the heap. Regular monitoring of temperature and oxygen level is done to ensure optimal rate of decomposition. This process takes 28 days to complete.

 

COARSE SEGREGATION

Now this material is fed to the coarse segregation section which has two consecutive trammels having screen sizes of 35 mm and 16 mm respectively. (-) 16 mm material received is called semi-finished material and is further cured for 15 days to ensure complete decomposition and stabilization of material

 

FINE REFINEMENT

Semi-finished material is fed to the refinement section having screen size of 4 mm. During this process cured semi-finish material is first passed through 4 mm trammel. Then, (-) 4mm material is passed through a magnetic separator to ensure removal of any ferrous containing material, then through destoners and cyclone separators to ensure removal of stones, glass pieces, non-ferrous metals and silt. The final product/outcome is fine textured, blackish brown in color, earthy smelled and free flowing material and is called city compost.

The quality of finished material is tested in our own in-house laboratory and in third party laboratory as well on regular interval.

 

PACKING

The finished material is packed manually in different bag sizes depending on orders

 

FINAL PRODUCT

The packing is done in different sizes 1Kg, 2Kg, 5Kg, 10Kg and 50 Kg; Loose compost is also sold to the farmers or others.

 

Rewards & Recognition

We've been picking up some recognition along the way:

  • 1st Municipal Solid Waste compost plant in the world to be issued Carbon Credits                                                                                                                                                                          
  • 1st company in India to produce FCO compliant organic compost                                       
  • 1st company to get an Organic Certification for its compost                                                 
  • Featured in C40 Sustainable 'Cities 100' 2015 publication

 

Partners who have helped us in our Journey

             

What are people saying about us?                

I was impressed by seeing this solid waste management project. I think it can really help the country to solve this problem.

Digamber Kamat

Ex-Chief Minister of Goa, India

 

What Wonderful Work! What I have seen is an important plan to reach a real development of our countries. I hope that you will now allow Burkina Faso to get benefit and share your rich experience about your project

Nana Benjamin

Director of Africa, Asia, Middle East and Pacific department, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Burkina Faso

 

Congratulations – This is a great initiative & good project for environment protection

Ny Rado Rajalimanana

Oceanix international, Dubai, UAE

 

This is a first experience for me in my life. I am impressed by the business model  - your concern for the environment is appreciated

Kamwanga Masankisi Senior Advisor to prime minister, Democratic Republic of Congo

 

Why do we need help?

 

Where will your contribution go?

It takes $100 to process 7 tons of Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) which produces 1 ton of Compost 

 

 

Mitigating Green House Gases

Processing 7 tons of MSW helps mitigate 3.5 tons of Green House Gases (GHG); every ton of GHG mitigates earns us 1 carbon credit

 

 

Land Productivity 

It takes 4 tons of compost across 1 hectare of land to increase its productivity by upwards of 20%. Also with increase usage of compost helps reduce water consumption 

 

 

Saving Land Space

1 full hectare of land is saved by processing 75,000 tons of Municipal Solid Waste that would otherwise find it's way into a landfill

 

 

Employment Opportunities

We are able to generate employment opportunities for the lowest strata of society - Rag Pickers; 7,800 man hours of work gets generated to process 33,000 tons of Municipal Solid Waste

 

 

Avoid Leachate

For every 7 tons of Municipal Solid Waste processed, 0.35 tons of Leachate are avoided

 

 

Diseases Avoided

There are multiple waste related diseases like Dengue, Malaria, Asthama, Skin ailments that are avoided by processing it & turning it into compost
story_txt:
Current State of Waste Management In India Composting offers an innovative way of managing this ever growing problem of waste management in Delhi Who We Are?We are a  professionally managed Company  dedicated to fighting urban pollution by creating circular economies. Our solution combines sustainable waste management practices for Indian cities with improving agricultural productivity through use of compost.We have set up a compost plant in the Okhla area of Delhi as a pioneering project focusing on processing of municipal solid waste into Compost. We ensure that the Compost produced by the plant is of high quality, meeting the norms defined by the Government and is safe for agricultural use. The Compost rejuvenates the soil that has been depleted of micro-nutrients and soil carbon through overuse of chemical fertilizers. The plant was set up at a cost of ~US$5.6M and has a capacity to process 200 tons of Municipal Solid Waste per day. It costs US$0.6M annually to run the plant and provides jobs to ~40 full time employees who are mostly migrated rural labor dependent on part-time work or rag-picking.The plant has the distinction of being the first municipal composting plant in the world to receive carbon credits. So how does a Composting Plant work ?PRE-SORTINGThe process starts with pre-sorting where Municipal Solid Waste is fed into the hopper with the help of grab and passes through 100 mm trommel  to separate (+) 100 mm and (-) 100 mm fractions. Manual segregation of large inorganic material and recyclables is also done by helpers on the conveyors itself before going to trommel. WINDROW COMPOSTING(-) 100 mm fraction received at pre-sorting contains more than 70 % biodegradable waste. This material is mixed with microbial culture (in a ratio 1 ltr per MT of waste) and moisture of material is maintained to about 50% w/w after which windrow (a trapezoidal structure) is formed of dimension max. 3m base width, max. 2.5m height, max. 2.5m top width and length according to quantity of material.Weekly turning of windrow is done to maintain the aerobic condition inside the heap. Regular monitoring of temperature and oxygen level is done to ensure optimal rate of decomposition. This process takes 28 days to complete. COARSE SEGREGATIONNow this material is fed to the coarse segregation section which has two consecutive trammels having screen sizes of 35 mm and 16 mm respectively. (-) 16 mm material received is called semi-finished material and is further cured for 15 days to ensure complete decomposition and stabilization of material FINE REFINEMENTSemi-finished material is fed to the refinement section having screen size of 4 mm. During this process cured semi-finish material is first passed through 4 mm trammel. Then, (-) 4mm material is passed through a magnetic separator to ensure removal of any ferrous containing material, then through destoners and cyclone separators to ensure removal of stones, glass pieces, non-ferrous metals and silt. The final product/outcome is fine textured, blackish brown in color, earthy smelled and free flowing material and is called city compost.The quality of finished material is tested in our own in-house laboratory and in third party laboratory as well on regular interval. PACKINGThe finished material is packed manually in different bag sizes depending on orders FINAL PRODUCTThe packing is done in different sizes 1Kg, 2Kg, 5Kg, 10Kg and 50 Kg; Loose compost is also sold to the farmers or others. Rewards & RecognitionWe've been picking up some recognition along the way:
1st Municipal Solid Waste compost plant in the world to be issued Carbon Credits                                                                                                                                                                          
1st company in India to produce FCO compliant organic compost                                       
1st company to get an Organic Certification for its compost                                                 
Featured in C40 Sustainable 'Cities 100' 2015 publication
 Partners who have helped us in our Journey             What are people saying about us?                I was impressed by seeing this solid waste management project. I think it can really help the country to solve this problem.Digamber KamatEx-Chief Minister of Goa, India What Wonderful Work! What I have seen is an important plan to reach a real development of our countries. I hope that you will now allow Burkina Faso to get benefit and share your rich experience about your projectNana BenjaminDirector of Africa, Asia, Middle East and Pacific department, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Burkina Faso Congratulations – This is a great initiative & good project for environment protectionNy Rado RajalimananaOceanix international, Dubai, UAE This is a first experience for me in my life. I am impressed by the business model  - your concern for the environment is appreciatedKamwanga Masankisi Senior Advisor to prime minister, Democratic Republic of Congo Why do we need help? Where will your contribution go?It takes $100 to process 7 tons of Municipal Solid Waste (MSW) which produces 1 ton of Compost   Mitigating Green House GasesProcessing 7 tons of MSW helps mitigate 3.5 tons of Green House Gases (GHG); every ton of GHG mitigates earns us 1 carbon credit  Land Productivity It takes 4 tons of compost across 1 hectare of land to increase its productivity by upwards of 20%. Also with increase usage of compost helps reduce water consumption   Saving Land Space1 full hectare of land is saved by processing 75,000 tons of Municipal Solid Waste that would otherwise find it's way into a landfill  Employment OpportunitiesWe are able to generate employment opportunities for the lowest strata of society - Rag Pickers; 7,800 man hours of work gets generated to process 33,000 tons of Municipal Solid Waste  Avoid LeachateFor every 7 tons of Municipal Solid Waste processed, 0.35 tons of Leachate are avoided  Diseases AvoidedThere are multiple waste related diseases like Dengue, Malaria, Asthama, Skin ailments that are avoided by processing it & turning it into compost

story:
UPDATE: We did it! 

Thank you to each and every one of you for helping us exceed the $12,500 necessary for our matching grant from Brown University. We can't wait to put each dollar to good use this summer. Keep in touch!

This is an Embark Fellowship campaign. If we raise $12,500, Brown University will donate $25,000 to our project!

What's up with fish? 

The world’s population is growing rapidly, and the global demand for animal protein—from fish to poultry, beef, and pork— is growing with it. But there’s a problem: animal feeds are made from wild-caught fish like anchovies and sardines. These fish are caught using highly destructive fishing methods that result in unintentional by-catch and the destruction of coral reefs. One third of global fish catch doesn't go towards direct human consumption; it goes to feeding animals. As a result, more than 85% of the world’s fisheries are exploited. We are feeding fish to other animals, and it doesn’t make sense.

Meanwhile, the world's population is increasing rapidly and is projected to hit 9.7 billion by 2050. We desperately need a new way to feed a growing population that is not at odds with the health of our oceans. 

Meet the black soldier fly.

The black soldier fly is a friendly non-buzzing, non-biting fly native to tropical and temperate regions of the world. As larvae, it feeds ravenously on organic waste—everything from spent grains from breweries to fruit and veggie peels. We divert this organic waste as our input and the black soldier fly larvae metabolize it to become our nutrient-rich output. This insect protein is then sold to chicken and fish farmers as a great protein base for their animals. 

 

What We Do

We partner with food and beverage companies—like breweries, restaurants, and fruit & vegetable processors—and implement an automated, retrofitted shipping container we like to call The Refinery. We’re working with some of the world’s leading experts in black soldier flies to develop an algorithm that automates the entire process. Our sensors measure data in realtime and the algorithm maximizes efficiency. Meanwhile, a community of microbes pre-treats the waste, breaking down fibrous content into more digestible compounds so we can work with a wide range of organic waste streams. 

What does The Refinery look like? 

 

About Us 

Viraj Sikand and Maya Faulstich-Hon are seniors at Brown University studying Environmental Studies, and Eric Katz is a senior studying Business at the University of Michigan. They share a drive to create more sustainable food systems and a passion for black soldier flies. Here they are with the first Kulisha bug-growing greenhouse: 

 

Where We've Come From & Where We're Going  

Our name means “to feed” in Swahili. We trace our roots to Kenya, where Kulisha was first born as a response to destructive fishing practices by commercial vessels. In the year and a half since we started, we've: 

  • Built two fully-functional prototype facilities for research & development 
  • Partnered with leading experts in black soldier flies, industrial design, computer science, and microbiology
  • Raised $210,000 of non-dilutive financing

We're relocating to Austin, Texas in the fall of 2017 to partner with a brewery and build our first commercial pilot facility! To make this possible, we need to raise $250,000 by January 2018. We've already raised $210,000 through various grants, competitions, and fellowships, and we need your help for the last $40,000.

These funds will go towards:

  • Materials for the shipping container (sprinkler system, sensors, bins, shelving, etc.)
  • Post-processing equipment like sifters, dryers, and packagers
  • Distribution of our product to consumers and feed millers

Our Vision

Through our operations, we will:

  • Divert waste from landfills, thereby reducing greenhouse gas emissions and conserving land
  • Reduce pressure off ocean ecosystems by providing an alternative to fishmeal
  • Provide an innovative use for a byproduct that is currently underused

Our technology has the potential to revolutionize the way the world uses waste and perceives food, and we are determined to do it—one black soldier fly at a time.

As is the nature of any startup, we recognize that launching a company takes sustained time and effort. For those who wish to have a more immediate impact on food security, Kenya is currently facing one of the worst famines in recent history. More information can be found at Red Cross Kenya.

Kulisha was selected by the Social Innovation Initiative at Brown University for the Embark Post-Graduate Fellowship, which supports graduating seniors continue pursuing their entrepreneurial goals, helps their ventures gain traction, and builds a connected alumni community. 

Huge thanks to the Brown University Plant Conservatory, the Brown University Swearer Center, the Nelson Center for Entrepreneurship, the University of Michigan Center for Entrepreneurship, the Zell Lurie Institute, Dow Distinguished Awards, and the Planet Blue Student Innovation Fund for their ongoing support.

And thanks to the talented Jimmy Xia and Lynn Tachihara for producing the video, Elli Sawada for the designs, and Abbey Perreault for the song!

story:
Esta es una campaña de unos 6 - 8 meses para crear conciencia sobre la contaminación plástica por toda Latinoamérica. Para esto vamos a preparar generadores de cambio quienes van a guiar a las personas en su comunidad para reducir la cantidad de plástico que llega y afecta el medio ambiente. 

Esta campaña que comenzó a mediados de marzo en Baja California, México, está enfocada en crear cambio a través de talleres de medio día. Con éstos se logra que las personas entiendan el impacto causado por la basura plástica tanto en el ambiente como en nuestra salud y que se lleven herramientas –como charlas e ideas de posibles campañas que pueden liderar- para ellos sean el motor de cambio en sus comunidades. El taller también trata de incentivar el amor a la naturaleza y desde ahí la necesidad de respetar y cuidarla. 

WorldCleanup plantó la semilla para lograr la prohibición de las bolsas plásticas en Panamá. 

La efectividad de la Campaña de Worldcleanup fue comprobada con la prohibición de la bolsa plástica en Panamá. 

En abril 2017, Martina de Marcos entrenó a través de Skype a jóvenes universitarios quienes dieron una charla/plática informativa a 150 personas, uno de ellos, un legislador de Panamá Samir Gozaine. 

El Sr. Gozaine quedó tan consternado con la charla/plática que presentó la propuesta de ley para prohibir la bolsa plástica en mayo 2017. Su ley fue aprobada y firmada por el presidente de la República en enero de este año.

Si pudimos juntos lograr eso con unos pocos líderes comunitarios, imagínense lo que podemos hacer con unos cuantos cientos y dispersos por toda Latinoamérica. 

Sobre Martina de Marcos

Con mucha experiencia y sucesos en lograr campañas de concientización ambiental, como el ejemplo de Panamá, la fundadora de WorldCleanup, Martina de Marcos, está a la cabeza de esta campaña. 

Creció en Argentina, se mudó a Australia en el año 2010 donde estudió Ciencias Marinas en la Universidad de Sydney, Australia. Actualmente escribe su tesis para su maestría en Gestión Ambiental con una investigación específica en la gestión de la basura plástica en lugares remotos costeros. 

Durante el 2016 trabajó como pasante y consultora para ONU Medio Ambiente donde lideró campañas de concientización sobre la basura marina, en especial el plástico, y ahí es donde la idea de WorldCleanup nació. 

Líderes comunitarios

Los líderes comunitarios van a ser entrenados y certificados por WorldCleanup. Ellos van a poder crear cambio en sus comunidades y van a ser parte de la comunidad Worldcleanup donde podrán compartir sus iniciativas, consultar dudas y motivarse. 

El problema

El problema con el plástico es un problema real y comprobado por cientos de artículos científicos. 8 millones de toneladas son desechadas o llegan al océano cada año, equivalente a 1 camnión lleno de basura por minuto, degradando ecosistemas, entrando en la cadena alimenticia, creando polución visual y problemas de salud. 

Hay una tendencia creciente alrededor del mundo para reducir el consumo del plástico de un solo uso, mejorar los materiales que están siendo utilizados para facilitar una economía circular, incrementar y mejorar el reciclado (que es casi nulo), limpiar el océano y prevenir la polución plástica. 

Pero, en Latinoamérica, este tipo de campañas, aunque cada vez haya más, es bastante limitado. Esto quiere decir que nuestra comunidad en general desconoce los problemas que trae la basura plástica al medio ambiente y nuestra salud en general. 

Desafortunadamente, es común ver ciudades sin programas gubernamentales de reciclado y zonas donde la recolección por parte del gobierno es inexistente, dejando a las casas y comercios como únicas responsables de la gestión de la basura. 

Como resultado, las personas dejan basura tirada en el medio ambiente como bosques, plazas y playas, y en sus comunidades en general, sin entender el problema que estamos causando. 

Esta falta de conocimiento y entendimiento es lo que WorldCleanup quiere cambiar. 

Los fondos recaudados

Los fondos serán destinados a cubrir los costos de transporte, alojamientos y demás que incurre la campaña. 

Muchas gracias! 

Martina de Marcos Holmberg.
