story:
About Casa de Mouraz

For nearly 20 years, Sara Dionisio and Antonio Ribeiro have pioneered Organic and Biodynamic viticulture in Portugal's Dão Region, taking their award-winning Casa de Mouraz label and ALR wines to many of Europe's top restaurants like MOMA, and also further afield to some of world's best wine shops.  Following critical acclaim from the likes of Julia Harding (Jancisrobinson.com), Sarah Ahmed, and Jamie Goode, Casa de Mouraz wines have regularly been featured in the top 50 Portuguese wines, both in the the UK and beyond.

15th October 2017 Fires in Portugal.

Unfortunately, like many others in the region, Sara and Antonio weren't able to escape the devastating impact of these latest fires.  Many of their vineyards, equipment and stock was consumed in the 15th October fire that raged across the Viseu and Tondela region. This has been a difficult time involving considerable loss and difficult consequences. However, we hope that with your help - together with Sara and Antonio's boundless energy and resilience – we'll be able to turn things around, and make the next 20 years of Casa de Mouraz an even greater success.

The 2017 Vintage.

With their modest yet efficient cellar left intact, and this year’s harvest saved from the fire, Sara and António, along with their devoted team of long standing collaborators and employees are ready to make this year’s harvest an outstanding success and start laying the foundations for the next 20 years to come - But they need all the help they can receive to make this work more efficient, to rebuild and replant the vineyards that have been badly damaged by the fires, and to recover financially from the loss of a very significant part of their stock and vineyard.

With future winemaking guaranteed from their current vintage Sara and Antonio are already rebuilding their business and moving forward with the vineyards that have escaped the fires, and you can help massively by simply buying their wine!

Casa de Mouraz 2.0 - Main goals:

  • 1 - Replant 6 Hectares of vineyards.
  • 2 - Replace destroyed farming equipment.
  • 3 - Rebuild warehouse and new cellar.

Amazing (and really tasty) Project Rewards.

Contribute now, exchange your reward vouchers in 2022.

We are extremely thankful for any donations you might want to make to this project, but we want to share with you the pleasure of making our wines, and we created a great set of wine voucher rewards! By funding this project we will be rewarding with our unique vouchers that you can exchange in our online store in 2022. Along with the wine vouchers special contributions will receive an unique set of treats and perks.

1 - Vineyard Replanting

Replanting 6 Hectares of  the "Monte da Sra. Esperança" Vinyeard in Mouraz

We will be planting a total of 6 hectares in the Monte da Sra. da. Esperança Vineyard (Esperança means hope in Portuguese) with a diverse set of native Portuguese indigenous varieties :

  • 1 ha of Touriga Nacional
  • 1 ha of Jaen
  • 1 ha of Alfrocheiro
  • 3ha of Mixed traditional varieties (traditional Field Blend)

The planting will be carried out along with our usual approach to biodiversity by planting  indigenous fruit trees, such as Laranja de Besteiros ( Orange tree), Fig trees, and apple orchards along with the vines.

Amount to raise for replanting: 30.000€

Total investment will be 150.000 Euros, of which we aim to raise a partial amount of 20% (30.000€)

2 - Replacing Farming equipment.

Many critical farming machinery was destroyed by the fire, and need immediate replacement,

  1. Inter Vine Trimmer
  2. Mulcher
  3. Atomizer for Biodynamic Preparations
  4. Sprinkler

Amount to raise for new equipment: 10.000€

Total investment will be 20.000 Euros, of which we aim to raise a partial amount of 50% (10.000€)

3 - New Cellar & Warehouse

The new Mouraz cellar is a vital piece for the growth and sustainability of the project. A full gravity  driven eco cellar, with all the necessary facilities for storage and vinification, as well as exploring new techniques and experiments in wine making. Along with the wine making facilities, the cellar will incorporate hospitality functions, to welcome wine tourism and business development as well promoting artistic residencies.

Amount to raise for New cellar + Warehouse: 60.000€

Total investment will be 600.000 Euros, of which we aim to raise a partial amount of 10% (60.000€)

FREQUENTLY ASKED QUESTIONS:

I’d like to contribute a different amount. What should I do?

On the platform you can make a donation (not associated with a perk and you choose the amount you want to give) or you can select a perk on the list. You may also contact us by email and we will be very pleased to give you all the help you need. Please email us: casademouraz@sapo.pt

I'd like to support CASA de MOURAZ, but I don't want my name to be made public. What should I do?

When you check out, you'll be asked how you want your contribution to be shown. You can choose Anonymous, and we won't list you.

When can I expect my reward?

We are running this campaign to plant one part of the vines affected by the fire, to buy the destroyed machinery and build a new warehouse and winery. We need a couple of years to recover and produce the full range of CASA de MOURAZ wines (and some new ones!).  You will get your reward in a maximum period of 5 years. It might be even earlier…

How will I receive my reward?

As soon as we can send it to you, we will post it to your address. All the people who helped us will be contacted by CASA de MOURAZ team to arrange all the details for the delivery. You can also suggest us the best way for that! Thanks again!

I'd like to back this campaign, but I want to give the perk as a gift. Can I have my reward shipped to someone else's address?

Yes! At checkout, you'll be asked for the shipping address. It's easy to have it sent to someone else: just enter the details you'd like. You can also contact us by email: casademouraz@sapo.pt

I chose a voucher as my perk. What should I do?

Our vouchers can be used towards a purchase from our website or directly to us. Soon we will include a shop in our website. We are working on it now, we believe it will be available in mid2018. We will send you an email with all the information later.

How long is my voucher valid?

The vouchers purchased under this campaign are valid until the end of 2022.

Can I visit CASA de MOURAZ?

Yes, we will be very pleased with your visit. The only request it’s to contact us to book the visit. To book you can also use our email: casademouraz@sapo.pt 

Did we answer your question?

If not, please email casademouraz@sapo.pt. We’ll get onto it straight away!
story_txt:
About Casa de MourazFor nearly 20 years, Sara Dionisio and Antonio Ribeiro have pioneered Organic and Biodynamic viticulture in Portugal's Dão Region, taking their award-winning Casa de Mouraz label and ALR wines to many of Europe's top restaurants like MOMA, and also further afield to some of world's best wine shops.  Following critical acclaim from the likes of Julia Harding (Jancisrobinson.com), Sarah Ahmed, and Jamie Goode, Casa de Mouraz wines have regularly been featured in the top 50 Portuguese wines, both in the the UK and beyond.15th October 2017 Fires in Portugal.Unfortunately, like many others in the region, Sara and Antonio weren't able to escape the devastating impact of these latest fires.  Many of their vineyards, equipment and stock was consumed in the 15th October fire that raged across the Viseu and Tondela region. This has been a difficult time involving considerable loss and difficult consequences. However, we hope that with your help - together with Sara and Antonio's boundless energy and resilience – we'll be able to turn things around, and make the next 20 years of Casa de Mouraz an even greater success.The 2017 Vintage.With their modest yet efficient cellar left intact, and this year’s harvest saved from the fire, Sara and António, along with their devoted team of long standing collaborators and employees are ready to make this year’s harvest an outstanding success and start laying the foundations for the next 20 years to come - But they need all the help they can receive to make this work more efficient, to rebuild and replant the vineyards that have been badly damaged by the fires, and to recover financially from the loss of a very significant part of their stock and vineyard.With future winemaking guaranteed from their current vintage Sara and Antonio are already rebuilding their business and moving forward with the vineyards that have escaped the fires, and you can help massively by simply buying their wine!Casa de Mouraz 2.0 - Main goals:
1 - Replant 6 Hectares of vineyards.
2 - Replace destroyed farming equipment.
3 - Rebuild warehouse and new cellar.

story:
Our Path to Success:

I believe that making art, by innovative training and creating unique artistic products, is a vector for sustainable development and for women’s empowerment, all while raising awareness of the socio-economic challenges to environmental conservation and notions of citizenship. As Moroccan female artist, I have dedicated my life to seek ways to improve the lives of others in my society through art, with a special focus on women and environment.

Through my life, I have learned the important lesson: when women are empowered, it has a direct positive impact on their families, and communities prosper.

 

This simple belief led me in 2013 to launch Au Grain de Sésame training workshop, the art and ecological design training program, to empower marginalized women through ecological art training.

Since 2013, more than 100 women have benefited from our training program with a real impact on improving their living conditions and that of their families and communities.

What your contribution will help us to achieve:

Over the past few years we have seen the positive impact that the training program has had on not just the local women but in the communities as a whole – and we want to do more! The future of the training program depends on support from our friends and customers.

We are launching this brand new innovative line of paper leather products, whose proceeds will contribute to ensuring the sustainability of the program and help us train even more women in the year to come.

Made from recycled paper and natural dyes, the handmade paper leather looks and feels like traditional animal leather but is much lighter, incredibly versatile, durable, and can be easily cleaned with watter.

Your support will contribute to help five Moroccan female artisans trained at Au Grain de Sésame to launch their own artisanal cooperative, ensure their own financial autonomy and train twenty five other women to the paper leather products making.

For every item purchased, 10% will be given to the women artisans and will go towards securing a space and launching their own cooperative.

The remaining proceeds will go towards registering the paper leather process with the national Moroccan patent office, the production of the first paper leather collection, and purchasing new equipment for the training workshops.

What we need and your thanks gift:

We need $15,000 to achieve our goal of launching the paper leather collection and help the Moroccan female artisans open their own cooperative.

Percentage breakdown:

  • OMPIC registration: 7.0 %
  • 3 month local rent for the women cooperative and cost for its creation: 10 %
  • Cost for 3 professionals sewing machines : 12.7 %
  • Supplies and tools cost : 7.3 %
  • 2 months cost for the Au Grain de Sésame workshop production : 63.0 %.

For helping out this campaign, you can choose from an assortment of goodies based on your level of funding, including the following:

  • A personalized e-Thank you card
  • A Souvenir of Hope
  • A Touch of Morocco
  • A sunshineTouch of Morocco
  • A creative Touch of Morocco
  • A paper leather Moroccan Quilt
  • An Invitation to be part of our Rabat Cultural Exchange Program for one week

In case we don’t reach the entire amount needed, we will first found the women cooperative launch and in the second step the OMPIC registration.

In case we raise more than the entire amount needed we will found the ecommerce website to access the international market.

Our Project Impact:

Climate change, poverty, access to knowledgel, gender equality, well-being: are the major problems and challenges of our time.

We all want to bring our seed and contribute to the most effectives solutions.

And Empowerment through Art Education is one of them!

 

Our most successful Projects :

For our training program with the vision “Empowering Women through Art” we have been :

-2013 SEED Award, a United Nations Initiative for the Environment,

-  2014-15, laureate of the American Alliance of Museum for a Cultural Exchange Program supported by the States Department Washington DC, That involves 20 US and Moroccan women and also 16 US and Moroccan Students,

- And in 2016-17, Au Grain de Sésame collaborated to the UNIDO (United Nations Industrial Development Organization) REVIS Project, a one year training project that aims to empower 25 Moroccan artisans from the north Est region in Morocco, until the access to the market.  

Make it happen:

When you empower women through art education, they transmit what they learn to their children, families and communities. 

It also develops their creativity and their respect for the environment and the human values. And of course increase their incomes which they spend on food, child education and health.

Many of our women have said to us “You’ve changed my life!”

At Au Grain de Sésame we believe that empowering women is creating a powerful multiplier effect that benefits all of the society.

And when a women move forward, the world change with them!

Everyone can contribute to changing lives through sustainable development and helps women fulfill their economic potential and drive economic and social change in their communities.

By supporting us you contribute to making this happen!

Anything you can give is valuable to us!

  • Spread the word about the campaign
  • Connect us with like-minded institutional partners and people interested in the work that we do
  • Do not hesitate to use all the sharing options on Indiegogo to help spread our message of hope!

Shukran, Thank you, Merci Beaucoup !

story:
About the Campaign 

I am 15 years old and I am the executive director of Universal Wildlands. I am launching this campaign because, in late summer 2018, the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change released a report outlining the necessary actions that must be taken to mitigate and even reversed climate change. The report urges immediate action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and sequester carbon. One vital step in this process is reforesting an area the size of Canada and restoring tree farms to their natural state of high carbon storage and biological diversity.

You can take action today to restore and preserve forest lands in a region with one of the highest carbon storage potentials in the world. The Western Cascades of Washington State offers a chance to build a climate-resilient ecosystem at a time when much of the world’s forests are threatened by inevitable Global Warming. With our inaugural conservation project, we are laying the foundations for the return of wilderness to the Skagit River basin and greater Cascadia.

Every $850 we raise will aid us in the protection and restoration of one acre of land on Lookout Mountain, where we are working to create a 160-acre conservancy. This conservancy will restore important habitat for the Northern Spotted Owl and other endangered species. Its south-facing slope will encourage lichen growth and in turn, attract deer and other ungulates and their predators to the area. The Lookout Mountain property is also home to cliff habitat and a small patch of old-growth forests above a mountain gorge.

As a Founding Sponsor, you will be planting the seed of Universal Wildlands. The Lookout Mountain Conservation Project is our first campaign, and if successful will build a track record and the credibility needed for us to approach our first corporate and philanthropic sponsors. It will open the door to more ambitious conservation projects targeting large tracts of land including those with irreplaceable ecological value.

Help us change the future of this mountain and others throughout the Cascades from patchworks of clear cuts to towering forests stretching from the Fraser River Valley to the Columbia River Gorge.

We Need You

In order to restore Lookout Mountain, we need your help. We are raising $136,000 to purchase and protect Lookout Mountain and to fund its restoration. By sponsoring this project, you will aid us in the protection and restoration of one acre of land for every $850 you invest, sequestering carbon, adding to biodiversity and creating a natural cathedral where otherwise there would be clear cuts. Please contribute whatever you can; if it is in your means please consider protecting 10 or even 20 acres. Don't consider this a gift, consider it an investment in our future and an investment in life. Please give what you can, and if you can't give, please share this campaign on social media. 

Your Impact

By sponsoring an acre you will directly add to the amount of protected wilderness in the world. Your sponsorship will help us restore a mountain forest to health, making it more resilient to climate change and creating an ecosystem that can act as an ark of biodiversity for thousands of years.

Carbon Sequestration

By protecting the temperate rainforest on Lookout mountain you will make possible the sequestration and storage of an estimated 250 metric tons of carbon dioxide per acre. Large-scale carbon storage of this type is critical to maintaining a healthy biosphere; every year we pump 30-40 billion tons of CO2 into the atmosphere. The goal is no longer simply to curtail emissions, we must act to pull excess carbon dioxide out of the atmosphere or we will face dire consequences. By sponsoring the restoration of Lookout Mountain you will become part of the change we need if we are to have any hope of maintaining life as we know it on our beautiful blue-green earth.

Preserving Biodiversity

Over the past centuries, we have seen an unprecedented collapse of biodiversity all around the world. As we have cleared the planet of native ecosystems we have lost keystone species and innumerable flora and fauna. We are offering you a chance to help reverse this trend. Old-growth forests of Cascadia are among the most biologically diverse ecosystems in the world. Once restored, the slopes of Lookout Mountain would support endangered species such as the Northern Spotted Owl. It would also develop the complex canopy only found in old growth forests, and become home to myriad insects, mosses, lichens, and birds. As climate change stresses many forest ecosystems around the world, the Pacific Northwest offers us a chance to promote biodiversity in one of the most climate-resilient eco-regions on Earth. Let us seize this chance and restore the forests of the Pacific Northwest.

A Forest Where There Once was Devastation

Setting aside the importance of carbon sequestration and biodiversity, your contribution will also directly allow a previously logged second-generation forest to return to its natural state of grandeur. For every acre of land you protect, you will be preserving hundreds of trees that are home to dozens of small mammals and birds, as well as hundreds of thousands of individual organisms, from the Liquorice Ferns that grow on trees, to the brambles on the forest floor to the hundreds of insect species that live in every niche of this ecosystem. Simply put, you will create a legacy of vibrancy and life where there once was devastation.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't in a position to contribute financially, you can still help us get the word out by sharing this campaign on social media and by encouraging others to support us. You can follow our activities on universalwildlands.com/news and use our Amazon Affiliate Link to support the campaign. You can also contact us to get involved with our organization.

story:
My name is Gustavo Castro and I am a biologist working as scientific director at Ave Sol River Sanctuary. I have been studying jaguars for some years now and currently I am working in this region for my MSc thesis project, under the supervision of the International Institute for Wildlife Conservation and Management at the Costa Rican National University.

Working in this region for the last seven years has brought me close to its great ecological importance and its incredible biodiversity. It has also brought me close to its people and the needs and problems they face everyday. I realize that there is much to do to help safeguard the future of the region's natural ecosystems and its people, and for this reason, we ask for your help in exchange of any of our unique and exciting perks.

Who We Are

Ave Sol River Sanctuary is a very secluded mountain/river lodge and natural reserve located in the Pacuare River, within the Talamanca Mountain Range, home of the country’s largest forested area. Ave Sol was first acquired and built ten years ago by my best friend, Álvaro Farías (aka Natu). Natu and I grew up together in the most biodiverse country (per square meter) in the world, Costa Rica. We both grew very close with nature, which soon became our greatest interest. I became a biologist and he became a professional naturalist and river guide. As a river guide, Natu fell in love with the Pacuare River and its exuberant tropical rainforests. He felt the need to give something back to the River and this is how, with very little resources, he managed to buy this land to preserve its wildlife and forests for the benefit of all future generations. I believe Natu is a true dreamer, the visionary and hands-on dream kind. I also believe that every major achievement starts as somebody’s dream.

He wanted to share the feeling of closeness with nature this place inspires with everybody. He believes that the more people come to know and love the Pacuare River and its forests, the more strength we gain to care for it, allowing it to flow powerful and free. This is how Ave Sol was raised in the year 2007, with the goal of protecting these invaluable ecosystems and supporting conservation efforts within this unique River basin. A River basin that serves as a very important life corridor that extends from the foothills of Costa Rica’s highest peaks (>12000 ft.) all the way to the Caribbean Sea. As it turns out, the Pacuare is among the last free-flowing, healthy, and mostly clean rivers that remain in the tropics. Maintaining its ecosystems and keeping the River flowing free and clean represents the future of countless wildlife species in this region.

We want to seize the great opportunity to help mitigate some critical environmental issues affecting a region with such ecological importance. A region that is constantly been threatened by particular interests such as the damming of the Pacuare and heavy poaching. For this journey, we have set up a team of professionals in biology, management of natural resources, veterinary, health and wellness, and tourism.

Why We Need Your Help

Tropical rainforests are among the richest and most productive ecosystems in the world, and this region of Costa Rica in particular bears great ecological importance. The region is distinguished for its high level of endemism (unique species to one geographic area) while representing the largest area with forest cover in the country. It is also the richest region in bird and mammal species of Costa Rica, including many that are endangered.

From jaguars up in its mountains, to leatherback turtles nesting in beaches close to its mouth, they all depend on the habitat connectivity that the ever-flowing Pacuare River and its forests provide. These endangered marine turtles actually use the Pacuare River mouth as a major landmark to find their nesting sites. The deep and profound relation that both jaguars and leatherback turtles keep with this River are just two examples of how profoundly entangled and fragile these complex ecosystems are. We are just beginning to understand this kind of relations, and there is so much more to do and learn.

As important and rich this ecoregion is, it is also one with the least technical and scientific information. Generation of ecological information becomes a huge priority for the conservation of these unique and important ecosystems. Only if we know and understand it, can we manage it effectively.

The Talamanca Mountains also hold, among other wonders, presumably the largest jaguar population in the country. The jaguar (Panthera onca) is our flag, not only for how passionate we feel towards the species and all its symbolic nature, but also for what it represents in the region and the immeasurable importance concerning its conservation. The jaguar is the largest cat in the Americas, it has an enormous cultural value, and among the thousands of threatened species of plants and animals in Costa Rica, the jaguar is without doubt one of the most charismatic, surprising, and majestic. Today, even after so many years, the jaguar retains many of its ancient symbolic meanings and has become gradually, and according to many scientists, an indicator of forest richness and health, which highlights its importance over other species and its role in the balance of entire ecosystems.

The Talamanca jaguar has been an important element in ancient culture cosmology and in the life of rural communities in the region, with which it has coexisted for centuries; however, in recent decades this friendly relationship has changed. This region, as many others around the globe, is experiencing a critical situation in terms of natural resource management. Every day, jaguars, and all wildlife, face major threats: from habitat destruction and poaching, to road collisions, pollution, lack of environmental policies or its enforcement and low education – it is a long and sad list of threats. The Pacuare River itself faces major threats, as particular economic groups are interested in damming the River for the generation of electricity and are well advanced in their intentions. In addition, jaguars are very elusive animals and are among the least studied felids in the world. Even the most basic information such as their reproduction and habitat preference remain to be completely understood. The lack of basic scientific research and species/ecosystem management techniques are serious constraints to address jaguar conservation.

Fortunately, there are many who share our vision. There are a number of individual groups and organizations working tirelessly to protect jaguars through research and/or education programs, but many of these efforts are coming from groups and organizations outside this region - just imagine what we could accomplish if we were all to pool our ideas, resources, and expertise and work together from within our region for the greater benefit of jaguars.

For these reasons, we are endeavoring to create the Talamanca Jaguar Station (TAJA Station) – a conservation initiative that will serve as an instrument to address all these issues from within this very important ecoregion. We will bring together all people, partners, and institutions working regionally with jaguars to achieve lasting conservation solutions. We want to lead conservation efforts towards filling gaps in forest protection, as well as gaps in research and information, education, habitat restoration, and training while fostering new alternatives and opportunities for economic development in the Pacuare river basin. We have the jaguar as our guide and emblem on this endeavor. Our work will aim at opening new perspectives in research, looking for viable alternatives to address this region’s environmental and socioeconomic needs in the short term. Also, to seize the opportunity to positively influence public economic and social development policies as well as legislative frameworks of models that privilege biodiversity conservation that will result in the permanence of the most charismatic of our tropical forest species, the jaguar.

The aim of the TAJA Station will not be to rescue jaguars, but rather to prevent them from needing rescue in the first place. While other groups will perform the necessary triage, we will work on curing the root cause of the problems.

Building on the success of this project, TAJA Station will seek to be a connected and capable facilitator for scientific research, bringing scientists together to gain an understanding of the fundamental processes that govern tropical ecosystems and corridor ecology through basic and applied research. We want to provide physical facilities (accommodation, major instrumentation, and study and conference rooms) and services (logistical support) that enable scientists to operate effectively in our region. We also have a more specific interest in fostering socially impactful projects and studies -in addition to science purely for conservation.

The first step to help jaguars is protecting all remaining natural ecosystems and working to maintain and increase functional connectivity between them. This is the cornerstone of modern conservation efforts. Ave Sol is located within what has been part of the historical and geological connection between what are now two major Biosphere Reserves (declared by UNESCO) – the Central Volcanic and La Amistad Biosphere Reserves, which in time are priority areas for jaguar conservation in America. This region/connection is recognized as the Barbilla Biological Corridor. Being located in this region gives us the great opportunity, and at the same time the obligation, of facilitating gene flow between not only jaguar populations, but also of countless wildlife species.

It is easy to say, but this is a very complex field requiring strong cooperation with many different groups from tour operators and other business, universities and other educational institutions, to government agencies, NGO's, and local rural and Indigenous communities. Committing to conservation requires working closely with the people on all stages. Fostering this level of cooperation is our ambitious long-term goal.

We believe in environmental education as one of the best tools to create a cultural shift towards environmental sustainability. We currently pursue this through our educational field trip program where our guests become field researchers for the day. We acknowledge that our education program is a small step towards a major goal, and we are poised and ready to expand this program as our resources and network grow. There are some important challenges our communities face on a local level to balance economic growth with long-term sustainability. Targeted education projects will play an important part in moving forward. We are very thankful to you, who empower us to pursue these programs with your patronage.

The key missions of the Talamanca Jaguar Station will be:

• To generate holistic forms of environmentally sustainable tourism by involving science, environmental education, and tourism with the cultural context of the region.

• To promote the protection of the natural ecosystems of the region, as well as innovative participatory mechanisms for the protection of forests.

• To fund and coordinate high quality research into the biology, ecology, genetics, evolution and physiology of jaguars; same as to provide the tools to generate scientific-technical information relevant to the conservation of all biodiversity and the socioeconomic well-being of people within the region.

• To tackle the issues that jaguars are facing in the wild by developing and implementing conservation strategies, working from the ground up through education of local communities to lobbying for change at a government level.

• To create development alternatives for local people to generate economic income while promoting conservation of natural ecosystems at a regional level.

Each of the objectives of the TAJA Station represents a work axis within this initiative. These are transversal work axes, since none is independent of the others. The work axes of the TAJA Station are the following:

• Sustainable tourism

• Forest Protection

• Scientific Research

• Environmental Education

• Technical Training

• Sustainable Development

To fulfill the objectives of the TAJA Station, we intend to implement various environmental programs and key projects. Such conservation strategies include (for example): education programs in local communities; creating sustainable opportunities for local people; planting forest corridors to connect fragmented habitats; farm reforestation and habitat restoration projects, construction of wildlife bridges across major roads; volunteering programs; wildlife monitoring programs within the Barbilla Biological Corridor and the Pacuare river basin; funding scientific research, education programs to reduce poaching of jaguar prey species; and training in sustainable economic activities.

Beyond all historical, cultural, and ethical reasons, the value of wildlife lies in the role it plays on our own subsistence. The results of the work done over the years with the jaguar as a guide, strengthen the idea of seeing it as a key element for designing strategies for its habitat and biological corridor conservation in order to maintain, in a sustainable way, this natural wealth for the benefit of local communities, and prevent the loss of countless regional and global environmental benefits.

Meeting these goals will be a challenge, but as my track record shows, if I believe in something then I will throw my heart and soul into it. I believe that by working together as a united front, we will have the power to secure a brighter future for jaguars in Costa Rica.

    Where Your Money Will Go

    All the money raised through this fundraiser will go directly towards providing basic facilities to carry quality research and targeted education programs in this very important ecoregion.

    Ave Sol River Sanctuary is a nature lodge and reserve with simple cabin accommodations in the heart of the Pacuare river basin. It was first constructed by hand and can accommodate 22 guests. It has no electricity - it is remote, rustic, and blends into the surrounding wilderness. It is how you might picture Costa Rica before exploration. This is all great for tourists that want a place to disconnect from the noise of modern life and get back in touch with nature, but these are not the best conditions to host researchers wanting to study this region.

    Nowadays, scientists need as little as electricity, basic technological and measure tools, access to the internet, and a space for experimental design and data analysis to carry out quality research. This is exactly what we want to achieve with this campaign.

    It is simple; Ave Sol needs a little hook into the grid, but in a very clean and sustainable way. As part of our vision is the rational use of all natural resources, with your help, Ave Sol will generate its own clean and sustainable energy by installing a very simple and low-maintenance, though efficient hydroelectric system highly suited for Ave Sol’s conditions - numerous water springs and steep slopes.

    Ave Sol will also produce its own gas from properly disposing all organic wastes into a biogas digester system. Instead of using the traditional and pollutant sceptic systems commonly found elsewhere, through the anaerobic digestion of biodegradable material, Ave Sol will transform its wastes into biogas and organic compost. Biogas that will be serve many purposes as a much cleaner and less pollutant alternative to fossil fuels, and compost that will be used to grow organic crops for local consumption.

    We also want to provide the space and basic tools to carry out research and education in Ave Sol. With your help, we will build this space in Ave Sol; it will be known as the Jaguar Hall. It will be equipped with desktop computers, video projector, and access to the internet. For this endeavor, we will use sustainably harvested timber from our own reserve - as all current buildings found in Ave Sol; and employ local Indigenous people to help improve their economy.

    This building will be a 100+ m2 circular room that will resemble a traditional Cabecar ‘cosmic house’ – traditional Cabecar construction with great symbolical value. The Cabecar people have lived in Talamanca for thousands of years. With this, we want to give tribute to the original people of Talamanca, the Indigenous Cabecar; the people of the forest; the people of the jaguar.

    We are privileged to have Cabecar families as our neighbors – the Nairi-Awari Indigenous Reserve. The Cabecar community represents one of the largest ethnic groups in Costa Rica. Its people has retained much of their culture and traditions. They are characterized by a system of beliefs and defined rules based in origin on respect for nature, principle that we not only share but also want to promote and multiply through the TAJA Station.

    They live in relatively isolated communities with little or no access at all to basic services such as telephone, electricity, water, and public transportation. They also have little or no access to outside markets. These conditions have led to an external dependency mainly with government subsidies. One of our priorities will be to create development opportunities and alternatives for their people to generate income and promote the conservation of their home, the natural ecosystems of Talamanca. The TAJA Station tends to help Cabecar families through the implementation of a series of sustainable development projects that will improve rural community tourism in Cabecar settlements, offer direct employment to Cabecar men and women, help in their education, and preserve their traditions.

    One of the projects that with your help we will be promoting is the Cabecar Souvenir Shop. Directed towards Cabecar women, we want to provide the space and facilities for Cabecar families to sell their pieces of Indigenous art and other traditional crafts to all of Ave Sol’s guests. In this way, we want to contribute with their income while helping preserve their traditions through the expression of their arts and crafts. We strongly believe that by giving women greater opportunities to participate in the economy, the benefits extend far beyond individual girls and women but also to societies and economies as a whole. Addressing gender gaps in accessing economic opportunities is not just the right thing to do from a human rights perspective; it is also smart economics.

    In addition, we want to bring more and more visitors to Indigenous communities. Improving visitation to the Indigenous Reserve translates in more opportunities to help its people. Visitors get the chance to experience the Cabecar culture, preserved over thousands of years, and learn about some of their modern challenges while bringing support to local families. For example, if desired, people will have the option to carry basic food, health, or school supplies while visiting the children’s school in a Cabecar community. We will provide food / health /school supply packs for every visit we do to the community. The initial number of packs that we will buy depends entirely upon how much money we raise through this fundraiser. We intend to keep funding our Cabecar Aid Program with part of the utilities raised through Ave Sol’s visitation.

    Improving visitation to the Indigenous Reserve is crucial. We need to improve the Ave Sol-Awari Rainforest Trail. Not only that we want the trail to be safe and in good condition anyone to use it, but also we want it to be an environmental education tool by itself. It will provide self-guided quality information that seeks to make walking to the Indigenous Reserve a complete learning and environmental awareness experience. This can achieved with the help of the TAJA Station Volunteer Program.

    By its very nature, volunteerism is an important vehicle for sustainable development. Social cohesion and trust is strengthened through individual and collective volunteer action, leading to sustainable outcomes for people, by people. Volunteerism strengthens civic engagement, safeguards social inclusion, deepens solidarity and solidifies ownership of development results. Importantly, volunteering has a ripple effect. It inspires others and advances the transformations required for our sustainable development goals to take root in communities.

    Besides the operational costs of carrying out all projects, the primary infrastructure and equipment that we are aiming to build and buy includes:

    Item

    Unit price

    Clean energy hydroelectric system, 200+ kwh/month

    Stopcock and flexible tubing, turbine, fuses, rectifier, fm60 load control, marine battery, inverter aps1250

     $15000

    V8 biodigester system (8 m3)

     $3000

    Conference/Study room

    Plan design, workforce, materials, tools, and equipment

     $25000

    Five desktop computers

     $2000

    Video projector

     $2000

    Satellite internet/wi-fi system

     $5000

    Ave Sol – Awari Trail Improvement

    Design, materials, tools, and equipment (workforce will be provided by volunteers)

     $5000

    Food / Health / School supply packs

    $100

     

    All additional donations that we receive on this page will go towards designing and building the Talamanca Jaguar Station and all its projects (research, conservation, sustainable development, and education). Costs will include creating a website, logo design, drawing up and submitting official non-profit documentation, design and implementation of targeted conservation strategies, promotion and marketing, and research and education programs; salaries, professional services, travel expenses, meetings and workshops, external auditing, and purchase of other materials, tools, and equipment.

    How You Can Help Us

    You can help us to conserve these incredible animals and ecosystems by donating whatever you can – no donation is too small, every dollar is a step closer to reaching our goal.

    I passionately believe that your contribution can help to make a huge difference to the conservation of jaguars in Costa Rica. Together we have the chance to discover more about these amazing animals and help to protect them in the future.

    As well as donations, please help us to spread the word and share this page with all of your friends.

    Alternatively, if there are any website or graphic designers out there who would be willing to get involved by donating their time – please send us a message with some samples of your work at rieriopacuare@gmail.com ! We would be delighted to collaborate with you on this project!

    Thank you again for your support and we look forward to step on this journey with you! 

    Follow Our Progress

    If you would like to keep up to date with the project, I will report our progress on Ave Sol River Sanctuary’s social networks.

    You can follow us on Facebook and Instagram.

My name is Gustavo Castro and I am a biologist working as scientific director at Ave Sol River Sanctuary. I have been studying jaguars for some years now and currently I am working in this region for my MSc thesis project, under the supervision of the International Institute for Wildlife Conservation and Management at the Costa Rican National University.
Working in this region for the last seven years has brought me close to its great ecological importance and its incredible biodiversity. It has also brought me close to its people and the needs and problems they face everyday. I realize that there is much to do to help safeguard the future of the region's natural ecosystems and its people, and for this reason, we ask for your help in exchange of any of our unique and exciting perks.

They also have little or no access to outside markets. These conditions have led to an external dependency mainly with government subsidies. One of our priorities will be to create development opportunities and alternatives for their people to generate income and promote the conservation of their home, the natural ecosystems of Talamanca. The TAJA Station tends to help Cabecar families through the implementation of a series of sustainable development projects that will improve rural community tourism in Cabecar settlements, offer direct employment to Cabecar men and women, help in their education, and preserve their traditions.
One of the projects that with your help we will be promoting is the Cabecar Souvenir Shop. Directed towards Cabecar women, we want to provide the space and facilities for Cabecar families to sell their pieces of Indigenous art and other traditional crafts to all of Ave Sol’s guests. In this way, we want to contribute with their income while helping preserve their traditions through the expression of their arts and crafts. We strongly believe that by giving women greater opportunities to participate in the economy, the benefits extend far beyond individual girls and women but also to societies and economies as a whole. Addressing gender gaps in accessing economic opportunities is not just the right thing to do from a human rights perspective; it is also smart economics.
In addition, we want to bring more and more visitors to Indigenous communities. Improving visitation to the Indigenous Reserve translates in more opportunities to help its people. Visitors get the chance to experience the Cabecar culture, preserved over thousands of years, and learn about some of their modern challenges while bringing support to local families. For example, if desired, people will have the option to carry basic food, health, or school supplies while visiting the children’s school in a Cabecar community. We will provide food / health /school supply packs for every visit we do to the community. The initial number of packs that we will buy depends entirely upon how much money we raise through this fundraiser. We intend to keep funding our Cabecar Aid Program with part of the utilities raised through Ave Sol’s visitation.

Improving visitation to the Indigenous Reserve is crucial. We need to improve the Ave Sol-Awari Rainforest Trail. Not only that we want the trail to be safe and in good condition anyone to use it, but also we want it to be an environmental education tool by itself. It will provide self-guided quality information that seeks to make walking to the Indigenous Reserve a complete learning and environmental awareness experience. This can achieved with the help of the TAJA Station Volunteer Program.
By its very nature, volunteerism is an important vehicle for sustainable development. Social cohesion and trust is strengthened through individual and collective volunteer action, leading to sustainable outcomes for people, by people. Volunteerism strengthens civic engagement, safeguards social inclusion, deepens solidarity and solidifies ownership of development results. Importantly, volunteering has a ripple effect. It inspires others and advances the transformations required for our sustainable development goals to take root in communities.
Besides the operational costs of carrying out all projects, the primary infrastructure and equipment that we are aiming to build and buy includes:


Item
Unit price



Clean energy hydroelectric system, 200+ kwh/month
Stopcock and flexible tubing, turbine, fuses, rectifier, fm60 load control, marine battery, inverter aps1250

 $15000


V8 biodigester system (8 m3)
 $3000



Conference/Study room
Plan design, workforce, materials, tools, and equipment

 $25000


Five desktop computers
 $2000


Video projector
 $2000


Satellite internet/wi-fi system
 $5000



Ave Sol – Awari Trail Improvement
Design, materials, tools, and equipment (workforce will be provided by volunteers)

 $5000


Food / Health / School supply packs
$100


 
All additional donations that we receive on this page will go towards designing and building the Talamanca Jaguar Station and all its projects (research, conservation, sustainable development, and education). Costs will include creating a website, logo design, drawing up and submitting official non-profit documentation, design and implementation of targeted conservation strategies, promotion and marketing, and research and education programs; salaries, professional services, travel expenses, meetings and workshops, external auditing, and purchase of other materials, tools, and equipment.
How You Can Help Us
You can help us to conserve these incredible animals and ecosystems by donating whatever you can – no donation is too small, every dollar is a step closer to reaching our goal.
I passionately believe that your contribution can help to make a huge difference to the conservation of jaguars in Costa Rica. Together we have the chance to discover more about these amazing animals and help to protect them in the future.
As well as donations, please help us to spread the word and share this page with all of your friends.
Alternatively, if there are any website or graphic designers out there who would be willing to get involved by donating their time – please send us a message with some samples of your work at rieriopacuare@gmail.com ! We would be delighted to collaborate with you on this project!
Thank you again for your support and we look forward to step on this journey with you! 
Follow Our Progress
If you would like to keep up to date with the project, I will report our progress on Ave Sol River Sanctuary’s social networks.
You can follow us on Facebook and Instagram.

story:
Plant 1-Tree for Humanity!

IAMovement and Young Water Solutions call upon you to join the #AmazonChallenge! The Amazon has been called the lungs of our planet, and together we can do our part to replace some of the trees that have been lost to fires - while sending a message that humanity is strong, and we consider care for our environment, indigenous peoples and wildlife a global priority.

This is a call to action: If you can't plant a tree physically - donate here to have your tree planted for you!

We challenge you to plant one tree, which you know you can take care of, and post a picture or video with your own #AmazonChallenge message and nominate 3 of your friends to do the same. There are 7 billion of us, and every tree counts. If it's impossible for you to plant a tree based on where you are - donate $5 to this campaign to plant your tree (or more if you wish) - and then tag 3 friends to plant their own as well!

We guarantee that every dollar received here will go towards planting trees - and while we promise to have at least one tree planted for every $5 received, we will find and work with the best partners for greatest number of trees and impact - which can possibly mean more trees getting planted, and communities in need being involved in the process, all around the world.

The Impact

This #AmazonChallenge is an act of resilience and solidarity, where we all stand together in the face of seemingly insurmountable challenges - as it pertains to the heart breaking loss of our Amazon rainforest (and other forests around the world), before our very eyes. While participating by planting a tree physically (or virtually - through your donation here to ensure that a tree gets planted) - we are not only helping to undo some of the damages in the Amazon and to capture carbon through our most efficient carbon capture machines right now (trees:), but we are also sending a collective message to those in power that we as awakened, conscious, 'woke' humanity - that our planet, forests, and animals do mean a lot to us, and we believe their PROTECTION and REGENERATION should be a global priority.

#AmazonChallenge #yOURplanet #EveryTreeCounts

story:
Introduction

PERKS FOR EVERYONE BELOW AND IN GALLERY. NGOs & COMPANIES REFER TO PERKS SECTION. 

Almost 100 young people from over the world have been chosen to become delegates of the World Youth Parliament for Water (WYPW). All of them  are very passionate and really worked hard to make it till here. Their next big step is supposed to be South Korea, yet they need your help.

What will happen in South Korea?

They will meet the week before the 7th World Water Forum (WWF) to discuss current issues related to water and sanitation and share their initiatives with other young people involved, policy makers and experts. The WYPW will thus have the opportunity to present their vision and commitments for water by developing a statement and a 2015-2018 action plan. This action plan, the main objective of this work week will be to develop as a "toolbox": a box containing all the tools that young people can use if they wish to implement a concrete project in favour of water and sanitation. These two strategic documents will be presented and promoted within the WWF, which will host nearly 35,000 participants from around the world.

Why is their attendance important? Why should you help?


Our accommodation in South Korea is covered by the Coordinators, yet the delegates had to find a sponsor for the flight ticket. Most of the delegates got sponsored, yet many others did not. Most of the sponsored delegates come from countries that are not experiencing lack of sanitation and access to potable water first hand. We need to balance our team, people from Brazil, parts of Africa, Armenia all worked as hard as the others and deserve to go to South Korea as much. Their motivation is inspiring and their experience will serve to help us find real tangible solutions. Water is what we will work for, yet we know that we will work better if we stick together all the nations.

WE WILL UPLOAD THE DECLARATION PRESENTED DURING THE WORLD WATER FORUM, RESULTS AND PICTURES.

WATER IS LIFE AND IF YOU HELP US WITH THIS CAMPAIGN YOU WILL BE HELPING US GIVE LIFE.

story:
En FRANÇAIS c'est par ICI! 
For the ENGLISH version press HERE!


Objetivo

Construir una casa sustentable, que sea social y económicamente viable en una realidad concreta, que sirva de modelo para la construcción de viviendas sociales. La construcción seguirá los objetivos de: ahorrar energía, mejorar la calidad de vida, y disminuir el impacto ambiental.

Todo el proceso del proyecto será documentado para poder difundir de forma masiva la información recaudada desde su comienzo hasta su finalización, facilitando la reproducción de este tipo de vivienda, respetando las condiciones precisas de cada lugar.


¿Quiénes Somos?

Somos una pareja joven que decidimos cambiar de vida. Vendimos lo poco que teníamos en Buenos Aires y comenzamos un viaje sin tiempo por América (pueden visitar nuestro blog en www.tiemposdeagua.com). Justo antes de partir tuvimos la grata sorpresa que dentro de poco se sumaría un integrante más a nuestro viaje. Esto no hizo que se detuviera nuestra aventura sino que le dio mayor sentido. Luego de varios meses de recorrido en Argentina, Chile y Bolivia, decidimos instalarnos unos meses esperando el nacimiento de nuestra hija en las Sierras de Córdoba. Queremos aprovechar de este espacio que nos dimos para realizar un proyecto útil para la comunidad y estimulante personalmente. Evaluando todo lo vivido hasta ahora en el viaje, más las propias experiencias que cada uno traía de nuestro pasado, decidimos darle vida a esta nueva idea.


¿Cómo nace la idea?

Al poco tiempo de comenzar nuestro viaje por America, las conversaciones acerca de las problemáticas de cada lugar que descubríamos eran cada vez más frecuentes. 

A cada paso encontrábamos problemas socio-ambientales que parecían tener una solución fácil, pero probablemente era una visión desde la perspectiva de personas con una determinada educación, consciencia ecológica o bien de un cierto poder adquisitivo. Notamos tristemente que esas soluciones no se aplicaban y no eran tan obvias para el lugar o la población como nos parecía.

Por ejemplo, vivimos la fuerte radiación solar que hay tanto en el Sur Argentino como en el Chileno, y sin embargo la energía solar no es aprovechada, no vimos casi calentadores solares.

Sentimos los vientos constantes y veloces de la Patagonia, y vimos varias pequeñas turbinas eólicas en las casas, pero estaban todas frenadas por falta de mantenimiento y de información de las poblaciones sobre el funcionamiento de las mismas.

Sufrimos el olor nauseabundo por las calles de algunos pueblos del norte argentino, y nos enteramos de que eran aguas sucias que estaban siendo enviadas de forma directa y sin tratamiento al río, el mismo que sirve para el riego y el ganado.

Vimos montañas de basura alrededor de los pueblos en Bolivia, contaminando el ambiente y los recursos hídricos y creando lugares insalubres.

Todos estos pequeños ejemplos nos hicieron preguntarnos: 

  • Cómo mejorar la calidad de vida de los latinoamericanos? 
  • Cómo aprovechar los recursos naturales de nuestro continente? 
  • Cómo vivir en mejor armonía con nuestro entorno y limitar el impacto ambiental?

De a poco la idea comenzaba a gestarse, y al llegar a las sierras de Córdoba, instalarnos y saber que por algunos meses ya no viajaríamos, nos pusimos a pensar en lo que podíamos hacer hasta que nazca nuestra hija. También reflexionamos sobre nuestra nueva responsabilidad, y a qué mundo queríamos traer a nuestra hija. Pensamos en la pregunta que nos podría hacer ella en algún momento: “ Y ustedes qué hicieron por cambiar algo? Sólo observaron y criticaron?“ Creemos que debemos actuar, y ahora tenemos la suerte de habernos dado el tiempo para poder hacerlo. Así que qué mejor que empezar ahora mismo!

¿Cuál es la solución?

Nuestra idea es construir una casa de bajo consumo energético y sustentable, que sirva de modelo para la construcción de viviendas sociales. Nos dimos cuenta de que, para mejorar la calidad de vida de las personas y disminuir el impacto ambiental, tenemos que juntar las diferentes tecnologías y practicas sustentables en un solo lugar, que se pueda visitar y que sirva de inspiración para mejores viviendas en otros lugares.

A corto plazo esta vivienda mejora la calidad de vida de la gente, y disminuye el impacto ambiental a futuro. Todo el proceso será documentado, desde su comienzo hasta su finalización, y toda la información recaudada será compartida de forma gratuita y masiva con la elaboración de un informe final. 

Cuando se nos presentó la oportunidad de hacerlo realmente – ya que disponemos de tiempo y del terreno físico – decidimos crear este proyecto demostrando que este enfoque de sostenibilidad es viable, y que servirá de base educativa accesible a todos a largo plazo.

Creemos que nuestro proyecto va a tener éxito porque:

- Valoramos el conocimiento que obtuvimos tanto en nuestra educación y profesión como en nuestra experiencia de vida.

- Conocemos el lugar y la cultura local, por lo cual nuestro proyecto estará enfocado en brindar soluciones locales que podrán ser adaptadas a otros lugares específicos con condiciones similares.

- Estamos enfocados en responder a necesidades reales, y no solo impresiones. A lo largo de nuestro viaje consultamos a las comunidades sobre sus necesidades, y confirmaremos la información recaudada con una primera fase de investigación, parte esencial en nuestro proyecto. Las soluciones brindadas estarán adaptadas a la población, para su mejor aceptación.

- Somos curiosos e innovadores, y estamos convencidos que este proyecto tiene un potencial que puede ser valorizado tecnológicamente y económicamente.


¿Qué criterios tomamos para el proyecto?

- Una casa económica. Necesitamos una casa que sea lo más accesible económicamente, ya que vimos en muchos lugares la falta de viviendas.

- Una casa simple. Esta vivienda estará adaptada a la población que la podría habitar, evitando cambios culturales drásticos. Las tecnologías implantadas tienen que mantenerse simples de uso y adaptadas a la comunidad, para que tenga una mayor aceptación social.

- Poco mantenimiento necesario. La vivienda y sus tecnologías deben requerir el mínimo mantenimiento especializado posible, en caso contrario existe el riesgo de que dejen de funcionar pronto.

- Eficiencia energética. El objetivo es reducir los gastos energéticos para minimizar el impacto ambiental y disminuir los costos de mantenimiento. (Ejemplo: Colectores solares, orientación incorporando conceptos bioclimaticos)

- Racionalización y reuso de agua. Con sistemas de filtrado, mecanismos de ahorro de agua (grifería, difusores incorporados, inodoros con doble descarga...), reutilización de aguas grises, y otros sistemas de reuso apropiados.

- Minimizar los desechos. Logrando producir menos desechos y reutilizar los mismos, reduciremos el impacto ambiental de la vivienda. Los residuos serán separados entre inorgánicos y orgánicos, reciclando estos últimos en composteras. El compost obtenido será utilizado en la huerta orgánica, que estará integrada a la casa de una manera funcional, estética y proporcionará gran parte de los vegetales frescos que se consumen durante todo el año.

- Sustentabilidad. La idea principal es que la construccion y estas practicas sean durables en el tiempo, y que se adapten a la poblacion como algo cotidiano.

- Un modelo reproducible. Nuestra visión es que este proyecto sirva como modelo para la construcción de nuevas viviendas y barrios sustentables, que se pueda reproducir y adaptar a diferentes escalas y en distintas localidades. La justificación de cada decisión es clave para poder adaptar este modelo a otros lugares, acorde con el clima, la población y los materiales disponibles. 

No estamos hablando forzosamente de tecnologías muy sofisticadas y costosas, sino pequeñas mejoras constructivas y practicas fácilmente implementables para reducir consumo, impacto ambiental, y mejorar significativamente calidad de vida.


¿Cómo empezar?

Fue uno de los grandes interrogantes, poder concentrar mucha información procesarla y arrancar el proyecto no es nada sencillo. Comenzamos investigando de forma general los diferentes métodos de ahorro de energía y de producción de la misma de la forma más eficiente y menos contaminante posible. Averiguamos sistemas de tratamiento y reuso de aguas, y los tiempos aproximados necesarios para la construcción de una vivienda en esta zona. Para quedarnos en un proyecto muy concreto, decidimos igualmente preguntar a la comunidad local cuáles eran sus mayores problemáticas. Definimos cuales eran los criterios claves que proporcionan un marco para el proyecto. 

Así con esta información reunida, más nuestras propias experiencias decidimos dar el siguiente paso y buscar la manera de financiar semejante sueño. Si buscamos una solución que termine siendo un servicio a la comunidad, que mejor que apelar a ella para lograrlo: ahí es cuando nos dirigimos hacia el Crowfunding. Creemos que esta plataforma para recaudar fondos y dar a conocer nuestro proyecto se acerca mucho a la idea comunitaria que poseemos. Esperamos conseguir colaboradores con los mismos valores y preocupaciones que nosotros, que compartan nuestra visión y nos ayuden a ayudar.


¿Cómo se va a desarrollar el proyecto?

En esta primer etapa toda nuestra energía está enfocada en darle difusión, conseguir los fondos, y paralelamente seguir investigando.

Esta investigación que ya empezó hace un tiempo, reúne en un principio datos del tipo de terreno que poseemos, el clima de la zona, los recursos naturales disponibles, el acceso al agua y a los servicios básicos, en fin todo el relevamiento de las condiciones iniciales locales.

Luego será la hora de buscar la solución más adecuada posible a estas condiciones, siempre basándonos en nuestros criterios antes mencionados. Esto incluye la investigación minuciosa de las tecnologías aplicables, los materiales disponibles en la zona, el pedido de presupuestos, entre otras.

Cada etapa del proceso será documentada. Una vez que tengamos los resultados y las decisiones tomadas, será la etapa de la compra de los materiales para luego comenzar la construcción de la vivienda.

Una vez terminada la vivienda, ya habiendo sido probada y solucionado los diferentes problemas que se podrían presentar, nos dedicaremos a la difusión adecuada para reproducirla en otros lugares. Esta última etapa es tal vez la más importante, ya que nuestro objetivo final es demostrar que se puede construir una vivienda económica, ecológica y sustentable, y compartir la información. Además, no sólo queremos dejar los datos para acceso libre, sino realmente educar a las personas, dar charlas sobre el proyecto y sobre la factibilidad de reproducirlo.


¿Cómo colaborar?

Una gran ayuda es el aporte económico por medio del Crowfunding, pero no menos importante son esos aportes que no se pueden medir con dinero. Todos pueden ayudarnos con:

- Enviarnos información de utilidad acerca de tecnologías aplicadas en otros lugares

- La difusión del proyecto

- Una palabra o mail de aliento, una crítica constructiva

- Sumarse como voluntario tanto para la hora de la mano de obra como para la comunicación

En fin, es un proyecto ambicioso y es mucho el trabajo, pero estamos convencidos que juntos lo podemos lograr. Toda colaboración e ideas son bienvenidas!


¿Por qué apoyarnos?

Tenemos una gran convicción y determinación para realizar este sueño. Muchas veces en nuestra vida - y especialmente en este último tiempo - han considerado que lo que emprendíamos era una locura, pero al ver los buenos resultados nos han comenzado a apoyar. Sabemos adaptarnos a las situaciones y somos flexibles ante una nueva oportunidad, como la que nos presenta hoy la vida. Seamos Realistas, Hagamos lo Imposible


Français

Projet EcoCasa Suyana

Maison écologique, économique et durable

Objectif

Construire une maison écologique, durable, qui soit socialement et économiquement viable, qui serve de modèle pour la construction de logements. La construction suivra les objectifs d'économie d'énergie, d'amélioration de la qualité de vie et de réduction de l'impact sur l'environnement.

L'ensemble du processus du projet sera documenté et l'information sera massivement diffusée, ce qui facilitera la reproduction de ce type de logement, en respectant les conditions spécifiques de chaque site.


À Propos De Nous

Nous sommes un jeune couple qui a décidé de changer de vie. Nous avons vendu le peu de choses que nous avions à Buenos Aires et commencé un voyage sans limite de temps en Amérique latine (vous pouvez visiter notre blog sur www.tiemposdeagua.com). Juste avant de partir, nous avons eu l'agréable surprise que bientôt nous allions accueillir un autre membre qui ferait partie du voyage. Cela n'a pas empêché notre aventure, et au contraire lui a donné plus de sens. Après plusieurs mois de voyage en Argentine, Chili et Bolivie, nous avons décidé de nous installer quelques mois en attendant la prochaine naissance de notre fille dans les montagnes de Córdoba. Nous voulons profiter de cet espace que nous nous sommes accordés pour réaliser un projet stimulant et utile à la communauté. Apres l’évaluation de tout ce que nous avons vécu jusqu'à présent lors de notre voyage, nous avons décidé de donner vie à cette nouvelle idée.


Comment est née l'idée?

Peu de temps après le début de notre voyage, les conversations sur les problèmes particuliers à chaque lieu que nous découvrions se faisaient de plus en plus fréquentes. En partie parce que nous étions ensemble jour et nuit, et parce que nous étions très ouverts et sensibles à tout ce qui se passait autour de nous.

A chaque endroit, nous avons trouvé des problèmes sociaux et environnementaux qui semblaient avoir une solution facile, mais il s'agissait probablement d'une vision du point de vue de personnes avec une certaine éducation, une conscience écologique ou bien un certain pouvoir d'achat. Nous avons malheureusement constaté que ces solutions ne sont pas appliquées et ne sont pas aussi évidentes aux yeux des habitants.

Par exemple, nous avons vécu le fort ensoleillement dans le sud de l’Argentine et du Chili, et pourtant l'énergie solaire n'est point exploitée: nous n'avons pas vu de chauffe-eau solaires.

Nous avons senti les vents constants de la Patagonie, et nous avons vu par endroits l’installation de petites éoliennes dans les maisons, mais elles étaint toutes à l’arrêt. Lorsque nous avons interrogé les habitants sur l’état des éoliennes, leur réponse fut: “Elles ont été installées il y a deux ans, mais elles ne fonctionnent plus. Il parait que nous faisons mauvais usage des batteries, mais on ne sait pas vraiment comment cela fonctionne. Maintenant, nous attendons que quelqu'un vienne fixer l'installation car le système est verrouillé et ne peut être touché que par un expert ".

Nous avons souffert des odeurs nauséabondes des rues de certaines villes dans le nord de l'Argentine, et avons découvert qu'il s'agissait des égouts qui étaient directement déversés sans traitement vers le fleuve, qui était lui-même utilisé pour l'irrigation et l'élevage.

Nous avons vu des décharges d'ordures en plein air autour des villages en Bolivie, polluant l'environnement ainsi que les ressources hydriques, et créant des lieux insalubres.

Tous ces petits exemples nous ont fait réfléchir et nous demander : 

  • Comment améliorer la qualité de vie des communautés en Amérique latine? 
  • Comment profiter et protéger les ressources naturelles de notre continent? 
  • Comment limiter l'impact sur l'environnement?

Petit à petit, l'idée a commencé à prendre forme, et lorsque nous nous sommes installés dans les montagnes de Cordoba, sachant que nous n'allions plus voyager pendant quelques mois, nous avons commencé à réfléchir à ce que nous pourrions faire jusqu'à la naissance de notre fille. Nous avons également songé à notre nouvelle responsabilité, et quel monde nous voulions pour notre fille. Nous avons pensé a la question qu'elle pourrait nous poser à un certain moment: "Et vous, qu'avez-vous fait pour changer les choses? Vous êtez-vous limité à observer et à critiquer?" Nous croyons que nous devons agir, et aujourd’hui nous avons la chance de nous avoir donné le temps de le faire. Il est temps d'agir, commençons des maintenant!


Quelle est la solution?

Notre idée est de construire une maison à faible consommation énergétique, durable, qui servira de modèle pour la construction de logements sociaux. Nous avons réalisé que, afin d'améliorer la qualité de vie et réduire l'impact environnemental, nous devons rassembler les différentes technologies et pratiques durables en un seul endroit: dans une maison qui serve de modèle, qui puisse être visitée et qui soit une source d'inspiration pour de meilleurs logements.

L'ensemble du processus sera documenté, du début jusqu'à la fin, et toute information recueillie sera partagée gratuitement.

Lorsque l'occasion de réaliser ce projet nous est apparue concrètement – étant donné que nous avons le temps et l'espace physique - nous avons décidé de donner vie à notre idée afin de démontrer que cette approche de développement durable est viable, et servira de base éducative accessible à tous à long terme.

Nous espérons que notre projet sera une réussite car il repose sur les points suivants:

- La valorisation de nos connaissances obtenues autant au cours de nos études et expériences professionnelles que personnelles.

- La connaissance du lieu et de la culture locale, de sorte que notre projet se concentrera sur la création de solutions locales qui peuvent être adaptées à d'autres endroits spécifiques ayant des conditions similaires.

- La réponse a des besoins réels et concrets. Tout au long de notre voyage, nous avons consulté les communautés au sujet de leurs besoins, et nous allons confirmer les informations recueillies avec une première phase de recherche, partie essentielle dans notre projet. Les solutions proposées seront adaptées à la population, afin de garantir une meilleure acceptation de celles-ci.

- Nous sommes curieux et innovateurs, et nous sommes convaincus que ce projet a un potentiel technologique et économique.


Quels sont les critères que nous allons prendre en compte?

- Une maison économique. Nous voulons construire une maison abordable, car nous avons remarqué que le manque de logements et la croissance démographique accélérée est un problème courant.

- Une maison simple. Ce logement sera adapté à la population qui pourrait y vivre, en évitant des changements culturels trop brusques. Les technologies mises en place devraient être simples à utiliser et adaptées à la communauté, afin d'avoir une plus grande acceptation sociale.

- Entretien minimum. Afin de limiter les risques de pannes, la maison et les technologies employées doivent avoir un entretien minimum et éviter au mieux tout besoin d'intervention de spécialistes.

- Efficacité énergétique. L'objectif est de réduire les dépenses énergétiques pour minimiser l'impact de l'environnement et de réduire les coûts d'entretien. (Exemple: Chauffe-eau solaires, Orientation intégrant des concepts bioclimatiques)

- Rationalisation et réutilisation de l'eau. Avec les systèmes de filtration, dispositifs d'économie d'eau (robinets, diffuseurs intégrés, toilettes à double chasse ...), traitement des eaux grises, et d'autres systèmes de réutilisation appropriées.

- Réduire les déchets. L'impact environnemental du logement sera moindre si la production de déchets est réduite et s'ils sont recyclés. Les déchets seront séparés entre inorganiques et organiques, et ces derniers seront recyclés pour la production de compost. Le compost obtenu sera utilisé dans le potager organique, qui sera intégré dans la maison d'une façon pratique et esthétique, et fournira une grande partie des légumes frais consommés pendant l'année.

- Une maison durable. L'idée principale est que la construction et les pratiques nommées soient durables dans le temps, et adaptables à la vie quotidienne.

- Un modèle reproductible. Notre but est que ce projet soit un modèle pour la construction de nouvelles maisons et de quartiers durables, qui puisse se reproduire et s'adapter à différentes échelles et à divers endroits. La justification de chaque décision est essentielle pour adapter ce modèle à d'autres lieux, selon le climat, la population et les matériaux disponibles. Nous ne parlons pas nécessairement de technologies très sophistiquées et coûteuses, mais de petites améliorations de conception, et la mise en place d'actions facilement réalisables pour réduire la consommation, l'impact sur l'environnement, et améliorer la qualité de vie de manière significative.


Par où commencer?

Ce fut une de nos questions, rassembler des donneés et les traiter afin de pouvoir démarrer le projet n'est pas si simple. Nous avons commencé par faire des recherches sur les différentes méthodes d'économie d'énergie en général, et sa production de manière efficace et non-polluante. Nous avons découvert des systèmes de traitement et de réutilisation de l'eau. Nous nous sommes renseignés sur les temps approximatifs requis pour la construire d'une maison dans cette zone. Afin de garder les pieds sur terre et de créer un projet concret, nous avons également décidé d'en parler à nos voisins et nous renseigner sur leurs plus grands problèmes.

Ainsi, avec toutes ces informations recueillies, ajoutées a nos propres expériences, nous avons décidé de faire le grand pas: donner un cadre à notre projet et trouver un moyen de financer un tel rêve. Si nous cherchons une solution qui sera un service à la communauté, comment ne pas y faire appel afin d'atteindre cet objectif? C'est ainsi que nous nous sommes dirigés vers le Crowdfunding. Nous croyons que cette plate-forme pour lever des fonds et faire connaître notre projet est très proche de l'idée d'entraide communautaire que nous tenons. Nous espérons trouver des partenaires avec les mêmes valeurs et préoccupations que nous, qui partagent notre vision et nous aident à aider.


Quel sera le déroulement du projet?

Au cours de cette première étape, nous sommes concentrés sur la diffusion du projet, la collecte de fonds, et la poursuite de nos recherches.

Cette recherche qui a déjà commencé il y a un certain temps, recueille en un premier temps des données sur le type de terrain que nous possédons, le climat local, les ressources naturelles, l'accès à l'eau et aux services de base, afin d'étudier toutes les conditions initiales locales.

Ensuite, il sera temps de trouver la meilleure solution possible en tenant compte de ces conditions, en gardant toujours comme repère les critères nommés ci-dessus. Cela inclut une recherche approfondie des technologies applicables, des matériaux disponibles dans la région, ainsi que de la demande de devis, entre autres.

Chaque étape du processus sera documentée. Suite a la synthèse des résultats et la prise de décision, il sera temps de passer à l'étape d'achat des matériaux et de commencer la construction de la maison.

Une fois la maison construite, après l’avoir testée et fait face aux différents problèmes qui pourraient survenir, nous allons nous concentrer sur la diffusion appropriée afin de reproduire ce modèle ailleurs. Cette dernière étape est peut-être la plus importante, car notre but ultime est de démontrer que la construction d'une maison économique, écologique et durable est possible, et nous allons partager toute l'information assemblée au cours du projet. De plus, non seulement nous voulons laisser libre accès aux données, mais réellement contribuer à l’éducation des populations, donner des conférences sur le projet et sur sa faisabilité.


Comment contribuer?

La contribution économique à travers le Crowdfunding est importante, mais toute aide non mesurable économiquement est tout aussi essentielle. Chacun peut nous aider avec:

- L'envoi d'information utile sur les technologies appliquées ailleurs

- La diffusion du projet

- Un mot d'encouragement, des critiques constructives

- Du travail de bénévolat sur le terrain

Enfin, il s'agit d'un projet ambitieux qui demande beaucoup de travail, mais nous sommes convaincus qu'ensemble nous pouvons lui donner vie. Toute contribution et idée sont les bienvenues!


Pourquoi nous soutenir?

Nous avons une grande conviction et détermination pour réaliser ce rêve. Plusieurs fois dans nos vies - et surtout ces derniers temps – nous avons été qualifiés de fous par les projets que nous entreprenions. Mais en voyant les bons résultats obtenus, nous avons commencé à être soutenus et encouragés dans nos démarches. Nous savons nous adapter et sommes flexibles face à de nouvelles opportunités, comme celle que la vie nous présente aujourd'hui. Soyons réalistes, faisons l'impossible!


10$ - Préparation du terrain

Merci! Votre contribution est essentielle pour nous: votre nom sera dans le rapport final, sur notre blog et les réseaux sociaux.

30$ - Chaque brique compte

Vous faites partie de Suyana! Votre nom sera écrit sur une brique de la maison. Vous recevrez une photo avec votre brique pour que vous l'ayez dans votre propre maison.

80$ - information exclusive

En plus des récompenses précédentes, vous serez le premier à recevoir toutes les informations du projet au format PDF. L'écoconstruction d'une maison comme Suyana n'aura plus aucun secret pour vous!

120$ - Partagez notre rêve

Portez fièrement notre motivant t-shirt "Soyons réalistes, demandons l'impossible!". Soyez inspiré et partagez votre histoire avec nous. Quel est votre rêve?

300$ - Mettez les mains à la pate!
