story:
Update! The Buena Vista Roastery has agreed to match the next $1000 raised through the campaign.

Our Opportunity to Change the Future

"I'm often told that it isn't smart to invest in Zimbabwe. We aren't. We're investing in its people." Laurie Benson, Founder, 1% For Women

We need your help to get started! Select a perk to make it happen!

The secret to incredible change is in healthy soil.

We have partnered with Slow Food International to change the stories for communities across Africa. These communities struggle daily to adapt to the impacts of climate change, feed their families, and find water to meet their basic needs. 1% For Women and Slow Food International's 10,000 Gardens in Africa Project are providing the skills and tools necessary to change the future for these people. Slow Food's project creates community and school gardens across the African Continent. The opportunity is now available for 1% For Women to train members in these garden communities, creating ripple effects that could shift the future for a continent incredibly affected by climate change, poverty and malnutrition.

The 10,000 Gardens Project coupled with our train-the-trainers program will increase crop production, increase access to water and create soil that is once again healthy and can support thriving communities.

Our team is working in collaboration with Slow Food International, Chinhoyi University of Technology, Chibememe Earth Healing Association and Zimbabwe Smallholder Organic Farmers Forum. Our 1% For Women team is experienced and ready to provide Holistic Land and Livestock Management to communities, beginning with this pilot project in Zimbabwe. Why is this important:

  • Holistic Land and Livestock Management uses tools already available within these African communities to heal the land.
  • Cattle are an important and prevalent part of families across Africa. They provide food and are a status symbol. When used in a communal manner, they are a tool that can repair the soil, increase crop production and raise the water table, creating access to water year-round.
  • Communal grazing has proven to increase crop production and yields enabling communities to stand on their own and ensure their families and neighbors have access to healthy, nutritious food.
  • By raising the water table, Holistic Land and Livestock Management changes the lives of women and children. Women who once awoke at 2am to gather their limited water for the day, can now focus on contributing to their family income, educate their children and earn respect for their ability to contribute to change and growth.
  • Healthy communities create healthy, empowered children that stay in school and positively contribute to the future of their families and communities, both local and global.

Here is a great graphic from the Chicago Council on Global Affairs that highlights why it is so important to support women in agriculture.


The Process

1% For Women is the organization coordinating and implementing the Slow Food and holistic management training package across Africa.  1% For Women values local ownership of the projects, hence the use of local people as representatives on the ground. We train trainers to keep the progress and momentum going well into the future.

The focus of our trainings is creating healthy soil. Soil that can once again sustain life, capture rain fall, and support communities encouraging families to stay together and thrive.

By focusing on communities that have already engaged with Slow Food, we know we have access to a group that is ready to learn and create change for themselves. A community already interested in taking control of their future.

The impact on surrounding communities will be felt by improved livelihoods, increased access to water, and increased crop production. The ripple effect created from this work will continue to spread and grow as the knowledge moves beyond the beginning communities.

You can learn more about our training program and request additional information on our website.

What Your Contribution Does

Your contribution allows us to go into these communities that are already invested in changing their own future, and provide training. Our train-the-trainers program focuses on community development, holistic land and livestock training, agroecology, natural resource planning, financial planning and more.

By training individuals within these communities, we provide the skills and tools needed to restore healthy soil, raise the water table and increase crop production, bringing security and dignity to families.

These communities become examples for their neighbors and they are soon sharing their knowledge and continuing this cycle of healing and growth.

Each community will cost approximately $12,500 for the following expenses. Your support will allow us to begin in 2 new communities in 2016.

Expenses:

Community Resources & Training Include:

Training Workshops

Resources and funding for community herders

Garden and Kraal (temporary, movable cattle enclosures) materials

Educational materials

Trainer lodging, food and travel

Marketing and outreach

The Communities and Gardens

There are 9 gardens in communities around Harare, Zimbabwe where our work begins. These gardens are at schools and also in the community centers of these villages. All 9 gardens are underway, with community members and school children engaged in elevating the quality of life of their friends and family.

Below is a description of the gardens as provided by our partners CHIEHA:

1. CHIEHA Garden

CHIEHA garden is the Chiredzi District, Masingo Province. The garden has 35 members composed of 23 women and 12 men.  One of their goals is to:  "locally supply fresh organic and nutritious vegetables to people living with HIV/AIDS". Apart from the garden project the group is also rehabilitating degraded land within their environment and at the same time encouraging each other to practice water harvesting as a move to recharge their ground water to guarantee adequate water supply for the garden.

2. Chiyambiro School Garden

Chiyambiro secondary school garden was established as a demonstration garden for school children. The school adopted organic agriculture as one of the key hands on lessons for young rural children. They are working with cluster leadership integrating the school into the social and productive skills development of the young schooling generation aimed at encouraging them to love farming that is  ecologically sound, easy, and appropriate to the  communal situation where resources are limited. The garden created learning examples of soil mulching, fertility trenches, and compost heaps and inters cropping. The cluster Coordinator provided training on agro ecology to the school children and their teachers. Agro ecology is gradually developing in the minds of this younger generation.

3. Takunda Sangwe School Garden

Takunda Secondary School garden is another garden that has benefited from the Slow Food project due to its important function of educating children in the community through developing learning examples for the children. Members of the Eastern cluster are continuing their efforts to link schools in order to disseminate information into their community on agro ecology, local seeds systems, climate change, youth and women empowerment.

4. Mhlotshana Garden

The new Mhlotshana Garden was started in the community by 20 smallholder farmers. The members started to fence off the area and introduced zero gradient contours using an ‘A’ frame. Land preparation began in order to work the soil before the farmers started to plant crops. The garden is close to the water point that has perennial water. The project funds managed to repair the group water pump and engine and bought the following to make sure the garden is functional, 100l Diesel, vegetable seeds. As seed beds were prepared a short course on Nursery management was done followed by planting. To date transplanting of tomatoes, cabbages. rape, choumolier and onions has been completed. "We are therefore expressing our great thanks to the organization for making our dream come true by availing funds to the garden", the farmers said.

5. Sibantubanye Garden

Another community garden of 18 members’ was established at Sibantubanye community. The area the garden was established in is very dry receiving an annual rainfall of 400mm per year. The 2013-14 rain season had good rains in Matebeleland provinces leading to high yields in the rain fed arable land. The members of Sibantubanye started working their garden after they had completed harvesting their crops. Seedlings nurseries were planted following a training conducted by cluster Coordinator on nursery management and currently the members are transplanting seedlings on their plots.

6. Mupata Garden

Mupata garden was established by the local Chief some 10 years ago following a successful project towards rehabilitation of a degraded wetland. The Chief realized that there was need to utilize the water and therefore he encouraged his community to develop the garden. Over the past years the garden has been irrigated by buckets which had become strenuous to the elderly. The coming of the Slow Foods Project was a blessing to the Chief and his community. An engine, water pump and 100m polythene pipe were purchased. Watering is now easy for the community and to date a variety of vegetable crops are growing in the garden supplying the community with adequate vegetables such as tomatoes, carrots, onions, rape and beans. The project has also become an eco-tourist attraction site and visited by many foreigners.

7. Topora Garden

Topora garden is an initiative of the 25 local community members in the Masvingo district. The garden was initially fenced with tree branches from the nearby forest. The Slow Food Project managed to support this community to purchase 3 by 50kgs of barbed wire and 4 by 1kg fencing nails. .The farmers have already started fencing the garden using barbed wire to close the phase of repairing every year due to stray animals. The garden is now well protected against cattle but sheep and goats still remain a challenge. The farmers are now able to grow their vegetables all year round. A variety of vegetables are being grown such as, chaumolia, sugar beans, rape, covo, onion, tomatoes, carrots, cabbage and early maize. Members were inactive due to stray animals but now they are fully participating. Members who are participating in the garden comprise of widows and youths. The number of members has also increased from 12 to 15 members.  In the garden there are also some herds such as lemon grass, mint, lavender, rosemary and comfrey.

8. Zunde Garden

Zunde garden was started some 5 years ago by 21 members (8 men and 13 women). The idea was to develop a demonstration model of permaculture where different vegetables are integrated with different herbal plants that act as pest repellants. Production in the garden declined because the farmers were no longer able to irrigate with buckets due to aging of the members and the difficulty carrying the water.
Production has just commenced following support from the Slow Food project. This garden was assisted with barbed wire fence, 100m hose pipe, 2 garden forks, different varieties of seeds such squash, potatoes, rape, onions, peas and carrots and production of vegetables is expected to commence.
Following the good rains of the 2013-14 season herbs are beginning to regrow and quite a number of people are benefiting through using these herbs as natural medicines.

9. Kuwirirana Garden

Kuwirana group has 6 members (5 female and 1 male) and these farmers are working very hard in a garden of 96m x 66m. They are growing different vegetables that are being sold to the local township. They also produce mushroom in their homesteads. Production in the garden had declined to lack of proper watering equipment and other garden tools. The five female members are elderly women who are now finding it hard to carry buckets and walk for long distances.
This garden was assisted with barbed wire fence; 100m hose pipe, 2 garden forks, and different varieties of seeds such squash, potatoes, rape, onions, peas and carrots.
Production have improved, watering has been made easier and thee garden is now well fenced reducing the problem of stray animals.

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising the funding for this collaborative project beginning in Zimbabwe and spreading across the African Continent. The results of this training have been proven, and the communities are already engaged  through their existing Slow Food Gardens. We will begin working with university students both in Harare, Zimbabwe and the United States to gather baseline data and put all of the pieces in place to scale our project across the African Continent. Changing the landscape of Africa is critical to global climate change efforts.

The next stage of training and implementation will take $25,000 to complete. Our team has been self-funding to date and has committed over $30,000 to get the project underway. We are committed to investing the additional $10,000 from the money we raise through this campaign to get the implementation started. With your support we can begin the work in Zimbabwe that will act as a springboard to impact garden communities and schools throughout Africa.

As a thank you for your support, we are offering incredible perks from one of our 1% For Women Businesses, the Buena Vista Roastery. 


The Roastery offers fair-trade, organic coffees and works directly with women farmers in Costa Rica and Guatemala. They are also the first non-land-based business to use Holistic Management to increase their profits and local and global community impact. We are excited to offer you some of their incredible coffee in return for your support.

Bumper Stickers! Some of our perks also include our 1% for Women bumper stickers, so you can show the world that you are engaged in creating a better future for us all.

Our Team

Our team at 1% for Women has experience and proven results implementing Holistic Land and Livestock Management (HLLM) in communities around the world.

In a community outside of Victoria Falls, Zimbabwe, the women used to wake at 2am and walk a significant distance to gather their water for the day from a communal well. If they over slept, or were late getting to the well, they and their families often went without water for the day.

Through HLLM and Communal Grazing Training, this community now has water that flows through their village, even during the dry season. The flowing water has changed the lives of the entire community. The women now contribute to the livelihood of their families, the community receives money for the water they are "creating" in the river, crops are thriving and their quality of life for all has increased significantly.

From their example, and the training from our team members, this community is now training and supporting adjoining communities.

The Slow Food Gardens Project utilizes individuals within the countries and communities of impact. Individuals familiar with the culture and ancestral knowledge of the communities.

Together, we collectively work to understand the community goals and needs, use their available tools to create a plan, monitor and adjust as necessary, all the while training them and empowering the community members to continue to thrive well into the future.

These efforts are being lead by our founder, Laurie Benson. After spending years promoting the work of Zimbabwean biologist Allan Savory and Holistic Management, she stepped out on her own to focus on empowering and uplifting women in agriculture on a global level. She believes that the empowerment of women is a crucial component to changing worldwide economic, environmental and social degradation.

Based in Buena Vista, CO, 1% For Women promotes businesses that commit 1% of their net profit to microcredit loans for women in agriculture around the world, actively changing the cycles of poverty and oppression that still affect so many. Along with the microcredit loans, 1% For Women brings the training program highlighted above to communities around the world.


Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can support financially. Please help us spread the word and create lasting change by using the Indiegogo share tools to share our campaign with your friends.

We appreciate your support and you taking the time to help us succeed!
story_txt:

Some of our perks also include our 1% for Women bumper stickers, so you can show the world that you are engaged in creating a better future for us all.
  Our Team
Our team at 1% for Women has experience and proven results implementing Holistic Land and Livestock Management (HLLM) in communities around the world. In a community outside of Victoria Falls, Zimbabwe, the women used to 
wake at 2am and walk a significant distance to gather their water for 
the day from a communal well. If they over slept, or were late getting 
to the well, they and their families often went without water for the 
day.Through HLLM and Communal Grazing Training, this community now has water that flows through their village, even during the dry season. The flowing water has changed the lives of the entire community. The women now contribute to the livelihood of their families, the community receives money for the water they are "creating" in the river, crops are thriving and their quality of life for all has increased significantly.From their example, and the training from our team members, this community is now training and supporting adjoining communities. The Slow Food Gardens Project utilizes individuals within the countries and communities of impact. Individuals familiar with the culture and ancestral knowledge of the communities. Together, we collectively work to understand the community goals and needs, use their available tools to create a plan, monitor and adjust as necessary, all the while training them and empowering the community members to continue to thrive well into the future.These efforts are being lead by our founder, Laurie Benson. After spending years promoting the work of Zimbabwean biologist Allan Savory and Holistic Management, she stepped out on her own to focus on empowering and uplifting women in agriculture on a global level. She believes that the empowerment of women is a crucial component to changing worldwide economic, environmental and social degradation.Based in Buena Vista, CO, 1% For Women promotes businesses that commit 1% of their net profit to microcredit loans for women in agriculture around the world, actively changing the cycles of poverty and oppression that still affect so many. Along with the microcredit loans, 1% For Women brings the training program highlighted above to communities around the world.

  Other Ways You Can Help We understand that not everyone can support financially. Please help us spread the word and create lasting change by using the Indiegogo share tools to share our campaign with your friends. 
We appreciate your support and you taking the time to help us succeed!

story:
Short Summary

Margarito’s Forest, a bilingual book in Spanish and K’iche’, is based on the life of Margarito Velázquez as told by his daughter, María Guadelupe. As a child, Margarito showed an early interest in growing plants by taking tree seedlings from the woodlands and planting them on the small plot of land around his home. As a grown man with a family, he continued planting trees and adding new plants to his forest. Margarito’s Forest is a story of Maya culture and wisdom passed from one generation to the next. It is a celebration of Margarito’s forest and its preservation.

The illustrations for the story are by Allison Havens. She has read the story to the children of Sak Ja and took them to the forest where she asked them to draw pictures for the story. She then collaged these drawings, along with her original drawings, photographs, and Guatemalan textiles to create the illustrations for the book.

What We Need & What You Get

Help us share this powerful story of  Maya culture and wisdom passed from one generation to the next and the incredible preservation of Margarito's forest. While the book's author, Andy Carter has been self-funding this project up until now, we need your help in distributing this book to school children in Guatemala. The first edition of the book will be in Spanish and K'iche' with English captions for the illustrations. We want to print 500 copies to donate to schools and organizations in the Western Highlands of Guatemala.

Any contributions in any amount are welcome and will help with the distribution of the book. But for each $100 donation, we'll send you a signed first edition copy of Margarito’s Forest.

    The Impact

    We will donate copies of Margarito’s Forest to the children of Sak Ja and their school, but we also believe that this powerful story would be enjoyed by children in other K'iche' communities in Guatemala.

    Unlike in the US, books in Guatemala are not easily accessible for rural children. They are expensive to buy and there are not many libraries near rural communities. In addition, there are even fewer books available in indigenous languages. Often, the only language rural children know aside from a bit of spanish that they learn in school, is an indigenous language such as K'iche'.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Even if you personally are not able to contribute, please help us spread the word about our fundraising campaign! If you have Facebook or Twitter, please share the link with your friends. If you have email, please send a short email to your friends suggesting a donation for the holidays. We appreciate the support!

    More details about Margarito's Forest 

    Margarito’s Forest is set in Saq Ja’, a small, remote village in the mountains of central Guatemala. Saq Ja’ was settled early in the twentieth century by indigenous Maya communities who left the highland plains because of deforestation and overcrowding. For many decades the families that settled in Saq Ja’ grew and prospered in their fertile mountain village. And it was there that Margarito Esteban Álvarez Velázquez—Don Margarito—was born on October 18, 1931.

    The peaceful existence of the families in Saq Ja’ began to crumble in 1954, when a military coup overthrew Jacobo Árbenz Guzmán, the democratically elected president of Guatemala. The overthrow led to a series of military dictators and a long dirty war, which included genocide of the Maya. In a series of assaults between 1981 and 1982, the village of Saq Ja’ was destroyed by the Guatemalan military. Many villagers died in the attacks, while others joined the political resistance, fled into the mountains, or went to refugee camps in Central America. Among those who went into hiding in the mountains was María Guadalupe, the daughter of Don Margarito, and among those who fled Guatemala was Virgilio Vicente. In response to this humanitarian crisis, the Sanctuary Movement was formed in the 1980s to welcome Central American refugees into the United States. In 1986 Don Virgilio was taken into sanctuary at University Church in Chicago, Illinois.

    After the signing of the Guatemalan Peace Accords in 1996, some of those displaced by the war began to return to their ancestral lands. Indigenous-led organizations like Guatemalan Christian Action (ACG) were particularly helpful to displaced Guatemalans as they sought to retain their cultural identity and rebuild their devastated homes. In 1998, accompanied by Garry Sparks from ACG and Dan Dale from University Church, Don Virgilio returned to participate in the rebuilding of Saq Ja’ . With that pilgrimage and Don Virgilio’s wise leadership, a partnership was established between the people of Saq Ja’ and members of University Church. Almost every year since that initial trip in 1998, a delegation from University Church has returned to Saq Ja’.

    In April of 2007 I made my first trip to Guatemala as a member of the University Church delegation. On our last day In Saq Ja’, Don Virgilio took the delegation on a tour of various projects in the community. It was a hot day and so he took us to a cool, densely forested part of the mountain to sit and talk. At that time I was struck by the stark contrast between the lush old-growth forest where we sat, and the fields and scrub brush that surrounded it. I asked Don Virgilio if he knew anything about the forest. He told me that Margarito, a man with a peculiar love of trees, had planted the forest. He added that although Margarito was killed during the war, his daughter, María Guadalupe, was now living here and tending his forest. With this intriguing introduction, and a series of interviews with María Guadalupe, the development of Margarito’s Forest was set into motion.

    During the war years María Guadalupe lost most of her family. She and her two young children survived by hiding in the mountains of Guatemala. Following the Peace Accords, María Guadalupe returned to Saq Ja’, where she has continued Don Margarito’s legacy of community leadership. She is a village midwife and serves on three of Saq Ja's committees: the Women's Committee, the Education Commission, and the Central Committee. In addition, she is a member of the National Committee on Reparations set up in 2005 after the end of the civil war.

    This book, the story of Don Margarito and his forest as told by his daughter María Guadalupe, resulted from the partnership Don Virgilio forged between Saq Ja’ and University Church. It is a story of Maya culture and wisdom passed from one generation to the next. It is a celebration of Margarito’s forest and its preservation.

story:
Keep the SNOWstorm going! 


Two years ago, when an historic invasion of snowy owls flooded eastern North America, a group of scientists, raptor banders, wildlife veterinarians and pathologists created Project SNOWstorm.

Our goal was -- and remains -- to study the winter ecology of these huge, ghostly raptors when they "irrupt" south of the Arctic. By understanding how they live and what they need, we can better know how to preserve snowy owls in the future. Although the irruptions are part of a natural cycle, scientists believe that these owls -- which nest at the very highest latitudes in the northern hemisphere -- are among the handful of species at greatest and most immediate risk from climate change.

The heart of our research is incredible new technology that allows us to track snowy owl behavior with an unprecedented level of detail -- GPS/GSM transmitters that let us follow the birds with astounding, 3D precision, around the clock and for years at a time.

The Indiegogo community has made this research possible by underwriting the expensive transmitters, which account for the largest portion of our expenses. Project SNOWstorm supporters have also underwritten the cost of laboratory tests for heavy metals, rodent poisons and other environmental toxins; the analysis of chemical isotopes in feathers, blood and tissue that tell us where in the Arctic the owl came from, and what it's been eating; and necropsies on owls that are found dead to understand the threats they face while down here with us.

Since that first winter, Project SNOWstorm has grown into a collaboration of more than 40 scientists and specialists, and dozens of organizations and agencies. But every penny we raise still goes straight into the research -- none of the team members draws a salary or a stipend. We are all volunteers.

In the past two years, we've unlocked many secrets about how these mysterious birds live, and confirmed quantitatively many things researchers had long suspected about their behavior, movement and ecology.

But we're not content to sit on our laurels. We're ready to take Project SNOWstorm to a new level -- with your help. The Indiegogo community remains our most important group of supporters.

This winter, we're deploying a new generation of GPS trackers that provide additional layers of data with no extra weight or expense -- like temperature sensors that give us information about the weather, or miniature tri-axial accelerometers that constantly record changes in a tagged owl's movement and even its posture, and allow us to study its hunting behavior, daily activity and energy expenditures.

Because preliminary tests suggest that mercury contamination is a significant problem for snowy owls, we're preparing to conduct extensive (and expensive) laboratory analysis of samples from hundreds of owls to determine the extent of this toxin in their systems, and how exposure varies geographically, between adults and juveniles, and from both the Arctic breeding grounds and the more southerly wintering areas.

Your support will also allow us to bring a Ph.D. student into the project, through our partners at the University of Saskatchewan -- someone whose dissertation research will focus on the complex movement ecology of our dozens of tagged owls.

Project SNOWstorm is possible because of you. If you're a past supporter, thank you, and please consider renewing your support. If you're new to our work, please consider a tax-deductible gift that will help better understand -- and preserve -- this remarkable species.

What We Need

We've set a goal for this winter of $25,000 -- a jump from last year. We're not doing this lightly.

The funding goes primarily to purchase the GPS/GSM transmitters we use. Even with a significant discount from the manufacturer, Cellular Tracking Technologies (something CTT has provided since the beginning) the transmitters cost roughly $3,000 each. We expect to tag an additional 8-10 owls this winter, and your support will help make that possible.

We're also committed to providing critical initial bridge funding to bring a Ph.D. student to our partner, the University of Saskatchewan, where the student will focus their doctoral research on analyzing our extraordinarily rich trove of snowy owl telemetry data -- the most detailed dataset of this species' movements ever assembled.  

And your support will allow us to continue the important laboratory work that is teasing out the environmental toxins like mercury, rodenticides, DDE and other chemicals that pose an increasingly significant risk to snowy owls and other raptors.

Bucket of Lemmings

Get (5) Project SNOWstorm stickers to show your support for the cause! Select this perk (while it lasts) and we will send out the stickers as soon as we can! These awesome stickers sport the Project SNOWstorm logo (thanks PRBYapparel.com!) and measure 2" x 5", perfect to stick anywhere to show your support.


Put an OWL on it!

We finally have our very own Burly Bird SNOWY OWL sticker! These fantastic 5"x5" round stickers feature a snowy owl on a dark background and are a unique reminder of the beauty of these owls and the importance of this project. Support us at this level and we will send you (1) Burly Bird Snowy Owl sticker and (5) 2"x5" Project SNOWstorm stickers. Created by burlybird.com



Edible Owls

In 2014, we tagged a snowy owl in Pennsylvania Dutch farm country with the help of the Burkholder family -- and when we were done banding we were served snowy owl cookies, made and decorated by Edith Burkholder with a cookie-cutter made by her husband, Mose. Now the Burkholders are providing a limited number of Mose's handmade cookie-cutters, which come with Edith's secret ginger cookie recipe and directions for decorating your own special snowy owl confections.


Feathered Facts

SNOWstorm cofounder Scott Weidensaul is also a Pulitzer Prize finalist, and generous donors at this level will receive a personalized, first-edition copy of his new book, Peterson Reference Guide to Owls of North America and the Caribbean. This latest addition to the prestigious Peterson Field Guide series covers 39 species of owls -- including the snowy, of course!


Unreal Snowy Owl

Unreal Birds has once again donated a small number of their incredible, felt-plush snowy owls, which we're offering on a special first-come, first-served basis. The Unreal owls went FAST last year, so get them while they last...these owls are amazing!
 

 

Happy Hedwig

Northside Jim, a snowy owl aficionado and superb photographer, has been a SNOWstorm supporter for a while. Thanks to his generosity, anyone donating at this level -- which fully funds a transmitter -- will receive a stunning, 30-by-40-inch signed canvas print of one of Jim's best snowy owl images, with a retail value of $2,000. Funders selecting this perk will get to pick from a section of Northside Jim's images. The finely textured canvas is hand stretched around a wood frame and sits two inches off the wall. Below is a sample of one of his spectacular images.


Hoo's our Sugar Owl? You!

A special donor at this level can help ensure that we conduct the rigorous research necessary to understand important aspects of snowy owl ecology, including DNA and isotope analyses and our important work on understanding how mercury contamination may be effecting the health, behavior and reproduction of snowy owls. This information has implications across the snowy owl's range. This supporter will receive all of the perks above, and their choice of two of Northside Jim's stunning owl canvases.


Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe you love snowy owls, but can't spare the cash. Maybe you've been a generous supporter of Project SNOWstorm in the past (if so, thank you very much!). There are still lots of other ways you can help us, though, by spreading the word and generating excitement for our campaign.

    • Share our campaign with your friends using the links beside the video at the top of the campaign.
    • Like us on Facebook!
    • Share our updates with your friends and family.
    • Follow along on our blog!
    • Sign up for our mailing list!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
VIOLON ET CHAMPIGNON : QUI SOMMES-NOUS ?

Nous sommes Violon et champignon, une entreprise œuvrant dans la production de champignons comestibles, de mycélium (semences de champignons) et de formations reliées au développement durable de cette culture, de l’aquaponie, de la polyculture et de la permaculture. Nous avons créé cette entreprise afin de promouvoir l’alimentation locale et la production d’aliments frais auprès de la communauté. Nous souhaitons aussi démocratiser la production de champignons en la rendant plus accessible, notamment en partageant nos connaissances.

De plus, en période estivale, nous vous offrons divers champignons frais et séchés au marché de Val-David, dans les Laurentides, afin de faire découvrir nos produits et les avantages de la production locale. Finalement, nous effectuons aussi des démonstrations de nouvelles méthodes de productions alimentaires circulaires qui facilitent une transition vers un mode de vie axé sur un équilibre plus naturel où le déchet de l’un devient la ressource de l’autre.

Ce qui nous tient à cœur, c’est de développer de nouvelles façons de faire avec une rigueur scientifique. Celles-ci démontrent la faisabilité de s’auto-alimenter à partir de techniques éprouvées sous notre climat nordique et, par la suite, de les communiquer.


POURQUOI UNE CAMPAGNE DE SOCIO-FINANCEMENT?

Nous avons besoin de votre aide! En effet, en plus de nos productions très fertiles, nous cultivons un terreau propice aux idées toujours plus créatives les unes que les autres dont Vincent Leblanc est l'initiateur, soutenu par ses collaborateurs. 

C’est là que vous entrez en scène. Avec votre appui, nous serions en mesure de développer les projets suivants :

1) Finaliser l'installation d'un foyer à combustion lente : Le foyer à combustion lente nous permettra, en cas de panne d'électricité, de sauver nos différents organismes vivants (champignons, spiruline, poissons, etc.). Il contribue également à une meilleure résilience.

2) Automatisation du système d’ouverture de la serre et du système d’exploitation : La serre demande énormément d’ajustements journaliers pour contrôler la température et les différents paramètres de culture. En ce sens, nous voulons automatiser le système pour libérer du temps et se consacrer à d’autres développements.

3) L’installation de panneaux solaires : Cet ajout nous permettra de produire et de consommer une partie de notre propre énergie. Cela aura pour effet d’augmenter notre indépendance dans ce domaine. 

4) Recherches et développements : Jamais à court d’idées, nous souhaitons développer de nouvelles avenues comme l’installation de chauffage au compost et d'écosystèmes alimentaires (avec l’utilisation d’écrevisses, la conception de polyculture, etc.) ainsi que la culture de spiruline (algue)... Nous avons aussi un volet de recherche et développement sur la culture des champignons en lien avec notre socio-financement. Visitez notre site internet pour plus d'informations. 


En quoi votre participation fera la différence?

Violon et Champignon sollicite votre aide pour ce socio-financement afin de cultiver de nouvelles avenues. En effet, celui-ci nous donnerait le coup de main nécessaire pour l’expansion de l'entreprise et nous permettrait de continuer à oeuvrer dans ce domaine qui nous passionne. 

Nous favorisons le partage d’informations. Nos formations, auxquelles vous pouvez participer, sont des condensés de nos études, de nos découvertes et de nos tentatives. Chaque dollar investi dans notre campagne vous revient au travers des outils que nous développons et que nous partageons par le biais de notre site internet, de nos réseaux sociaux. 

Au final, plus nous développons d’idées, plus vous êtes gagnants!
story_txt:
VIOLON ET CHAMPIGNON : QUI SOMMES-NOUS ?

Nous sommes Violon et champignon, une entreprise œuvrant dans la production de champignons comestibles, de mycélium (semences de champignons) et de formations reliées au développement durable de cette culture, de l’aquaponie, de la polyculture et de la permaculture. Nous avons créé cette entreprise afin de promouvoir l’alimentation locale et la production d’aliments frais auprès de la communauté. Nous souhaitons aussi démocratiser la production de champignons en la rendant plus accessible, notamment en partageant nos connaissances.


De plus, en période estivale, nous vous offrons divers champignons frais et séchés au marché de Val-David, dans les Laurentides, afin de faire découvrir nos produits et les avantages de la production locale. Finalement, nous effectuons aussi des démonstrations de nouvelles méthodes de productions alimentaires circulaires qui facilitent une transition vers un mode de vie axé sur un équilibre plus naturel où le déchet de l’un devient la ressource de l’autre.
Ce qui nous tient à cœur, c’est de développer de nouvelles façons de faire avec une rigueur scientifique. Celles-ci démontrent la faisabilité de s’auto-alimenter à partir de techniques éprouvées sous notre climat nordique et, par la suite, de les communiquer.

POURQUOI UNE CAMPAGNE DE SOCIO-FINANCEMENT?
Nous avons besoin de votre aide! En effet, en plus de nos productions très fertiles, nous cultivons un terreau propice aux idées toujours plus créatives les unes que les autres dont Vincent Leblanc est l'initiateur, soutenu par ses collaborateurs. 
C’est là que vous entrez en scène. Avec votre appui, nous serions en mesure de développer les projets suivants : 
1) Finaliser l'installation d'un foyer à combustion lente : Le foyer à combustion lente nous permettra, en cas de panne d'électricité, de sauver nos différents organismes vivants (champignons, spiruline, poissons, etc.). Il contribue également à une meilleure résilience.

2) Automatisation du système d’ouverture de la serre et du système d’exploitation : La serre demande énormément d’ajustements journaliers pour contrôler la température et les différents paramètres de culture. En ce sens, nous voulons automatiser le système pour libérer du temps et se consacrer à d’autres développements.
3) L’installation de panneaux solaires : Cet ajout nous permettra de produire et de consommer une partie de notre propre énergie. Cela aura pour effet d’augmenter notre indépendance dans ce domaine. 
4) Recherches et développements : Jamais à court d’idées, nous souhaitons développer de nouvelles avenues comme l’installation de chauffage au compost et d'écosystèmes alimentaires (avec l’utilisation d’écrevisses, la conception de polyculture, etc.) ainsi que la culture de spiruline (algue)... Nous avons aussi un volet de recherche et développement sur la culture des champignons en lien avec notre socio-financement. Visitez notre site internet pour plus d'informations. 


En quoi votre participation fera la différence?
Violon et Champignon sollicite votre aide pour ce socio-financement afin de cultiver de nouvelles avenues. En effet, celui-ci nous donnerait le coup de main nécessaire pour l’expansion de l'entreprise et nous permettrait de continuer à oeuvrer dans ce domaine qui nous passionne. 
Nous favorisons le partage d’informations. Nos formations, auxquelles vous pouvez participer, sont des condensés de nos études, de nos découvertes et de nos tentatives. Chaque dollar investi dans notre campagne vous revient au travers des outils que nous développons et que nous partageons par le biais de notre site internet, de nos réseaux sociaux. 
Au final, plus nous développons d’idées, plus vous êtes gagnants!

story:
About the Project

The Kitsap Forest & Bay Project is a visionary effort to conserve nearly 7,000 acres of forest and shoreline on Puget Sound. This land was once a hub of Washington State’s timber industry.  With the former lumber mill gone, the landowner has provided the community with a tremendous opportunity to conserve the land and trails for all time.  With your help, we can conserve this beautiful place and all of the wonderful outdoor recreation it supports.


In 2014 donors like you helped raise funds to purchase the first 500 acres of forest and beach on Port Gamble Bay, preserving the property's rich ecosystems and well-loved nature trails.  We then purchased a nearly 400-acre expansion to North Kitsap Heritage Park.

Now, with your help, we can protect 270 more acres in the heart of our project.  Grovers Creek Preserve is the jewel at the center of the Kitsap Forest and Bay Project – a place of old growth trees and a vital link in the Sound to Olympics Trail.

We’ve raised more than $1.8 million toward this purchase.  Now we need YOUR help to raise the last $25,000 in the next 18 days! Any funds raised beyond our goal will help purchase additional land in the Kitsap Forest & Bay Project.


Our Opportunity to Save a SPECIAL Place

Kitsap Forest & Bay lands and waters have been at the cultural heart of local tribes for eons–providing sustenance for families and enriching tribal traditions that continue to this day.  They draw thousands of outdoor recreationists annually–strengthening the local economy and promoting healthy lifestyles.  These waters support fish and wildlife that are critical to a healthy Puget Sound.

This land was a hub of the Puget Sound timber industry for a century and a half. With the former lumber mill gone and an uncertain future for its timberlands, the landowner has provided the community with a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to conserve the land for all time.

One Step at a Time
Due to Kitsap Forest & Bay Project's immense size, the Coalition is tackling land acquisition in phases.  With your help, we completed the first phase–saving the Port Gamble Bay Shoreline.  With that accomplished, we went on to Phase II–adding nearly 400 acres to expand North Kitsap Heritage Park.  Now, with your help we will accomplish Phase III–saving Grovers Creek Preserve!


Saving the Land and Trails
Phase III: Grovers Creek Preserve

Explore the Grovers Creek landscape and you'll find a rare grove of 200-year-old Sitka spruce, hemlock, cedar, Douglas fir and grand fir.  You'll also find a peat bog that gives spring to your step as you cross its hummocks and skirt its pools.  You'll cross Grovers Creek on a fallen log and marvel at the handiwork of beavers.  These diverse habitats support over 60 bird species and host threatened steelhead as well as coho and cutthroat trout.

Grovers Creek Preserve is at the center of a forest corridor of nearly 1,700 acres spanning the Kitsap Peninsula.  To the east lies North Kitsap Heritage Park.  The land to the west is proposed to be protected as the North Kitsap Community Forest.  Farther west, the Kitsap Forest & Bay Coalition is working to conserve the Port Gamble Forest's trails and wildlife habitat.  Together, these properties will conserve a significant open space corridor and protect land critical to a future Sound to Olympics Trail.

A regional trail like the Burke-Gilman Trail and Olympic Discovery Trail, the Sound to Olympics Trail will connect to regional trails on the east side of Puget Sound via the Seattle-Bainbridge and the Edmonds-Kingston ferries, and west to the Olympic Peninsula via the Hood Canal Bridge. Construction of the first link in the Sound to Olympics Trail is scheduled to begin this year.  A key element of the Sound to Olympics Trail vision is protection of lands like Grovers Creek Preserve.

Protected for all time, the Preserve will provide a place for families to explore these natural wonders on foot and bicycle.  YOUR help is needed TODAY to raise the last $25,000!


Kitsap Forest & Bay Coalition

Our dedicated coalition represents an unprecedented partnership between state, local, tribal, environmental, and recreational organizations.  Coalition partners include: Kitsap County, Port Gamble S’Klallam Tribe, Suquamish Tribe, Forterra, Great Peninsula Conservancy, Kitsap Audubon Society, North Kitsap Trails Association, Evergreen Mountain Bike Alliance–West Sound, Kitsap Economic Development Alliance, Visit Kitsap Peninsula, local and state agencies, and other community partners.  Passionate in their love for the land, these groups have been working for years to secure their vibrant future.

Why YOU Can Make a Difference

Just $25,000 separates us from our goal of conserving Grovers Creek Preserve forever!  By making a donation today, you can be part of conserving this beautiful place and all the wonderful outdoor recreation it supports.  Please make a donation today!

Video credits: John F. Williams, Steve Stolee, Larry Tice, Evergreen Mountain Bike Alliance–West Sound Chapter; photos by Joe Walsh; audio of Winter Wren courtesy of Richard Webster via xeno-canto

story:
Story

Did you know pollinators are responsible for one out of every three bites of food we eat? Unfortunately, like managed honey bees, many of our wild native bee species are suffering alarming population declines. But with Wild Bee ID, you don’t have to be an expert entomologist to learn about these incredible species, and to be a part of the solution!

Center for Food Safety is working to develop an innovative mobile app called Wild Bee ID that is designed to educate and inspire users about our thousands of species of native bees and what we can all do in our own backyards to help conserve these essential pollinators. The app is easy to navigate, visually engaging, and highly informative, making it the ideal tool for students, home gardeners, and bee-enthusiasts of all ages.

By donating to our campaign, you’re not only joining a team protecting our bees, our environment, and our food supply, but you are also helping us build a fun and educational resource that will be free to use – inspiring a whole new community of pollinator-protection advocates. We know this app will be an invaluable tool for teachers, students, gardeners, and bee enthusiasts of all ages – help us make our vision for this app a reality!

 

The Specifics

Wild Bee ID will be your go-to wild bee ID app and pollinator-friendly planting guide. The app has high-resolution images of native bees and the flowers they visit; background on the different lifecycles, anatomy, and nesting requirements for different bee species; and concrete steps you can take to help protect pollinators.

Did you know that bumblebees can buzz-pollinate garden favorites, like tomatoes and blueberries – something even the notorious honey bee isn’t equipped to do? Have you ever wondered if different bee species have preferences when it comes to flowering plants (hint – they do)? The Wild Bee ID app encourages users to get outside in the garden and observe first-hand how wild bees help bring our favorite foods to the table.

 

What We’ve Done

  1. Users use the app to identify different species of wild bees.
  2. Search for species of native bees and their associated plant habitats/forage preferences.
  3. Learn how to create a successful bee-friendly garden.
  4. Explore our comprehensive guides and learn about bee lifecycles, nesting requirements, anatomy and much, much more.
  5. Use the app’s resources to educate your family and friends and keep the buzz going!

The app will also offer dozens of pages of background and educational material on native bees, organized into multiple “guides.” The guides will include detailed information on the role of native bees in their natural ecosystems and food webs, the ecology and life cycles of native bees, how to create a successful bee-friendly garden, and how to recognize the native bees that will visit these gardens. For the more advanced student, the guides include sections on bee anatomy; how to distinguish bees from flies and wasps; and a table of common North American bee families, sub-families, tribes, and genera.

 

Meet Our Team

Center for Food Safety (CFS) is a national nonprofit environmental advocacy group that empowers people, supports farmers, and protects the earth from harmful food production technologies. We work to advance organic and other sustainable forms of agriculture. One of our longstanding programs has been to protect pollinators from toxic pesticides used in our agriculture practices.

As an established leader in the food movement at the forefront of the fight to protect pollinators, CFS is well equipped to spearhead native bee educational opportunities through both the Wild Bee ID app and our existing pollinator education program. CFS staff members have the experience and knowledge to develop materials that will be instructive, creative, and effective in cultivating a new generation of pollinator protectors and sustainable food advocates.

*All donations to Center for Food Safety are tax-deductible, minus the value of any gifts.

 

Timeline

June – Fundraising

July/August – App Development and Internal Testing

September/October – Public release

 

Click Here to Learn More About Seggiano Honey

story:
Anda-Andalucía! (Abajo en Español)

You are about to help plant a forest...

                                            We know it's possible!

We (David and Celia) arrived in the Alpujarras in Andalucía, Spain, 7 years ago without having a clue how to plant a lettuce. After 7 years living in the mountains, studying and practicing the principles of permaculture we now wish to put in to practice what we've learnt and make a positive impact. 

In a nutshell, we are looking to re-forest a barren and depleted piece of land with fruit and nut trees. We’d like to do this in a sustainable way which benefits not only people but animals and the local environment in general. With your help this will happen in the blink of an eye.  Within a relatively short space of time a small sustainable ecosystem will emerge which can look after itself to a great extent and be here for future generations. Many of the plant/tree species selected will, once estabslished, work off rain water alone. The forest will be a perennial food source for people, a wild-life habitat, a soil creation system, and a place of beauty. 

You will be part of it, as we will keep you up to date with images and news as the process unfolds, and perhaps you'd even like to come and visit this little paradise, re-charge your batteries, and taste the fruits for yourself.

What We Need  

With your contribution we can aquire the following things which will help make this dream a reality:

·  Water storage pool

·  Chicken tractor + chickens (mobile structure moved around the land for soil conditioning, paving the way for the sowing of cover crops)

·  Compost / manure

·  Seeds for soil enriching cover crops (nitrogen fixing species such as clover, alfalfa and the pea/bean family.)

·  Excavator

·  Irrigation tubes + fittings

·  Fencing

·  Garden tools

·  Shrubs / young trees (including many leguminious soil enriching varieties)

Our goal above all is to give something back to the land. Soil repair and ever increasing fertility are paramount.

As you check our website www.organicenglish.es, which includes testimonials of those who have stayed with us in the past, you will discover more about us and our commitment. We welcome people to work on our project through www.workaway.com,  

Other Ways You Can Help

The best way to help us is...:

  • Donate: a monetary donation to help us raise the funds to make this happen.
  • Share this project with all the people you know (Use the Indiegogo share tools!)
  • Forward the information we send about the project.
  • Contact us if you know of any group of people or organisation that might be interested in supporting us.
  • Come and work with us... 

 

Anda-Andalucía! (EN ESPAÑOL)

¿Alguna vez soñaste que co-crearías un bosque?

                                            ¡Sabemos que es posible!

Cuando llegamos a las Alpujarras no sabíamos ni plantar una lechuga.  Después de 7 años viviendo en las montañas, estudiando y practicando los principios de la permacultura queremos poner en práctica lo que hemos aprendido y crear un impacto positivo.

Resumiendo, queremos reforestar un terreno estéril y empobrecido y convertirlo en un vergel. Con tu ayuda podemos hacerlo de manera sostenible de forma que beneficie no solo a gente y animals, sino también al medioambiente local. Con tu donación puede ocurrir en un abrir y cerrar de ojos. En un espacio de tiempo relativamente breve surgirá un ecosistema sostenible que puede cuidar de sí mismo y permacer como regalo para las generaciones futures. Será una fuente continua de comida para la gente, un habitat para la vida salvaje, un sistema de creación de tierra, y un lugar muy bello.

Serás parte de ello, porque te mantendremos informado con imágenes y noticias según se vaya desarrollando el proceso. Incluso a lo mejor deseas visitor este pequeño paraíso, recargar las pilas y saborear la fruta de primera mano.

Necesitamos…

Algunas cosas para comenzar este proyecto…

  • Alberca y sistema de riego
  • Gallinero móvil y pollos
  • Compost / abono
  • Semillas para enriquecer el suelo y cubrirlo
  • Excavadora
  •  Ballas
  • Herramientas
  • Árboles y arbustos

También nos puedes ayudar si…

  • Donas: si lo haces, es mejor al principio de la campaña, ¡dona ahora!
  • Compartes este proyecto con toda la gente a la que conoces
  • Re-enviasla información que te enviamos del proyecto
  • Nos contactas si conoces a algún grupo de personas u organización que pueda estar interesado en apoyarnos
  • Vienes a trabajar con nosotros

(EN ESPAÑOL)¿Alguna vez soñaste que co-crearías un bosque?                                            ¡Sabemos que es posible!Cuando llegamos a las Alpujarras no sabíamos ni plantar una lechuga.  Después de 7 años viviendo en las montañas, estudiando y practicando los principios de la permacultura queremos poner en práctica lo que hemos aprendido y crear un impacto positivo.Resumiendo, queremos reforestar un terreno estéril y empobrecido y convertirlo en un vergel. Con tu ayuda podemos hacerlo de manera sostenible de forma que beneficie no solo a gente y animals, sino también al medioambiente local. Con tu donación puede ocurrir en un abrir y cerrar de ojos. En un espacio de tiempo relativamente breve surgirá un ecosistema sostenible que puede cuidar de sí mismo y permacer como regalo para las generaciones futures. Será una fuente continua de comida para la gente, un habitat para la vida salvaje, un sistema de creación de tierra, y un lugar muy bello.Serás parte de ello, porque te mantendremos informado con imágenes y noticias según se vaya desarrollando el proceso. Incluso a lo mejor deseas visitor este pequeño paraíso, recargar las pilas y saborear la fruta de primera mano.Necesitamos…Algunas cosas para comenzar este proyecto…
Alberca y sistema de riego
Gallinero móvil y pollos
Compost / abono
Semillas para enriquecer el suelo y cubrirlo
Excavadora
 Ballas
Herramientas
Árboles y arbustos
También nos puedes ayudar si…

Donas: si lo haces, es mejor al principio de la campaña, ¡dona ahora!

Compartes este proyecto con toda la gente a la que conoces

Re-enviasla información que te enviamos del proyecto

Nos contactas si conoces a algún grupo de personas u organización que pueda estar interesado en apoyarnos
Vienes a trabajar con nosotros

story:
SOLAR ENERGY needs to be on our emergency services. Sunlight is free electricity that reduces or eliminates our power bills and therefore our taxes.  Solar panels are warranted for twenty five years and as dependable as sunrise. There is no downside to solar. Strengthens our civil defense and security in times of national Disasters. Climate change is a real problem that only grows worse by the years, see the documentary Inconvenient Truth ziipp.eu/?u=http://www.youtube . Increasing solar usage helps to promote the solution to the general public and is good advertising for installers.

            The latest science on solar flares says that just one of these directly hitting the earth can overload the power grids of the planet. Destroying transformers, generators, and high voltage power lines. See youtube video from discovery The Sun in HD www.youtube .  Solar panels are low voltage, decentralized, and easier to protect so they should survive most of that sort of damage. Your donations will pay for our corporate charter and tax filing with the IRS. GoSolarASAP.org is going to be a social welfare organization non-profit 501 (c 4) foundation helping this country to persevere. We raise funds to help provide solar energy panels for emergency services. Fire departments, hospitals,and police stations should have a long term power source uninterruptable from war, EMPS, CMES, grid failure, and severe weather. Today's world demands energy for essential services and solar energy is the perfect locally produced power for years and decades. Diesel backup generators don't have that capability.

               The more electricity from rooftops the stronger this country is in national emergencies. Nothing is more reliable than the sun for clean free power. This also strengthens the grid by increasing power production during peak daylight hours. My name is Leo Trollope founder of GoSolarASAP.org www.youtube  and can be found on twitter. I have a corporate attorney located in ashland city and an accountant ready for critically important work for our civil society.

story:
California Ecorun® is an eco-friendly race circuit of coastline courses that fund local green projects. Student projects from all levels of education will be featured in a Sustainability Fair after each race. This will provide a cross-sectional platform for runners, students, NGOs, green companies, and environmentalists to help local communities meet their goals and make dreams of a brighter future a reality. These races will be hosted in California’s most beautiful state parks and aim to have a zero carbon footprint. Our mission is to be a positive influence in the race industry by becoming one the largest eco-friendly races in the country.



PARTNERS

Schools

We are partnering with local student governments and schools to create collaborative projects help cities meet sustainability goals faster.

Non-Profit Organizations

We want to help green NGO's gain traction for current campaigns and provide exposure to cutting edge projects via our Sustainability Fair. 

State Parks

California State Parks and California EcoRun are teaming up to focus on park restoration and conservation campaigns. We hope to generate revenue to help offset staffing costs and make our coastline parks as beautiful as possible. 

Green Companies

We invite green companies and ethical entrepreneurs to promote their brands and connect with passionate interns, runners, students, and environmentalists. This provides a great opportunity for business-to-business networking and exposure.

story:
The Team

Tampa Deep-Sea X-plorers LLC was formed as a legal entity in the state of Florida with the intention of competing for the XPRIZE. We are currently recruiting talented technicians and engineers who are interested in participating in the contest. We have a particular need for expertise in the areas of mechanical engineering, computer programming, robotics, marketing, web design, and business. The overall team will consist of 10 – 30 individuals across multiple disciplines. The team will be subdivided into smaller teams to concentrate on specific components that will be incorporated into the larger project. We will be building our robots out of recycled scuba tanks and other recycled materials.

If you would like to participate as a team member please email elarson@tampadeepsea.com

Update: 09/01/16 We have added 4 team members from the Tampa Hackerspace. Two are programming experts, one is a digital video expert, and the other has experience with 3D printing and design.

Update: 09/08/16 We have obtained materials for the design and construction of a pressure vessel capable of withstanding 2000 meters of seawater.

Update: 09/12/16 We have paid our registration fee for the XPRIZE! We are all in at this point.

Update: Preliminary designs are complete and we are building prototype.

What We Need:

We are currently in the registration phase of the competition. We will need to pay a non-refundable fee of 5,000 dollars to become an officially registered team. The registration deadline is September 30, 2016. We are also exploring the possibility of partnering with a local university as a student project. The student project will cost 25,000 dollars. These are the two largest expenses that the project faces at this point in the contest. We are seeking 30,000 dollars to cover registration of the team and to pay for the student project. Any additional funds will be used to defray the cost of the website, marketing and recruiting efforts, and to buy necessary equipment.

The Impact

Your contribution is crucial at this stage in the competition, without it we cannot hope to compete in the overall contest. Once we are registered, we can approach angel investors, corporations, and interested investors to help us to raise the capital necessary to develop and build the 250 - 300 autonomous underwater vehicles and surface equipment necessary to field a successful challenge.

Risks & Challenges

Aside from fundraising our current challenges include:

  • recruiting the necessary talent to compete
  • development of a pressure vessel capable of withstanding the pressure
  • manufacturing 300 AUVs
  • programming
  • processing the necessary data

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot make a monetary contribution there are ways that you can help. Please share this site with your network. Visit our website at www.tampadeepsea.com to stay informed about the progress of the team. Join the Tampa Deep-Sea group on facebook. If you or someone you know is interested in becoming a member of the team, please email elarson@tampadeepsea.com.

Thank you for your interest in our project.

story:
B&B Aboard was started over a year ago in Clearwater, Florida with the simple idea that travelers might enjoy staying on the water just as much as we do! We were right, since opening we now have 2 boats and are booked to capacity almost every day.


The floating tourism industry is rapidly growing and we are firm believers that with the industries growing popularity, we need to take the same steps to reduce our environmental impact. But we are a small operation and can't do it alone. That is why we are starting this campaign. With your help we hope to first take ourselves off the grid with self sustaining energy while offering you some great perks in return. 



As travel enthusiasts, lifelong boaters, sailors and entrepreneurs we have lived or visited most of the far reaching corners of the world.  In those journeys we learned just how easy it can be to get our power from the sun, wind and water as well as harvest fresh water from the sea. Unfortunately we also learned how under utilized those resources are. We've witnessed, first hand, the effects of pollution and environmental disregard. Since then we have made a conscious effort to make decisions that help the environment instead of hurting it. 


Eco tourism is becoming more and more popular especially in under developed countries. We want to show that not only can we continue to make our floating B&B more Eco-friendly but also prove that Eco tourism is a viable option on the water in the United States.

Once the initiative is funded and completed you will be able to soak in our hot tubs, take that long hot shower, sit outside at night under the blue glow of LED lights, enjoy the breeze while watching an outdoor movie, or crank up your room's AC all without negatively impacting the environment because now the sun and wind are providing the whole business with that energy!


These boats have both been a work of love from the start.  Laid Back was purchased from a family that had used it with three generations, but had just left it sit for almost a decade.  We brought it back from the brink with custom hand built cherry cabinetry, bamboo floors and more.


The remodel above shows left to right:  King Room 1, the kitchen, and the main living area.  Laid Back has been reborn with character!


The story of the remodel of Innfinity has a sad start as well.  After 8 years of fishing charter in the BVIs, she was brough back to Fort Myers florida and left to rot.  With 50 holes in the roof, trees growing inside, engines underwater and no mechanical system in tact.  She was basically a start from scratch, completely re-wire, re-plumb, re-floor, re-ceiling, rebuilt engines......I think you get the picture.


The remodel above shows left to right: King Room 4, the living area, and the kitchen.  Innfinity was rebuilt not only with style and character but also with A LOT of sweat!


Since the initial rebuilts, we have started taking steps to make these boats more environmentally friendly. 

We have installed sun shades that block out 90% off the sun's warming effect while still remaining see through for the guests enjoyment!


We have upgraded both vessels to very high efficiency mini split cooling systems that consume about 50% of traditional compressor based air conditioners!


We have upgraded all of the hot water systems to high efficiency instant heat technology. 


We have migrated all of the lighting to low consumption LEDs.  


We have started our own recycling program for the boats even though no marina we have ever been in with any boat has ever recycled anything!  

But we want to do more....


What we need is the materials and technology to outfit both of our boats with both solar panels and wind generators so they are COMPLETELY self-sufficient! 

Our campaign is to achieve the following:


Acquire materials and build the aluminum support structure for the solar panels.


Acquire materials and build the aluminum support structure for the wind generators.


Solar panels  along with wiring and junction boxes.



Inverters connected to battery banks capable of turning the green output into usable power.



How much is it going to cost us to do this?  Here is a breakdown of our budget:

  • Solar Panels (75 @ $350) => $26,250
  • Wind Generators (6 @ $1750) => $10,500
  • Batteries (50 @ $1500) => $75,000
  • Wire (2500ft @ $1) => $2,500
  • Connectors/JunctionBoxes  => $1500
  • Hardware => $250
  • Aluminum Solar Support Structure =>$10,000
  • Aluminum Wind Support Structure (6@500) => $3,000
  • Roofing gutters/seals => $500
  • Mechanical Labor (2 weeks, 2 people) => $3200
  • Electrical Labor (2 weeks, 2 people) => $3200
  • Engineering (structures and wiring) => $4000
TOTAL:  ~$150,000

We want to get this phase done quickly so we can move on to bigger impacts in our future phases, so we have a very aggressive timeline to complete this project!


Although helping our environment is rewarding in itself, we are offering some great perks for your donations.  From the simple to the sublime, we have a perk that we think everyone can enjoy.  The bonus part about our perks is that the boats are already running, so you can enjoy your perk literally tomorrow........no big wait times, no delays.  If your timing is right, you might even get to see your donation becoming reality as we build out the equipment on the boats (quietly of course).
If you just want to help us make a difference in our power hungry world but cannot actually come and enjoy the donations:

T-shirts - Sweaters - Hoodies - Sun shirts

We are offering 4 different apparel choices that will help show your support for our cause. There is a style for every taste and climate. We chose the highest quality shirts we could find for maximum comfort and durability. 

Tax Credit For Equipment Sponsorship

Interested in making a bigger impact?  The federal government offers direct tax credits for the installation of alternative energy systems.  If you sponsor a solar panel, inverter, wind generator or battery and you get your name on it as well as all of the paperwork and instructions necessary for you to obtain that tax credit on your 2016 Federal Income taxes.  The CREDIT is approximately 30% of your total donation!

Accommodation Packages  
If you'd like to come and check out the impact of what you have helped to create with your donations, we are offering accommodation packages on either of our boats!  We are also offering all-inclusive nights, boat exclusive nights, luxury nights and luxury exclusive nights!  And the great part is you can come and use your perk as soon as this campaign is over because the boats are already open!
Innfinity - 105 foot boat with 5 bedrooms and 4 baths


Laid Back - 65 foot boat with 2 bedrooms and 1 bath

If you want more than one night, grab a couple and we can book them back to back for you too!


Below are some videos that showcase a few things that you can enjoy if you choose to grab one of these accommodation perks!  





Scott Rowles - The Mechanic

The man with the plan and the boats. The mechanical, electrical, epoxy, plumbing..... Mr. Fixitallandmakeitwork.  He has been living on boats for almost two decades and loves introducing people to his love of float life!

Kerry Rowles - The Accountant 

  • Calculator guy, well....graduated to Quickbooks.  He acts as the father figure for the company (along with actually being Scott's father).

    • Mark Miller - The Paddler 

    Our graphic designer and on board SUP specialist. He is a well traveled entrepreneur that recently moved to FL from the Midwest. He lives vicariously through himself.

    Andrea Benninger - The Local

    Our experience creator extraordinaire.  Whether it is helping to set up your perfect event spread or giving you recommendations on restaurants or teaching you how to paddle board.  Her love of the water comes through in everything she does.

    Ronan - The Dog

  • He once taught a German shepherd how to bark in Spanish.  Just kidding, but he could definitely teach you a thing or two about how to relax around the water.....he has it mastered.  Just don't fall for the puppy dog eyes!



    • Are you making a difference in our business?  Absolutely!  We will be able to provide the same level of service just in a carbon neutral footprint!  But it is not just our little footprint on the earth that we will be changing.  

    Think about it....vacation accommodations are big energy consumers.  People go on vacation and indulge.  If they normally set the air conditioner at 77 degrees at home because they have to pay the bill, they splurge when they are on vacation and run it down to a chilly 67.  And vacation locations want to make sure their guests are happy so they over light, over heat, over cool all of their amenities to make sure their guests have the best time and return to see them again! 

    If we could help to influence adoption of alternative energies at vacation accommodations.....the impact could be huge.


    We have already installed and maintained wind and solar power systems on multiple boats (Tubi and Tri-Muirin shown below), so actually getting the system up and running is just a wee bit of sweat and perseverance.  The biggest risks we face are that we will not reaching our campaign milestones and then will not be able to actually unplug from the grid.



    So, you are not able to contribute to our eco-ization of the accommodation industry, but you can help spread the word.  Please pass the word to family and friends!

    Let them know that we are willing to put in the effort and change our business to be a better world citizen!


    This is just the first phase of our Green Business Initiative!  If you help us get to this goal, we vow to come back with follow-on campaigns to continue to turn our offerings completely green!

    We also want to extend our business to help preserve and provide Eco conscious access to some of the most pristine, private and beautiful barrier islands that Florida has to offer....come with us on our journey!


    How often have you looked at vacation options in our country and wish that you could go to a "private eco resort" island in OUR country that treated the land, water and animals with respect and preserved them for the future.

    Florida undeveloped coastal land is becoming extinct.  If you have been to Florida, you have seen what development and tourism has done to Miami, Clearwater, Naples and more.  We want to help PRESERVE, but still provide "walk lightly" access to some of the last, natural islands in the Tampa Bay area!

    We have identified a multiple island location within 30 minutes of a major airport in Florida that we could acquire and turn into a eco-friendly vacation location that not only is environmentally friendly in its use, but also in how the accommodations are built up.

    Minimally invasive flora removal to locate the necessary buildings to support our boats access to the land and amenities with hand carrying and clearing to ensure we only "tread" on what we absolutely have to.....and we will keep 90% of the land in its natural condition!



    How often have you looked at vacation options in our country and wished that the owners had any idea how simple it can be to make the facility kind to nature.  Our new facility would use sustainable materials for the build.  

    We will again power it completely with solar and wind power to be a 100% sustainable location and we can get our eco-cyling going much stronger with our own landside presence!  

    We will use composting toilets so that we turn the waste that WE produce into fertilizer for the flora that we LEFT when we built the accommodations.  

    We will be fresh water neutral: we will install our own desalinization portable system running on OUR solar and wind energy to harvest fresh water for life from the sea as well as converting all of our boats with this fresh water supply!

    We will also need LPG for cooking and laundry, but we also have great options to make that need sustainable as well.  It also just so happens that we can help support our other fellow Crowdfunders.  By implementing our own gas creation system, we will also be able to create an eco-cycle for that need as well.  This gas supply will run our cooking, laundry and more on both land and our boats!(https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/homebiogas-create-your-own-energy-environment-green/x/14560409#/)

    We will have salt water swimming pools with solar powered heating and cooling that made the pool chemical free, but also energy neutral.  




    This particular area has approximately a dozen small islands that are all private and for sale.  In the future, we would like to continue our preservation with small, private,  Eco-friendly bungalows on each island connected to the very first island via an electric ferry boat that is charged by our solar arrays!!!


    We can do this, we can build the case that shows that it is feasible and viable, we can make a difference and we can lead our industry and country forward.......................................................with your help!
