story:
Project Summary

We want to begin a conservation based research project that would help with the sustainability of sharks in the waters of the Dominican Republic. Our team is comprised of scientists, conservation leaders and award winning filmmakers. Through this conservation work we will also establish research that will help us better understand the shark species in those waters.

Our project objectives would be:

  • Establish a finalized protection plan for nurseries used by sharks in the Dominican Republic.
  • Create a shark monitoring program with the locals in the areas to compile and keep data.
  • Document shark behavior through film and photo for conservation purposes.
  • Have ongoing local and international presentations about our work, our procedures and how this project is helping the locals and their economy.

What We Need & What You Get

Since we are a nonprofit, everything comes out of our own pockets and sometimes we simply cannot afford all of the costs. What the money would be used for:

  • 100% of the funding is to cover our research, meetings, awareness and education programs, and transportation to monitor the areas we are establishing as protected regions.
  • If you help fund this project you will be one in a group of a few people who can have access to our research and work before the general public does.

The Impact

There is currently no proper monitoring program in the Dominican Republic and specifically none for the nurseries that are being used by sharks, and as a result the sharks are being fished out of the waters faster than they can reproduce. This is where this project comes in:

  • Sharks are migratory species, so we need to do all that we can to better protect them and establishing a proper nursery protection and monitoring program is the first step.
  • A lot of the sharks we will be working with use most of the areas we are monitoring as nurseries - so, these areas are vital to healthy and stable shark populations hence why they need to be monitored.
  • We all need healthy shark populations in order to have healthy oceans and this project takes a very active approach to help maintain that.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign - social media is a vital tool, so please feel free to share this campaign everywhere! (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Blogs, etc...)

Thank you and we appreciate your support!



Resumen Del Proyecto

Nuestro objetivo principal es el establecimiento de un programa para la investigación de la comunidad de elasmobranquios que habitan las aguas de la Republica Dominicana. Nuestro equipo está compuesto por biólogos, ecologistas, conservacionistas y cinematógrafos. A través de este programa esperamos poder proporcionar los datos necesarios para la mejor conservación de los escualos de la isla.

Objetivos Principales del Proyecto:

·  Establecer un santuario de elasmobranquios en la Republica Dominicana.

·  Crear un programa de marcado y seguimiento de tiburones con la colaboración de las autoridades locales y la población local.


Que nos hace falta & Como puedes ayudar

Ya que somos una organización sin ánimo de lucro, el presente y futuro de nuestro programa depende de nuestra habilidad diaria de encontrar fondos. A pesar de haber podido financiar el nacimiento de este proyecto, para poder seguir expandiéndolo, necesitamos tu ayuda. Las contribuciones que recibimos son usadas para:

·  La financiación de transporte hacia y en la Republica Dominicana. Dado el carácter internacional de nuestro equipo, llegar al país isleño y desplazarnos a las zonas de conservación se convierte en uno de nuestros gastos principales.

·  La compra y uso de material para el estudio de los escualos de la isla. Todo aquel que se vea involucrado recibirá de forma exclusive todos los avances de nuestros descubrimientos sobre la comunidad de tiburones en la Republica Dominicana.

·  Otro de los gastos principales de nuestro programa tiene que ver con la vigilancia de las zonas de conservación y el seguimiento de las actividades que afectan a los elasmobranquios de la isla.


Nuestro Impacto

En la actualidad, no existes ni santuarios de tiburones, ni programas de investigación de tiburones en la Republica Dominicana. Esta falta medios para la conservación de los escualos, ha llevado a pesca de muchas especies por encima de su habilidad reproductiva. A través de nuestro proyecto esperamos alcanzar las siguientes metas:

·  Entender la ecología geo-espacial de las especies de tiburón migratorias que hacen uso de las aguas de la Republica Dominicana.

·  Evaluar y proteger las áreas de cría halladas en los manglares de la isla – estas áreas son cruciales para asegurar la continuidad de muchas especies.

·  A largo plazo, repoblar a las  especies que se han visto afectadas por la falta de regulaciones de pesca sostenibles.


Otras maneras en las que puedes ayudar

No te preocupes! Si no nos puedes ayudar de forma financiera, puedes ayudarnos de otras formas. Ayúdanos a incrementar nuestra presencia en las redes sociales, habla de nuestra investigación a tus amigos y conocidos y establece contacto con los miembros de nuestra organización.

Realmente valoramos tu ayuda para proteger lo que nos pertenece a todos y a nadie a la vez; nuestros mares y sus habitantes.
story_txt:
Project Summary We want to begin a conservation based research project that would help with the sustainability of sharks in the waters of the Dominican Republic. Our team is comprised of scientists, conservation leaders and award winning filmmakers. Through this conservation work we will also establish research that will help us better understand the shark species in those waters.
Our project objectives would be:  Establish a finalized protection plan for nurseries used by sharks in the Dominican Republic. Create a shark monitoring program with the locals in the areas to compile and keep data. Document shark behavior through film and photo for conservation purposes.
Have ongoing local and international presentations about our work, our procedures and how this project is helping the locals and their economy.

   What We Need & What You Get Since we are a nonprofit, everything comes out of our own pockets and sometimes we simply cannot afford all of the costs. What the money would be used for:  100% of the funding is to cover our research, meetings, awareness and education programs, and transportation to monitor the areas we are establishing as protected regions. If you help fund this project you will be one in a group of a few people who can have access to our research and work before the general public does.    The Impact There is currently no proper monitoring program in the Dominican Republic and specifically none for the nurseries that are being used by sharks, and as a result the sharks are being fished out of the waters faster than they can reproduce. This is where this project comes in:  Sharks are migratory species, so we need to do all that we can to better protect them and establishing a proper nursery protection and monitoring program is the first step. A lot of the sharks we will be working with use most of the areas we are monitoring as nurseries - so, these areas are vital to healthy and stable shark populations hence why they need to be monitored. We all need healthy shark populations in order to have healthy oceans and this project takes a very active approach to help maintain that.



    Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:  Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign - social media is a vital tool, so please feel free to share this campaign everywhere! (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Blogs, etc...)   Thank you and we appreciate your support!Resumen Del Proyecto
Nuestro
objetivo principal es el establecimiento de un programa para la investigación
de la comunidad de elasmobranquios que habitan las aguas de la Republica
Dominicana. Nuestro equipo está compuesto por biólogos, ecologistas,
conservacionistas y cinematógrafos. A través de este programa esperamos poder
proporcionar los datos necesarios para la mejor conservación de los escualos de
la isla.

Objetivos Principales del Proyecto:
· 
Establecer un santuario de elasmobranquios en la Republica Dominicana.
· 
Crear un programa de marcado y seguimiento de tiburones con la colaboración
de las autoridades locales y la población local.
Que nos hace falta & Como
puedes ayudar

Ya que somos una organización sin ánimo de lucro, el presente y futuro de
nuestro programa depende de nuestra habilidad diaria de encontrar fondos. A
pesar de haber podido financiar el nacimiento de este proyecto, para poder
seguir expandiéndolo, necesitamos tu ayuda. Las contribuciones que recibimos
son usadas para:
· 
La financiación de transporte hacia y en la Republica Dominicana. Dado
el carácter internacional de nuestro equipo, llegar al país isleño y
desplazarnos a las zonas de conservación se convierte en uno de nuestros gastos
principales.
· 
La compra y uso de material para el estudio de los escualos de la
isla. Todo aquel que se vea involucrado recibirá de forma exclusive todos los
avances de nuestros descubrimientos sobre la comunidad de tiburones en la
Republica Dominicana.
· 
Otro de los gastos principales de nuestro programa tiene que ver con
la vigilancia de las zonas de conservación y el seguimiento de las actividades
que afectan a los elasmobranquios de la isla.
Nuestro Impacto
En la
actualidad, no existes ni santuarios de tiburones, ni programas de
investigación de tiburones en la Republica Dominicana. Esta falta medios para
la conservación de los escualos, ha llevado a pesca de muchas especies por
encima de su habilidad reproductiva. A través de nuestro proyecto esperamos
alcanzar las siguientes metas:
· 
Entender la ecología geo-espacial de las especies de tiburón
migratorias que hacen uso de las aguas de la Republica Dominicana.
· 
Evaluar y proteger las áreas de cría halladas en los manglares de la
isla – estas áreas son cruciales para asegurar la continuidad de muchas
especies.
· 
A largo plazo, repoblar a las 
especies que se han visto afectadas por la falta de regulaciones de
pesca sostenibles.
Otras maneras en las que puedes
ayudar
No te
preocupes! Si no nos puedes ayudar de forma financiera, puedes ayudarnos de
otras formas. Ayúdanos a incrementar nuestra presencia en las redes sociales,
habla de nuestra investigación a tus amigos y conocidos y establece contacto
con los miembros de nuestra organización.

Realmente valoramos tu ayuda para proteger lo que nos pertenece a todos y a
nadie a la vez; nuestros mares y sus habitantes.

story:
Thank you for your help. We really appreciate all of the referrals also, thank you. However, a referral alone isn't going to change the direction of our future, $1 will.

If you want just a fraction of the trillions of dollars being spent on global issues to accomplish real progress, do something about it, work with us.

We are extending an invitation to everyone, to work with us in creating the future of business, that can also sustain life. Anyone with vision can make a difference.

Our first project is a more permanent housing solution for relief, on a broader, more efficient  scale, to those most in need around the world. We have been working on a new, Eco-sustainable, building system. We can start substantially reducing need for fossil fuels with better building materials.

1) We are a group of small business owners who have gotten together and created a company to take action for global relief - Humanitarian, Ecological, and Economical. We believe that we have created a more impactful, and permanent solution.

2) We feel that our technology and system will be how business is done in the future, but we need participants and partners to make it happen and make it work. It benefits everyone involved.

3) Our simple philosophy is 'We have to start somewhere and we have to start sometime. Why not here and now?' or as President Ronald Reagan put it... "If not us, who? And if not now, when?"

4) Our system is focused on relieving issues at the base, such as housing, food/water, education, etc. globally.

5) We believe that by relieving some of the most common factors that further escalate strife, we will help to de-escalate the violence and hopefully ease the suffering of the millions of innocents that are being affected. (Namely: Homeless, Refugees, others in poor housing conditions.)

6) A secondary benefit is that our business plan is lucrative. We wish to create as many jobs as we can in America and keep all manufacturing here. Our plan has potentials in many of the world markets, but we are starting with a housing solution as our first project.

7) We have been staying under the radar for the better part of four years while we studied various markets, technology - especially green technologies, and many related and not related subjects.

8) We are not yet public. As anyone who has ever had a great idea would agree, we are keeping our secrets guarded. Just a precaution until we can come out strong, as not to be infringed upon while we build momentum.

9) We want to get our company up and running as soon as possible. We need  to start getting the relief to those most in need. We are trying to do what needs to be done, and make this trend "Going Green" a viable direction and future for all of us.

10)  Since we are out of time, we are willing to get started within any country, including the U.S, that is willing to start the fundamental changes to turn their economies around.

All we are looking for at the moment is seed money to get this project into the next stage of R&D. The sooner we can, the sooner we can provide safe, clean housing for those in critical need.

We are asking for $1, and anyone who would like to work with us. 

Please help us spread the word.

Thank you

story:
***CHECK OUT OUR CONTEST IN UPDATES!***

Everything's Beachy(tm) brings the beach feeling to you, no matter where you are, with beautiful, sustainable, reusable, recycled and recyclable products.

Profits will be used to bring beach clean-up supplies and organization products to local communities to help in their efforts to keep our waterfronts and waterways clean and pure for future generations.

Many communities would love to have beach cleanup days, but some are too financially or resource stressed to be able to make them happen.  Which is where Everything's Beachy comes in!

Our goal is to support these communities by Sponsoring at least 50 beach cleanups in the coming year, and to build a robust, interactive website for these communities to engage with!

Everything's Beachy - thanks to our Sponsors, fundraising and Foundation, will supply basic beach cleanup kits consisting of 50 biodegradable bags, 3 sand sifter scoops, 2 trash picker uppers, 20 pre-printed posters and a dedicated webpage on our site.

All the local community has to do is pick a date, fill out the info on the posters, post them in their neighborhoods, create their web page, and get ready for the date! We'll even help promote it!

Beach Cleanup Supply  


                                             


Everything's Beachy is also thrilled to join in the movement to keep beaches and parks clean by supporting composting dog waste using compostible BioBags. We are offering a Sponsorship (or purchase) of a Doggie Waste Bag Station with 500! The station's location will be permanently posted on our map and app.

Doggie Waste Station  



- All of the porducts above can be Sponsored/purchased for your local beach, or sent to any needy beach in the US.
- Sponsors will receive Everything's Beachy Sponsor Car Magnets
- Purchasing the products below provide us with the funds to help needy beaches nationwide!
-To nominate your beach to receive our help, please fill out the application here


Window Decal or Car Magnet 

Visor

Tervis

TShirt   

TShirt   

Woman's Top   

Beach Towel     

Tote Bag   

Tire Cover

We would like to thank Jeff Vasquez, from JV Media Productions, for our video.  He's great to work with and we would be happy to share his info.

Also, Audrey Sperano DiSpigna for her editing and media help, she is an excellent Public Relations & Marketing Consultant, also happy to share her info.

Not to mention the many friends who have listened to us talk about this project for so long, and gave thoughts, prayers and guidance!  Thank you!

story:
''The wildlife of today is not ours to dispose of as we please. We have it in trust. We must account for it to those who come after''. King George V. 1935.
 These words make Even More Sense in 2015.

Introduction

My name is Peter Kamau. I am a PhD candidate in the Department of Geography and Anthropology at Louisiana State University in Baton Rouge, Louisiana. I conduct research on human-environment interactions in Africa. My current research focus is on how local knowledge can be integrated with scientific knowledge to solve environmental problems in Africa. Specifically, I am very passionate about the conservation of the African elephant. 

My research area

In Africa, modern conservation approaches that disregard indigenous conservation practices and exclude local communities in conservation planning have proved very ineffective.  With growing human numbers across Africa, keeping poor people away from protected areas have become too costly and confrontational.

In Tsavo, Kenya, conflicts between residents and conservation authorities over access to protected area resources are intense. Human activities especially livestock grazing in Tsavo have put pressure on wildlife habitat and also created an environment for illegal killing of elephants for ivory. Poaching of elephants for ivory persists in Tsavo despite enormous efforts by conservation authorities.

Map of Tsavo region

My research objective

In order to ensure the survival of elephants in Tsavo, there is urgent need for research that seek to understand indigenous conservation philosophies and explore ways to integrate these philosophies with modern conservation strategies. A historical perspective of the Tsavo landscape will shed light on current conflicts of over access to and control of scarce natural resources and inform new management action. The main objective of my research in Tsavo is to explore an alternative management approach that empowers local people to be the first protectors of elephants. There is need to resurrect a sense of ownership of wildlife resources among communities resident in Tsavo. This ground breaking research intends to design programs that will correct the erroneous perception that government officials own wildlife resources including elephants. These programs will re-instill a sense of ownership of wildlife resources among local people in Tsavo and create a better environment for collaboration between government officials and residents. Ultimately, this research will develop a new tool for environmental conservation in Tsavo that can be adopted as a model in other African countries.  


  Research Impact

This campaign seeks to raise funds to promote the conservation of elephants in Tsavo through field research. My main conviction in this campaign is that local people's knowledge is critical in protecting elephants and their habitats. Success in protecting elephants in Tsavo depends on the goodwill of local people. Research has shown that conservation approaches that create hostility between local people and authorities are counterproductive. There must be deliberate effort to ensure that local people support conservation efforts.

I intend to conduct participatory research in Tsavo over a one month period between December 15th 2015 and January 10th 2016. This will be a continuation of research conducted in Tsavo in the summer of 2015. I will do oral interviews with key informants, hold focus group discussions with existing village groups to gain local perspectives on elephant conservation. My research will also include participant observation and transect walks across villages adjacent to Tsavo parks.

Funds donated in this campaign will facilitate my travel to Tsavo, Kenya in December 2015 and also cater for my accommodation and food expenses while in Tsavo. The estimated cost of a return air ticket to Kenya is $ 1500. I will be in Tsavo for 25 days at an estimated cost of $ 20 per day in food and accommodation. I will need $ 500 to compensate my research participants for their time.

Am kindly requesting to be supported with $ 2500 to facilitate my research in December this year. Thank you very much for your generous support. 


Peter Kamau.

wakamau2011@gmail.com

513-658 4635. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!
And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary


  • . I would like to re-vamp and re-launch the B&B and use it to bring more info re the Knysna Seahorse as well as the famous Knysna Forests to more people. I feel the more people are educated about our forests and seas the more they will take ownership and start bettering themselves and taking more care of the world around them.
  • I am a 60 year old woman, who is tired of people saying that old people cant do things, I would like to show that I can do this and at the same time teach younger people how to run a B&B and how to believe in their dreams. 
  • I would really be grateful for assistance with this dream of mine.


What We Need & What You Get


  • I will use the funding to clean up th building and property around it and to kit out the bedrooms and bathrooms to make them more eco-friendly etc Bamboo bedding, energy saver lights, solar water heaters. I need about $11000 to achieve this. I will thank donors in the following way:    $100 donation will receive a beaded seahorse keyring .  $500 donation will receive a free nights stay at Seahorse Lodge, once re-launched. $1000 donation will receive all above and a trip across the Lagoon to Featherbed Nature Reserve.
  • If I don't reach my target, I will use the funds to do as much as I can on re-vamping Seahorse Lodge. (Seahorse Lodge does not yet have a website, I am working on that)


The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • By assisting me with this project, you will be helping bring the plight of the Knysna Seahorse to more people and to educate about the health of our Lagoons and Oceans. I would like to run workshops that will highlight the way we misuse the Oceans. I will be using the crafts and skills of the local ladies to decorate the Seahorse Lodge.

Risks & Challenges

 I am aware that there are many others who feel the same way about helping teach young people and children, but as a Grandmother of 3, I feel it is my duty to help protect the Knysna Seahorses, so my .4 year old grandson will still be able to show them to his grandchildren some day.

Other Ways You Can Help

 

If you are unable to contribute financially, please post this on your Facebook pages,Thank you very much

story:
Movimiento Ciudadano Frente al Cambio Climático (Mocicc)

MOCICC is a platform that brings together civil society: social organizations, NGOs, networks, religious institutions, professional associations, youth groups and independent citizens. MOCICC aims to take actions as well as generate multi-faceted discussions in defense of life and sustainability of the Earth, which is threatened by climate change.

MOCICC es una plataforma de la sociedad civil que reúne: organizaciones sociales, ONG, redes, instituciones religiosas, colegios profesionales, colectivos juveniles y ciudadanos independientes, todos ellos orientados a generar acciones, así como una corriente de opinión plural en defensa de la vida y la sostenibilidad de la Tierra, que se están amenazadas por el cambio climático.


Peruvian Schools Against Climate Change / Instituciones Educativas Activas Frente al Cambio Climático

Peruvian Schools Against Climate Change is a project promoted by MOCICC  consisting of training school staff and implementing BioGardens. Drawing on the benefits of BioGarden implementation, Peruvian Schools Against Climate Change aims to educate children in a holistic manner and grow produce that Peruvian Schools can then consume or sell.

Instituciones Educativas Activas Frente al Cambio Climático es un proyecto promovido por MOCICC que consiste en el entrenamiento del personal del colegio, la implementación de un BioHuerto, aprovechar todos los beneficios de la implementación de un Biohuerto para la educacion holistica de los niños y los productos que el colegio pueda obtener de su uso o venta.

The BioGardens serve to educate children in respect for life and confronting  climate change.

YOUR SUPPORT creates direct impact and value!

With your support we can continue to establish Peruvian schools against climate change. Your contribution is crucial to helping us work in 5 new schools and to double our impact by reaching up to 2500 more students (500 children per school).

La implementación de Biohuertos sirven para educar a los niños en el respeto a la vida y confrontar el cambio climático.
TU APOYO crea impacto directo y valor !!!
Con tu ayuda podremos continuar creando Instituciones Educativas Activas Frente al Cambio Climático. Tu contribución es crucial para ayudarnos a llegar a las siguientes 5 escuelas y doblar nuestro impacto a alrededor de 2500 niños ( 500 niños por escuela)
Achievements / Logros

We have already achieved successful implementation of the project in these schools:

I.E. 116 Abraham Valderomar

I.E, 1166 Libertador Simón Bolivar

I.E. Juan Pablo Vizcardo y Guzmán

I.E. 1163 José María Arguedas 

I.E. 1157 Julio César Tello

Translation: "Representing successful and innovative Peruvian schools, we are sending a message: that we as Peruvians emphasize all that is the quality of our environment, our education, and our families in order to be proud of our children, who are our future."
Video:

Why do we need you? / ¿Por qué te necesitamos ?

Children with an education in respect for life will be conscious actors against climate change and will be aware of environmental pollution throughout their entire lives. Thanks to your help more children can access all the benefits offered through the project: the preparation and creation of BioGardens as well as the consumption of Biohuerto products in their schools .

With your help we can bring Schools Against Climate Change to 5 more schools in Lima!

Los Niños educados en el respeto por la vida, conscientes y actores en contra del cambio climático son conscientes de la contaminación ambiental a lo largo de su vida, gracias a tu ayuda, más niños podrán acceder a todos los beneficios que ofrece la preparación, creación y los productos de un Biohuerto en su escuela
Con tu ayuda podremos Instituciones Educativas Frente al Cambio Climático a 5 colegio más en Lima 

• Create more Peruvian Schools Against Climate Change

• Educate more children on respect for life and acting against climate change

• Implement more BioGardens in Peruvian Schools with appropriate staff training

• Acquire more seeds, organic fertilizers and tools for the development of BioGardens

• Increase the number of schools within the project.

Goal / Meta

We need to raise at least 17 000 US$ to expand Schools Against Climate Change to the next 5 schools in Lima. The more money we raise, The more schools would have BioGardens and the more children would benefit.

Necesitamos llegar a 17,000 US$ para expandir Instituciones Educativas Activas Frente al Cambio Climático a los siguientes 5 colegios. Cuanto más recaudemos, más escuelas tendrán un BioHuerto y más niños se verán beneficiados.


Perks / Recompensas 

Choose one of our suggested amounts to contribute, Here are some peeks: 


No money ? NO PROBLEMA !
You can also help us by spreading the message on your social media or through e-mail! Thank you !!

Puedes ayudarnos tambien pasando la voz en tus redes sociales o a travez de tu correo electronico !! Muchas Gracias !!
story_txt:
Movimiento Ciudadano Frente al Cambio Climático (Mocicc)
 

MOCICC is a platform that brings together civil society: social organizations, NGOs, networks, religious institutions, professional associations, youth groups and independent citizens. MOCICC aims to take actions as well as generate multi-faceted discussions in defense of life and sustainability of the Earth, which is threatened by climate change.

MOCICC es una plataforma de la sociedad civil que reúne: organizaciones sociales, ONG, redes, instituciones religiosas, colegios profesionales, colectivos juveniles y ciudadanos independientes, todos ellos orientados a generar acciones, así como una corriente de opinión plural en defensa de la vida y la sostenibilidad de la Tierra, que se están amenazadas por el cambio climático.
   
Peruvian Schools Against Climate Change / Instituciones Educativas Activas Frente al Cambio Climático 
Peruvian Schools Against Climate Change is a project promoted by MOCICC  consisting of training school staff and implementing BioGardens. Drawing on the benefits of BioGarden implementation, Peruvian Schools Against Climate Change aims to educate children in a holistic manner and grow produce that Peruvian Schools can then consume or sell.
Instituciones Educativas Activas Frente al Cambio Climático es un proyecto promovido por MOCICC que consiste en el entrenamiento del personal del colegio, la implementación de un BioHuerto, aprovechar todos los beneficios de la implementación de un Biohuerto para la educacion holistica de los niños y los productos que el colegio pueda obtener de su uso o venta.



The BioGardens serve to educate children in respect for life and confronting  climate change.
YOUR SUPPORT creates
direct impact and value!
With your support we can continue to establish Peruvian schools against climate change. Your contribution is crucial to helping us work in 5 new schools and to double our impact by reaching up to 2500 more students (500 children per school).La implementación de Biohuertos sirven para educar a los niños en el respeto a la vida y confrontar el cambio climático.TU APOYO crea impacto directo y valor !!!Con tu ayuda podremos continuar creando Instituciones Educativas Activas Frente al Cambio Climático. Tu contribución es crucial para ayudarnos a llegar a las siguientes 5 escuelas y doblar nuestro impacto a alrededor de 2500 niños ( 500 niños por escuela)

story:
Among all of life’s uncertainties, weather is one of the biggest. We cannot control it, we can only live with it. Today, we have to live with a very serious mega-drought of uncertain duration. It is already the worst in California history.

It is imperative that we do everything possible to mitigate the effects of the drought. It is a tall order, and Enviro Conservation Solutions (ECS) has found an answer.

ECS technology can reduce water usage up to 50%, while enhancing plant yield and growth efficiency, thereby saving the end user money. A win-win situation.

Utilizing the science of Magnetic Hydro Dynamics, ECS has technology that causes water to become more soluble, allowing for maximum absorption into soil. High absorbency requires less water to keep vegetation healthy.

The hydro magnetic products are self-sustaining, long lasting, and fast acting with no need of external power. Once the product is attached to a pipe, the magnetic field will magnetize the pipe within 72 hours and immediately begin treating the water. Within days the effects will start to become apparent.

The Impact

If ECS technology is used it can save California. Agricultural demands and the beauty of all landscapes can be maintained while still reducing water usage by 35-50%.

With Governor Brown declaring a drought state of emergency, new technologies must be explored and implemented immediately.

ECS technology would be a first strike in the fight against the drought. Combining this technology with water conservation education could make the effects of the drought much less dangerous or difficult. It will also grant California a very smooth transition back to normalcy when climate shifts in our favor.

The beauty is that the cost of the product (which is nominal when compared to other conservation alternatives) will eventually be covered by the money saved from a 30 - 50% cut in water bills.

If we can be successful developing this first project, we can make use of additional ESC products in California to multiply the benefits. It doesn't really matter where in the world the installation is, everyone with ECS products will equally benefit.

We need your help!

We now require funding to ensure we can get our product out to as much of the state as is needed. With 80% of the state in extreme drought or worst, we know we are going to have to market and distribute quickly.

Total funds needed to cover all of this is $50,000. With these funds we can really get things moving along with a marketing blitz and educating the state’s decision-makers on giving the citizen’s that use our product and save water incentives and rebates.  

We really appreciate your donations to support us on our mission to save California from environmental and economic disaster.


News

Here are some links to news stories about the California Drought



SHOCKING PICTURES OF THE DROUGHT IN CALIFORNIA:

http://www.buzzfeed.com/alexnaidus/california-drought-images#.hbZx68V4p


June 12, 2015 - California Cuts Farmers’ Share of Scant Water

http://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/13/us/california-announces-restrictions-on-water-use-by-farmers.html?_r=0

June 5, 2015 - Here’s What The 2015 Drought Will Do To California’s Economy

http://thinkprogress.org/climate/2015/06/05/3666630/california-drought-economic-toll/

June 2, 2015 - Tough water restrictions leveled on Rancho Santa Fe residents

http://fox5sandiego.com/2015/06/01/toughest-water-restrictions-in-county-leveled-on-rancho-santa-fe-residents/

June 1, 2015 - California Drought 2015: 70 Percent Water Use Cuts Proposed For Large Families, Properties: Report

http://www.ibtimes.com/california-drought-2015-70-percent-water-use-cuts-proposed-large-families-properties-1946797

story:
Please Help Us Fund the Legal Effort!

6/12/15 -- Despite years of widespread community opposition in Old Bethpage and Plainview, the Town of Oyster Bay on May 12, 2015 unanimously approved Country Pointe Plainview -- a massive project that will overwhelm the local community and decimate the wildlife and forest on the 143 acre site near the LIE. 

On June 10, 2015, a group of five neighbors on Round Swamp Road appeared in court on their own behalf and under the prodding of the Supreme Court judge hearing the case obtained agreement from the developer not to begin any work, or damage the environment in any way, pending a hearing on July 8, 2015. 

The neighbors -- who are non-lawyers -- filed a massive Article 78 petition detailing and documenting blatant violations of the State Environmental Quality Review Act by the Town which downplayed and distorted the impacts of the project. The lawsuit asks the court to overturn the zoning, site plan, and subdivision plans, and compel a new environmental review.

There is much legal work to be done.

We urgently need funding for a "bond" as required by the Court for a Preliminary Injunction. Without the injunction work may begin even while the lawsuit is pending. We do not know how much will be required, yet, and will not know until the judge decides on it. 

Furthermore we are looking for legal assistance as we move forward and face the full weight of the developer's legal team -- as well as the Town's. 

We need the help now of the hundreds of P/OB residents and others concerned about the environment who testified, wrote letters and emails, and signed petitions against this project over the past few years. PLEASE HELP!!!

THANKS!!

========================================================

This Press Release was issued the day after the case was filed: 

145-acre Development in Plainview-Old Bethpage Challenged  Over Alleged Violations in Environmental Review 

Old Bethpage, June 11, 2015 -- Three Old Bethpage families appeared in State Supreme Court yesterday to file an extensive article 78 lawsuit challenging how the Town of Oyster Bay performed its environmental review of the massive Country Pointe at Plainview development project. 

The judge in the case scheduled a follow-up hearing for July 8, 2015 and obtained consent of all the parties -- represented in court by five attorneys for the Town and the developer -- that no construction or environmental damage would occur before that time.

The lawsuit intends to annul the rezoning, subdivision and site plan, and re-open the environmental review to allow a full accounting of the impacts on wildlife, habitat, and neighboring properties. 

Such a review could result in a re-design better minimizing the environmental impact, as required by the State Environmental Quality Review Act, "SEQRA". 

The site of the proposed project is a 143-acre property sold off by Nassau County in 1998. It currently contains about 60 acres of forest in five separate stands, about 15 soccer fields in two areas, and about a dozen abandoned buildings formerly used by the county as its "Nassau East Office Complex". 

Zoning for the project was approved by the Town of Oyster Bay on May 12, 2015 after years of intense controversy that led Charles Wang to abandon a prior proposed development, and leading to its sale to the present developer Beechwood POB LLC, a Delaware company headquartered in Jericho. 

As approved by the Town, the plans call for completely levelling about 100 acres  across the site to be developed with houses, townhouses, condominiums, some apartments, and stores (Petition, paragraph 29), and leaving the remaining acreage for Town to use, mostly as athletic fields.

While many residents had opposed the project over issues of traffic and density,  -- deluging the Town with petitions, phone calls, letters, and verbal testimony including a hearing in April, 2014, that lasted until 3 AM -- the lawsuit focuses on four areas of environmental review the plaintiffs argue led to fatal flaws in the process.

First, the lawsuit argues that the Town unlawfully "segmented" the environmental review by separating its plans to construct new athletic fields on forest-land it will be given, as well as deferring review of the construction of several new traffic lanes at or nearby the site.

Second, the lawsuit argues that the Town failed to take a required "hard look" at the environmental impact on the roughly 55 of species of wildlife and 47 species of Lepitdoptera on the site -- including foxes, bats and pheasants (petition, paragraphs 72-3). 

The plaintiffs point to a failure to actually count or estimate how many animals are on the site, and allege the Town falsely down-played the value of the dense  forests on the site as habitat for wildlife.

Third, the lawsuit argues that the Town failed to take a required "hard look" at the environmental impact on habitat on the site. The plaintiffs argue the Town engaged in a pattern of using deceptive math and semantics to overstate the amount of wildlife habitat preserved and understate the amount originally present. 

Finally, the lawsuit argues the town failed to take a "hard look" at the visual impact on the neighbors on Round Swamp Road -- of whom all the five plaintiffs are members -- because the analysis of the proposed 125-foot wooded "buffer" intended to shield the development was confused and incomplete.

Among other issues the developer plans to cut a swath through the buffer for a fitness train and fitness stations. 

The State Environmental Quality Review Act ("SEQRA"), which the lawsuit is based on, is the state's bedrock environmental protection law, passed in 1975. 

The law attempts to guarantee that actions by governments and agencies at all levels of the state -- except the State Legislature -- are done in a way that rationally and transparently analyzes and minimizes the negative impacts on the environment. 

The plaintiffs were assisted by East Hills environmental activist Richard Brummel (contact (516) 238-1646, editor Planet-in-Peril.org), who has also been involved in numerous other legal actions in Nassau County directed at protecting the environment from over-development.

"This is a good example of how citizens can and should stand up for their communities and for the limited healthy environment that remains on Long Island, especially in Nassau County. It also documented governments have favored development to the point of undermining environmental law," Mr. Brummel said.

The lawsuit contains 52-pages of text and 48 exhibits including satellite photos and text and graphics from the SEQRA review.

story:
THIS CAMPAIGN

This campaign is an effort to mobilize 3 Partners of the California based Whole Com Team to develop multiple commercial solar projects in the Southeastern United States. 

This campaign gets you involved INSIDE of Whole Com and shows you HOW to MAKE A DIFFERENCE, SIMPLY AND EASILY. The more people invest, the more 'sustainable' solar power is deployed.

Whole Com is offering you the opportunity to invest in the solar panels on our next commercial project!  You can invest a small amount per solar panel and help produce more clean energy without having to buy a whole system or start a solar development company yourself!


Perhaps you have an apartment and cannot get solar for your home. Maybe you are already powering your home with solar energy but want to make a bigger impact on the growth of the industry by partnering with us!   Yes, YOU can invest in Whole Com and help produce more clean energy!

This is your opportunity to invest in our company and take ownership in a commercial Solar Project. Besides the satisfaction of contributing to the healing of the earth you could get a return from your investment over the next 5 years! 


ABOUT WHOLE COM 

Whole Com was founded 15 months ago by entrepreneur and transformational thought leader, Corey Call. The success of his RENEW FI conference has developed many innovative financing abilities and created an advanced network with large scale solutions. Corey has aligned himself with mentors and Solar leaders like Danny Kennedy, Mark Grobmyer,  Doug Carter and Pablo Otin.  

Currently, Corey is traveling on a “Solar Tour” through Arkansas, Tennessee and North Carolina, with long term partner and co-founder Daniel Jimenez and new business development team member, Joel Atchison.

We are continuing to expand from already popular residential solar markets to developing commercial solar projects which can start chiseling away at the energy crisis at a much faster rate. Recently the Pope said, "We need a Revolution of Hearts and Minds of the Human Race" to face the Climate issues at hand. 

Whole Com has worked hard to gather an effective system and team, and now we have the opportunity to share it with the world! Whole Com gives you the access and ability to become part of the bigger picture. 

HOW THE FUNDS WILL BE USED

The funds raised through this campaign will underwrite the basic needs of the Whole Com Team as they travel in a circuit around Arkansas, Tennessee, and North Carolina working on multiple Commercial Solar projects already in motion.  The more our campaign raises, the more work we can get done to get the solar ball rolling in the southeast!


SPREAD THE WORD

You will help us accomplish our common goal by sharing this link with your network during these 40 days. Thank you for joining us on this wonderful Journey. Lets do this now!



Teamwork makes the Dream Work! 

Click here to read more detailed profiles on the team members

story:
Learn More About Care About Climate

Short Summary

December 2015 will be a pivotal moment for our planet. The United Nations will gather in Paris, France to develop a new global agreement for combating climate change. For the first time, we have the opportunity to join together -- across our communities, our countries, our planet -- to ensure strong action is taken to prevent further global climate change.

See more at: http://www.cop21.gouv.fr/en

This fall, Care About Climate will be traveling across the United States to raise awareness about how people like you can have an impact on the UN negotiations and the future of our climate! We will be visiting college campuses and other communities to educate people on climate change, climate policy, and how sustainable choices make a big difference in preventing climate change in the future. We will also be taking the climate symbol around the country to allow individuals to show that they care about the climate through a uniting image. 

What We Need & What You Get

In order to make this educational tour happen, we need to get together some funding for fuel, materials, food, and accommodation. That's where you come in! When you donate to our cause, you're helping us spread awareness about climate change, and what we can do about it. This is a special time, because right now people can voice their concerns and opinions and actually impact the resolution at the Paris negotiations in December.

In addition to that warm fuzzy feeling you get for being involved in saving the world, you also get our fun perks! Get a variety of goodies and official recognition as a sponsor. Check out the list below and the links to the right for more detail. 

The Impact

The United States negotiators will be meeting with the rest of the United Nations in Paris this December and representing the opinions of our country as they negotiate a new climate policy. Right now, they're listening to see exactly what those opinions are and how invested our country is in making a strong, proactive policy. Here's our plan of action:

  • Bring together communities to engage in collaborative action 
  • Show that Americans have the will and desire to make serious changes
  • Encourage our State Department to be a leader in the negotiations
  • Impact the worldwide policy for climate change through 2030
This will be measured through the following metrics:

  • Visit at least 40 cities in the US. Host at least 30 presentation events. 

  • Build up email list of at least 7,000 people

  • Get 5,000 followers on Facebook, get 1,000 followers on twitter, get 1,500 followers on Instagram 

  • Have 350 visitors to our website per week

  • Recruit 30 Climate Ambassadors

  • Have 20 supporting local actions while we are in Paris to show negotiators that we want action on climate change. Have people change their profile pictures to the climate symbol while in Paris.

  • Give presentations to 1,000 people 

  • Obtain at least 50 climate stories (videos, written stories) from the people we visit.

  • Take pictures of at least 500 people with the climate symbol.
  • Distribute at least 10,000 climate symbol stickers.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

Risk: Hosting events out of our local community and state.

Solution:

  • We are working within our networks of friends and colleagues asking them to help us put on each event. One of the core leaders of this project has been working in a national group for 7 years and has developed relationships with people across the country, which we can use to help us engage with communities that we have not worked in. We are also going to be contacting relevant local groups to advertise our event prior to us getting there. 
Risk: Care About Climate's First Initiative and Program
Solution:
  • Although this is the first program that Care About Climate is pursuing, we are working to make sure that the money being spent on this is having the impacts that we desire. We have created quantitative metrics that we want to hit during the Road Trip, and if we see that we are not making sufficient progress towards those goals we will reevaluate how we are operating the Road Trip to ensure that we have the greatest impact possible. This is an inexpensive pilot project that will build our base, bring awareness to the climate change negotiations, and get local communities to engage in the international discussion by hosting local impacts. 
Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about the #RoadTripToParis
  • Please share our campaign with others
  • Help us by posting our events in your community
  • Help us host an event in your community
  • Sent out our interest form to get other people involved 
  • Like us on Facebook, Follow us on Twitter, and Follow us on Instagram
  • Change picture to climate symbol during Paris negotiations
  • Help house us, feed us, and get us involved in your networks
And that's all there is to it!
Help us to get your community involved and provide outreach programs that lead up to and include coverage of COP21/CMP11, this December in Paris.

story:
Overview

Our oceans are facing a catastrophic biodiversity decline. Coastal communities often lack incentives to protect marine animals and continue to kill even endangered species. Ocean Eye is an innovative technology solution that provides a financial benefit to coastal communities which is linked to the long-term recovery of marine animal populations through an application that facilitates small tourism payments for each animal sighted during a trip.

Our Story

We are Sari, Mareike, Simon and Paul, a team of ocean lovers, conservation experts and a tech developer. We have been working in the global marine conservation arena for decades and have developed ocean eye to meet the key conservation challenge we often face -- stakeholder buy in. 

With Ocean Eye we can finally start giving rewards from marine tourism directly to the people who most depend on the hunting and killing of these animals, the coastal communities. This technology allows secure and transparent payment that is for the first time linked to species recovery, creating a powerful incentive for behavior change and conservation.

We already raised over 6000 USD in our campaign in June, which has allowed us to incorporate Ocean Eye into a legal entity, to develop our business plan, develop a prototype app as well as identify first pilot sites for testing the prototype and began field operations.

We now need funds to develop the full minimum viable product. Given the complexity of the features  and high level of security required this is estimated to cost another 25 000 USD.

What We Need & What You Get

-We need  25 000 USD towards the development of  the minimum viable product and to properly launch Ocean Eye.

-For individuals donations of 500 USD or over you will get your name on our website and for companies with donations of 1000 USD or over you will get your logo as a sponsor on our website.

-Donations of 100 USD or over will get a digital marine life photograph and a personal thank you note. 

-After the application is ready we can start implementing in the field and we will send all donors over 50 USD success stories of marine life numbers and community benefits one year after the application is launched so you can stay tuned and really see what wonderful impact your donation had. 

-For donation of 10 USD and over you will get personalised thank you note.

The Impact

We and our many colleagues working in the biodiversity and marine conservation sectors believe this innovation is a game changing idea, especially in the developing country context where coastal communities lack incentives to protect marine life. Science has demonstrated that number one factor in successful marine protected areas is stakeholder buy in. This is what Ocean Eye is working at. It will enable a direct and transparent payment from tourists to the community and provide them an incentive to protect sharks, turtles, manta rays, dolphins and many other marine animals instead of killing them for short term cash. 

As an example, shark fin is priced at 600 USD a kilo, a real example of shark sightings at a dive operation in Papua, Indonesia showed that if one shark sighting by divers was priced at 50cents, the local community would have received 4653 USD over one year as direct payment. Creating a real financial incentive to control shark fishing in the community. 

It will also empower the tourists and the marine recreation sector to be part of the solution and provide a tangible benefit to the communities in the area they visit. In addition this app can provide much needed citizen's science that can further improve the conservation of these species.

Risks & Challenges

We are engaging an experienced tech company that has worked with community interphases to do our app to ensure it will work well in various community and tourism situations and provide flexible enough functions to tailor the species and prices i.e. high end tourists vs budget destinations and to be able to adjust the species according to local issues and biodiversity. 

The app has big potential to scale as it does not need ongoing NGO support or funding. The tourism sector can adopt it themselves to use in their areas to help achieve conservation outcomes.

There is always a risk involved when working with communities in conservation and we are consulting broadly with groups and experts in marine conservation and community work that will help us establish guidelines and best practices to ensure the best long-term environmental and social impacts and to mitigate unwanted consequences.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread this campaign and the need for urgent action to halt biodiversity decline in our oceans. We have no time to waste. Join our mailing list on https://oceaneye.io  for more updates. Thank you!

story:
Composting Needed Now

I promote and support use of Composting Toilets, help people to find out how nature works and how this knowledge can be applied in their everyday life on physical and metaphysical level to create their life in sustainability and balance.

I became a passionate composter in 2008 at the Boom Festival in Portugal. Since then I have worked with http://www.naturalevent.com.au to  design and implement a flat pack compost toilet solution across the festival circuit.

In this time, I realized the complexity and potential of Composting toilets as a viable waste management system. Working towards global sustainability by repairing the soil, reducing water usage and saving our natural fertility from being dumped into the ocean.

As a father and conscious human being, I feel responsible to leave a well functioning environment for future generations. We should be able to swim in the sea and rivers and eat food from our gardens, without being afraid of the array of chemicals produced by industrial processes.

Through this project, we will open minds and be able to promote composting Toilet services on a larger scale. We hope to find allies globally who want to invest in change and restore global sustainability for all.

We aim to prove a profitable sanitation system that can be implemented in all circumstances.


What We Will Do & Perks For You

We need funding for the crew of eight to deliver the composting toilet materials for the build, for transport and maintenance procedures and for the collection and delivery of the resource back to the land.  We would also like to document our work by continuing to work with Arch Pictures video production company.  This will allow us to create & present a longer composting film to our supporters and a wider audience. 

Through our supporters, we can offer memorable hand painted water colour pictures,  2 Oil on canvas hand painted copies of masters, hand crafted love-hearts from wool, custom made upcycled dresses, also you can join and become a member of the team to experience and see the impact of these toilets. You can gain knowledge of building and maintaining composting toilets while having a life changing experience.

Pictures of Perks

Oil on Canvas copy of "The Singing Butler"-by Jack Vettriano  (artist Shoana Taylor)
(275x360)

Oil on canvas copy of "Study of Figure with Parasol"(to the right) by Claude Monet

(artist Shoana Taylor) (340 x 500)

If we don't reach our funding goal we can still do our project with less toilets . If we   don't reach our minimum target (£5000), we will donate the funds to a charity that is providing support for the refugee camp in Calais(l‘auberge des migrants and Care 4 Calais). Funding is being collected through a non profit account HECATE, (Heathfield Environmental and Community Action Team), set up to support environmental and community causes.

The Impact

Strengthening communities.  Lowering maintenance costs. Providing sanitation education. Reducing environmental impacts. Restoring soil integrity. Changing perceptions.


Refugees will have a chance to express and get involved through an Information center.  They can be naturally educated as sanitary engineers.


Further expansion, through composting the resource, can produce electricity, gas and fertilizer, as part of a sustainable energy and permaculture sector.
Challenges

The Refugee situation in Europe is open to change, misrepresentation and can create fear on all sides. With this in mind, we feel equipped to deliver a message of hope, dignity and sanitation. Our team has a long and diverse wealth of experience in composting, refugee and land matters that will serve us well.


Ways You Can Help

Donate funds, equipment, materials and time.

Think about the future and consider what impact your actions have on the environment.

Spread our vision with your friends.

Use the Indiegogo share tools to help to spread the project.

If you can't contribute funds, you can still help.

Keep Hope Alive & Communicate 

compostloos@gmail.com

story:
Globally we are experiencing a shocking rate of forest loss. At the rate logging, charcoal production, slash and burn farming and monoculture are going Zambia will be completely denuded within 15 years. This area of South Central Africa is a biodiversity hotspot and under threat of losing an incredible wealth of plant and animal species.

To raise awareness for Zambia, and global deforestation in general, I plan on cycling 3000 km solo from Cape Town , South Africa to Livingstone, Zambia to attend a reforestation festival hosted by the non profit organisation, Greenpop. At the Zambia festival of action in June/July volunteers from around the world will join with the local community and schools in an exciting, educational 3 week festival where thousands of trees will be planted, hands will get dirty and ideas about a sustainable future will be shared.

We need so little to live and be truly happy and I want prove this by cycling with minimal gear and comforts. The majority of my nights will be spent camping along the roadside listening to the sounds of the African bush as I pass through remote areas of South Africa, Namibia and Botswana where I look forward to some frightening, but hopefully friendly encounters with wild animals, and no doubt heart warming experiences with the local people. My experiences will be documented almost as they occur and will appear on my website: www.return2earth.org


I believe we need to start being more conscious of how live, and how the decisions we make regarding what we consume and discard affects our environment. We impulsively buy items that we have been convinced are necessary to our survival, comfort and happiness, but in fact serve only to complicate our lives and estrange us to the natural cycles and laws of nature. We are losing touch with our planet, making it easier to disregard the damage we are doing, 

By embarking on this adventure I hope to attract large media coverage, and thereby bring to public attention the environmental concerns of our time – particularly the shocking rate at which we are losing our forests. I have already acquired sponsorship from 3 gear and equipment companies and have features in 2 of the local newspapers. Help me further my message by donating trees to be planted at the Zambia Festival of Action and donating operating funds for my journey across Africa. If you wish to donate directly to Greenpop so that every cent goes directly to the purchasing of trees then please visit my givengain campaign https://www.givengain.com/activist/129032/projects/12263/

Each tree costs only $12 and the GPS coordinates will be given to the donor on a certificate. If you wish to donate operating funds so that I can afford to spread my message and make the  trip toZambia then please donate here. I am also selling my prized possession - my vehicle to fund this trip. 

 For more information about Greenpop, the non profit organisation I am representing, please visit greenpop.org or check my website www.return2earth.org

Who am I? 

I am a passionate lover of nature and the outdoors and spend my days wondering off into the woods when I'm not at sea captaining yachts. I have a profound respect for those cultures that inhabit remote areas of the world and practice ancient skills and are privy to a wealth of knowledge that will be lost with the forests and wildernesses if we continue along this destructive trajectory. My heart goes out to these beautiful people and places and feel that if we loose these we have lost the very soul of our world. For me this is the beginning of many journeys to come to awaken positive change.

If you are unable to donate, I ask that you share this with as many people as possible!

story:
Un milagro para Los Milagros

Somos Isabel (Peruana) y Jose Enrique (Español), un matrimonio de fotógrafos y docentes universitarios concienciados con el cuidado del medio ambiente y la importancia de la conservación. Hemos adquirido un fundo de 15 hectáreas en la selva de Aucayacu, en el Caserío Los Milagros, Valle del Alto Huallaga (en la Cuenca Amazónica del Perú), al cual nos queremos dedicar a tiempo completo. 

Nuestro proyecto de vida aquí tiene tres ejes:

  • Reforestación.
  • Agricultura sostenible.
  • Ecoturismo. 

Queremos recuperar el bosque, los suelos, tener cultivos sostenibles, como cacao y café, y realizar actividades ecoturísticas. Esta es una tierra que ha estado abandonada por 10 años (tras muchos años de ser usada para monocultivo de coca), localizada en una comunidad de campesinos que intentan dejar atrás la pobreza mediante cultivos alternativos, sin recurrir nuevamente al cultivo de coca. Contamos con la asesoría de profesionales de la Universidad Agraria de la Selva (UNAS), y estamos empezando desde ya con este proyecto. 

Esta campaña busca fondos para poder empezar a hacer lo más necesario y culminar las primeras etapas lo antes posible, y a largo plazo conseguir el estatus legal de Área de Conservación Privada.

El siguiente video muestra las diferentes secciones del terreno, desde las partes mejor conservadas del bosque hasta la zona agrícola donde plantaremos guaba, cacao y café. 


A miracle for Los Milagros

We are Isabel (Peruvian) and Jose Enrique (Spanish), a marriage of photographers and college professors who care deeply for the environment and for conservation.  We have legally acquired 15 hectares of land in Aucayacu, in Los Milagros, a settlement located in the Alto Huallaga Valley in the Peruvian Amazon basin. 

Our current dream and main project here covers three areas:

  • Reforestation.
  • Sustainable agriculture.
  • Ecotourism. 
 We want to recover the degraded rainforest and its soil, as well as develop sustainable crops, such as cocoa and coffee beans, and starting ecotourism activities. This land has been abandoned for some 10 years, after many years of coca leaf production. Los Milagros (the name means "Miracles") is a poor peasant community aiming to progress and leave poverty behind without growing coca again. We are being advised by professionals from the Universidad Agraria de la Selva (National Agrarian University of the Jungle) and have already started to work. 
This fundraising campaign aims to have enough funds to just to start working in the land and making our first stage goals happen as soon as possible, and in the long term to support our land's change in legal status to Private Conservation Area. 

Our home video shows the different zones of our land, since the most well-preserved forest until the agricultural area where we will grow guaba, cocoa and coffee (see below).

 ¿Qué queremos hacer? / What do we want to do?

  • Recuperar los bosques degradados y conservar los árboles grandes aún existentes. (Recuperación de Suelos y Reforestación) 
  • Recover degraded rainforests and soils, and to preserve the remaining big trees. 
  • . 
  • Recuperar el terreno agrícola para establecer una plantación sostenible de cacao y café. (Recuperación de suelos y Agricultura Sostenible)
  • Recover agricultural soils in order to develop sustainable crops of cacao and coffee beans.

  • Involucrar a la comunidad local (para su beneficio) en actividades conexas de Ecoturismo y Turismo Vivencial
  • Involving local population into ecotourism and experiential turism activities, in their own benefit.

¿Qué tenemos que hacer?

What do we HAVE to do?

  • Colocación de un cerco de alambre de púas (casi 3km), para proteger el área y disuadir a los taladores y cazadores ilegales.
  • Building a barbed-wire fence (almost 3km lenght) to protect the area from poachers and illegal loggers.
  • Reforestación de las áreas de aptitud forestal taladas y/o degradadas, reintroduciendo paulatinamente en ellas 2500 plantones de diversas especies nativas de árboles, como Huayruro (Ormosia coccinea), Cedro Rojo Amazónico (Cedrela odorata), Lupuna (Ceiba pentandra), Tornillo (Cedrelinga cateniformis), Capirona (Capirona decorticans) Pino chuncho (Schizolobiumamazonicum) entre otros.
  • Reforestation with 2,500 native species trees, such as Ormosia coccinea, Cedrela odorata, Ceiba pentandra, Cedrelinga cateniformis, Capirona decorticans, Schizolobiumamazonicum, among others.
  • Adquisición y plantación de 1000 arbolitos de Guaba (Inga sp.),  especie recomendada por los especialistas para recuperar los suelos dañados por años de monocultivo de coca.
  • Sowing 1,000 "guaba" trees (Inga sp.), a species recommended by specialists to nurture and recover soils damaged by years of monoculture of coca.
  • Plantación de cultivos sostenibles de cacao y café. La meta es alcanzar con el tiempo una certificación orgánica.
  • Plantation of sustainable crops (cocoa and coffee beans). The long-term goal is achieving in the long term an Organic Certification.
  • Compartir con la comunidad los avances y los conocimientos, así como brindar capacitación a los campesinos con charlas de profesionales en agricultura y zootecnia.
  • Sharing knowledge and techniques in agriculture and zootechnics with local communities.
  • Limpieza y mejoramiento de los accesos, y de los senderos para caminatas.
  • Cleaning, improvement and maintenance of access roads and hiking trails.
  • Construcción (con técnicas y materiales tradicionales) de unas cuatro cabañas (para alojamiento y actividades diversas), un cobertizo, y un silo.
  • Construction (using traditional materials and techniques) of some four cabins, a shed and a pit latrin.
  • Instalaciones para recolectar y almacenar agua de lluvia (durante los meses lluviosos). 
  • Installing systems to collect and store water from rain (during the rainy season).
  • Instalación de un sistema de energía por placas solares.
  • Installing a solar energy system.

(Foto mariposa Morphos: (CC) Lorenzo Magnis https://goo.gl/HuR4NN)


Impacto socioambiental 

Social/Environmental Impact 

  • Capacitación de la población local de ejemplos y técnicas de agricultura sostenible, lo que contribuye a mejorar su nivel de vida y a disminuir la presión del entorno para volver al monocultivo de la hoja de coca.
  • Empower local communities with knowledge and techniques in sustainable agriculture, contributing to rise their standard of living and to reduce peer pressure to come back into coca monoculture.
  • Recuperación del bosque nativo, que implica secuestro de carbono y recuperación de hábitats para especies amenazadas.
  • Recovery of native forests, in order to help carbon sequestration and to recover habitats for endangered native species.
  • Desarrollo de actividades ecoturísticas y de concienciación en conservación del medio ambiente.
  • Organizing diverse ecotouristic and other environmental awareness activities.

¿Cómo puedes ayudar? / How can you help?

Escoge alguna de las opciones que presentamos. Si te es imposible contribuir con una donación, eso no significa que no puedas ayudar:

Choose one of our featured options. If you actually cannot contribute with a monetary donation, that doesn't mean you cannot help:

  • ¡Difunde nuestra campaña entre tus amigos y tus redes sociales!
  • Spread the word among your friends and social media contacts!

  • ¡Usa las herramientas para compartir de Indiegogo!.
  • Use Indiegogo's sharing tools!

¡MUCHAS GRACIAS!

THANK YOU VERY MUCH!

story:
Resumen

 
The modern life on earth has been powered by the utilization of fossil fuels, in order to meet the increasing demand of energy. Especially the rapid development of technology, science and quality of life within the last two centuries is related with the use of these sources of energy (Steam Engine, 1774; Railway, 1830; public lighting, 1807, among others).

Especially the rapid development of technology, science and quality of life within the last two centuries is related with the use of these sources of energy (Steam Engine, 1774; Railway, 1830; public lighting, 1807, among others).

story:
Our Mission:

As noted above, there is an excess of plastic that is not being recycled. Our goal is to help reduce poverty and clean up our planet by paying the locals that live on less than two dollars a day to collect plastic.   

Plastic Pollution & Poverty

Since 1950, human beings have created over 8.3 billion metric tons/tonnes of plastic and only 9% of that plastic has been recycled. The remaining 7.47 million metrics tons/tonnes of plastic have either been incinerated or are accumulating in landfills, which will eventually end up in our waterways and oceans. It is estimated that ocean plastic causes $13 billion a year in damages and lost revenue. This has and will continue to affect tourism, shipping, and fishing.

Why Haiti

Natural Disasters (2002-Current)

Haiti is located in one of the world's toughest geographical regions. Recently 6 major floods, 17 major hurricanes/tropical storms/torrential rain, as well as 2 earthquakes have devastated the island. Haiti is constantly hit with horrific natural disasters that result in worse conditions than it previously was in. This is partially why Haiti has an 80% poverty rate, which leaves two out of every three people jobless. 

Pilate Haiti:

My business partner and I have formed a strategic relationship with Suze Francois, a local from Pilate, Haiti. Suze will provide us with the necessary local connections that are crucial to success within the region. Our mission is to provide the locals with jobs and to build our first set of homes in Pilate. We will then spread to other towns, which will create additional jobs and increase our social impact. 

Our Solution

Happy Homes plans to help impoverished Haitians' by providing a consistent, earnable wage and sustainable and affordable housing made out of plastic. 

Our Brick:

The center of our block will be composed of Vetiver, which is a root that is commonly grown in Haiti. These roots are very cheap, abundantly available, and have historically been used as building material in Haiti. The integration of the root will reduce the cost and weight of our bricks. The dimensions of our bricks are 10''L X 6''W X14"H and weigh just over 16lbs. This is nearly one-third the weight of a typical brick this size.

About Us:

Nick Kellicker: When I was a sophomore in college I spent my winter break in India. I fell in love with the culture and the people. I spent a lot of time exploring different historical sites as well as working at the Pumpkin House Orphanage while I was there.This experience truly opened my eyes and changed the way I thought about the world. The amount of poverty and plastic waste really impacted me during my stay. I met Rafic Korban as I began to think about potential solutions. This is when we began molding an idea that would bring about a social impact by providing people with a steady income, giving them an opportunity to have a safe and sustainable home while cleaning up the environment all at the same time.

 

Rafic Korban: I grew up in Hong Kong, the most densely populated city in East Asia. I noticed a great deal of trash, which has become a growing problem in and around the city. I recently met my business partner, Nick Kellicker, at Suffolk University. We quickly realized that we shared a common interest in helping out impoverished countries dealing with trash problems, specifically plastic. Happy Homes is my solution to help people in need while cleaning up our environment. I am extremely dedicated to making a difference and finding more people who share the same passion as Nick and me.

What We Need 

The Impact

Many people take having a home for granted and don't realize how important it is to have a healthy and happy environment to live in. By providing people with the opportunity to live in an affordable home, we are allowing them to flourish and survive. 

Along with providing safe, affordable and sustainable homes made out of recycled plastic, Happy Homes is dedicated to providing the Haitian locals with a consistent wage. The Haitian locals will have complete control over the number of hours they choose to put in. Happy Homes is dedicated to forming a community where everyone feels safe and comfortable, which is why we have chosen to hire local leaders to work with. 

Providing the Haitian economy with this opportunity will enable them to live a more comfortable life. This is a crucial aspect of our mission because along with helping the impoverished community, we are also stimulating their economy by keeping the plastic in Haiti and directly helping those who collect it. 

Units of Social  Impact:

  1. Homes built
  2. Employees and wages
  3. Pounds of plastic collected & recycled

Risks & Challenges

  • Sociopolitical factors
  • Perfecting our process
  • Volunteers
  • Natural disasters
  • corruption

Other Ways You Can Help

Please check out our social media sites list below and share them if you have a free moment.

  • Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/OfficialHappyHomes/ 
  • Twitter:  https://twitter.com/_Happy_Homes 
  • Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/official_happy_homes/

The more people we show the true value of plastic the quicker society can become less plastic dependent and help save our planet.
