story:
Short Summary

We are a group of sustainable food systems Masters students, Stephanie Benoit, Clara Ramin, and McKayla Baker, and our professor, Olivia Sylvester, all passionate farmers. We recently learned that Costa Rica uses more harmful pesticides per capita than any other country in the world. So, to offer healthy food options to students and rural community members, we created an small organic farm to grow our own pesticide-free food and to teach community children learn about nature, safe farming practices, and healthy food. Everything we do on this farm is volunteer work and we need your help. Your support will allow us to hire a community member to maintain our farm during summer months when no students are on campus and help it reach its full potential.

What We Need & What You Get

We are fundraising for $5,000 to pay for one part-time community member to maintain our farm while students are not on campus for two consecutive summers and two December breaks. This works out to 5 months per year (June, July, August, September and December) starting in December 2018. Having a part-time staff member means we can: 1) maintain soil nourished, 2) weed and clear out the many wild species that take over our garden if we are not careful, 3) keep a year round harvest which means a year round farmer’s market for university staff and community members, 4) host and receive children and refugees as volunteers in our garden during the summer and December break (this is also when children are on school holidays and gardening can be something they can do here as a family activity). If we do not reach our entire goal, we will hire a community member for less time (e.g., if we raise 3000 USD, we can hire them for 6 months instead of 10). 

Your donations will allow us to hire a part-time staff member for all their hard work maintaining this farm. If your donation is 5 USD or more, we will include your name and country on a mural to be displayed on our farm! If your donation is 50 USD or more, we will send you a UPEACE organic farm T-shirt (optional)!

    The Impact

    In less than 2 years, we have created a successful organic farm that has been used as a classroom for over 200 Master’s students from over 20 countries. We have hosted 3 workshops with community school children, one workshop is now part of the local school’s curriculum. We have hosted Indigenous farmer’s from Costa Rica to share their traditional food and medicine knowledge with community youth. Our farm not only produces food but it is a growing site for intergenerational and cross-cultural knowledge sharing about sustainability and peace. All of our work has been done using small donations like yours as well as dedication from student and community volunteers.

    By hiring of a staff member during the months that we have no volunteers, we can help ensure that the garden is ready for when students start their school year - and we can make sure this space is being used by our local community all year round. 

    The University for Peace has provided us the land and access to water to farm, we have a strong network of excited community members and Master's student who want to learn to garden, our sales from farmers markets provide income to buy organic inputs (e.g., charcoal, seeds) - all we need is a little help running our farm when our student volunteers are not on campus!

    Risks & Challenges

    With your help will we be able to hire a part-time worker from our community to help us maintain our beautiful garden, to run local farmer’s markets, and to host children and refugees in our garden, and to help the new Masters students integrate into the farm when their academic year starts. What is always challenging is to continue to find funding to keep a staff member with us beyond these 2 years. We will overcome this challenge by searching for another source of 2 year funding as soon as this campaign closes - this way we can ensure that we can continue to employ a community member on our sustainable farm.  

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can not contribute financially, that does not mean you can not help us! Please spread the word and make some noise about our organic farming campaign at the University for Peace! You can use the Indiegogo share tools to get the word out to your friend, family, and social media networks. We are deeply thankful for your time and support.

We are fundraising for $5,000 to pay for one part-time community member to maintain our farm while students are not on campus for two consecutive summers and two December breaks. This works out to 5 months per year (June, July, August, September and December) starting in December 2018. Having a part-time staff member means we can: 1) maintain soil nourished, 2) weed and clear out the many wild species that take over our garden if we are not careful, 3) keep a year round harvest which means a year round farmer’s market for university staff and community members, 4) host and receive children and refugees as volunteers in our garden during the summer and December break (this is also when children are on school holidays and gardening can be something they can do here as a family activity). If we do not reach our entire goal, we will hire a community member for less time (e.g., if we raise 3000 USD, we can hire them for 6 months instead of 10). 
Your donations will allow us to hire a part-time staff member for all their hard work maintaining this farm. If your donation is 5 USD or more, we will include your name and country on a mural to be displayed on our farm! If your donation is 50 USD or more, we will send you a UPEACE organic farm T-shirt (optional)!



The Impact
In less than 2 years, we have created a successful organic farm that has been used as a classroom for over 200 Master’s students from over 20 countries. We have hosted 3 workshops with community school children, one workshop is now part of the local school’s curriculum. We have hosted Indigenous farmer’s from Costa Rica to share their traditional food and medicine knowledge with community youth. Our farm not only produces food but it is a growing site for intergenerational and cross-cultural knowledge sharing about sustainability and peace. All of our work has been done using small donations like yours as well as dedication from student and community volunteers.
By hiring of a staff member during the months that we have no volunteers, we can help ensure that the garden is ready for when students start their school year - and we can make sure this space is being used by our local community all year round. 
The University for Peace has provided us the land and access to water to farm, we have a strong network of excited community members and Master's student who want to learn to garden, our sales from farmers markets provide income to buy organic inputs (e.g., charcoal, seeds) - all we need is a little help running our farm when our student volunteers are not on campus!


Risks & Challenges
With your help will we be able to hire a part-time worker from our community to help us maintain our beautiful garden, to run local farmer’s markets, and to host children and refugees in our garden, and to help the new Masters students integrate into the farm when their academic year starts. What is always challenging is to continue to find funding to keep a staff member with us beyond these 2 years. We will overcome this challenge by searching for another source of 2 year funding as soon as this campaign closes - this way we can ensure that we can continue to employ a community member on our sustainable farm.  


Other Ways You Can Help
If you can not contribute financially, that does not mean you can not help us! Please spread the word and make some noise about our organic farming campaign at the University for Peace! You can use the Indiegogo share tools to get the word out to your friend, family, and social media networks. We are deeply thankful for your time and support.

story:
Promicanje izgradnje ekoloških kuća e+HH i stvaranje preduvjeta održivog načina života

Projekt e+HH

FACEBOOK  |  WEB  |  BLOG

Realizacijom projekta „Promicanje izgradnje ekoloških kuća e+HH i stvaranje preduvjeta održivog načina života“ (skraćeni naziv: Projekt e+HH) Udruga za promicanje kreativnog izražavanja Studio 8 nastoji potaknuti izgradnju ekoloških kuća od drveta i slame, s višestrukim ekološkim doprinosima. Istovremeno, izgradnjom ovakvih kuća podrazumijeva se i angažman lokalnih tvrtki i stručnjaka odnosno potiče gospodarska aktivnost. U RH je izgradnja ekoloških kuća u začecima. Izgrađeno je tek nekoliko objekata i uglavnom je riječ o entuzijastima koji su se upustili u njihovu izgradnju.

Projekt e+HH provodi se kroz 3 faze:

  1. faza: Izgradnja ekološke kuće od drveta i slame e+HH
  2. faza: Izgradnja permakulturnog vrta
  3. faza: Održivost projekta, koja se provodi na način ispitivanja prednosti stanovanja u kući e+HH, pružanju informacija o izgradnji i stanovanju u kući e+HH, te uzgoj hrane u permakulturnom vrtu i stvaranje održivog načina života

Izgradnja ekološke kuće e+HH

Ovim projektom žele se:

  • smanjiti operativni troškovi stanovanja, troškove energenata, te troškove održavanja
  • poboljšati kvaliteta stanovanja uslijed poboljšane kvalitete zraka u zatvorenim prostorima i održavanja ugodne temperature kako ljeti tako i zimi
  • smanjiti štetni utjecaj na okoliš upotrebom prirodnih građevinskih materijala, čime je emisija CO2 za njihovu proizvodnju svedena na minimum ili je uopće nema
  • potaknuti korištenje obnovljivih izvora energije
  • stvoriti preduvjeti održivog načina života uzgojem hrane u permakulturnom vrtu.

Zainteresiranost za gradnju ekološki održive kuće postoji, no zbog nepoznavanja ovakvog načina izgradnje Projekt e+HH pun je izazova. Predstavlja jedan od pionirskih zahvata na našem području. Uspjeli smo projektirati osim drvene konstrukcije i vanjskih zidova izgrađenih od bala slame i ostale dijelove kuće od ekološki prihvatljivih materijala, kao što su obloge unutrašnjih zidova, pregrade te strop. Realizacijom ovog projekta nastojimo potaknuti ekološku izgradnju i održivost, te osviješteni način života koji se dalje proteže na ekološki uzgoj hrane u permakulturnom vrtu.

Dvije godine tražili smo adekvatnu lokaciju za projekt e+HH, koja će zadovoljiti ne samo prirodno okruženje, već i adekvatnu veličinu parcele za gradnju permakulturnog vrta.

Sinergijom Udruge Studio 8, koja daje svoju tehničku podršku, tvrtke Studio 8 d.o.o., koja ulaže rad i odriče se svoje zarade, te privatnog investitora zatvorena je financijska konstrukcija I. faze projekta. Privatni investitor, član Udruge Studio 8, prodao je svoju ekskluzivnu obiteljsku kuću i novac uložio u kupnju zemljišta, ishođenje projektne dokumentacije, podmirenje komunalnih davanja, te podmirenje jednog dijela troškova izgradnje objekta. Međutim, tijekom izgradnje objekta, zbog upotrebe fungicida koji su namijenjeni za zaštitu drveta, došlo je do požara, koji je uništio do temelja sve do tada izgrađeno. Unatoč financijskom gubitku ne odustajemo od projekta izgradnje ekološke kuće e+HH, već nas je ovaj izazov samo učvrstio u našoj težnji promicanja izgradnje eko održivih objekata. Svoja iskustva želimo podijeliti s drugim korisnicima koji također žele izgraditi ekološku kuću od drveta i slame. Sredstva iz akcije Indiegogo namijenjena su završetku I. faze projekta, a prije svega namirenju gubitka prouzrokovanog požarom.

Osim promicanja izgradnje ekoloških kuća i zaštite okoliša dodatne koristi Udruge Studio 8 i tvrtke Studio 8 su:

  • provedba izrade informacije o energetskoj učinkovitosti i uštedi energije - očekuje se smanjenje troškova energenata, te smanjenje troškova održavanja objekta
  • provedba izrade komparacije troškova izgradnje ekološkog objekta u odnosu na  konvencionalno izgrađen objekt.

U petogodišnjem proučavanju izgradnje kuće od slame vjerovali smo da postoji tržište i zainteresiranost za ovakvu izgradnju. Što nam je i potvrđeno, te je samo u kratkom razdoblju tromjesečne izgradnje, bez ikakvih dodatnih ulaganja u propagandu, bilo je više zainteresiranih ozbiljnih, potencijalnih investitora.

 

English version

Promotion of eco-friendly house e+HH and creating the preconditions for sustainable lifestyle

Project e+HH

FACEBOOK  |  WEB  |  BLOG

 

Throug the realization of the project „Promoting the construction of eco-friendly houses e+HH and creating the preconditions for a sustainable lifestyle" (short name: Project e+HH), Association Studio 8  strive to encourage the construction of ecological wood and straw houses with multiple ecological contributions. At the same time, the construction of such houses also implies the engagement of local companies and experts and promotes economic activity. In the Republic of Croatia the construction of eco-friendly houses is at the beginning. Only a few eco-friendly houses were built by enthusiasts who had started to build them.

The Project e+HH is implemented through 3 phases:

  1. Phase: Contruction of eco-friendly house of wood and straw e+HH
  2. Phase: Construction of a permaculture garden
  3. Phase: Sustainability of the Project e+HH, which is carried out as a way of examining the benefits of housing in eco-friendly house e+HH, providing information of construction and housing in eco-friendly house e+HH, and cultivating food in a permaculture garden and creating a sustainable lifestyle

Construction of eco-friendly house e+HH

 With this project we want:

  • to reduce operational cost of housing, energy costs and maintenance costs
  •  to improve the quality of living due to improved indoor air quality and maintaining a comfortable temperature both in summer and winter
  • to  reduce negative environmental impact by using of natural materials in order to reduce CO2 emissions
  • to use of renewable energy sources
  • to create the prerequisites for a sustainable way of life by cultivating food in a permaculture garden.

There is an interest in building an environmentally sustainable house, but due to the lack of awareness of this type of construction, the Project e+HH is full of challenges. It represents one of pioneering projects in our area. We have been able to design apart from the wooden structure and the exterior walls made of block straw, designing other parts of the house from ecologicaly acceptable materials such as lining of interior walls, partitions and ceilings. By implementing this project, we strive to promote ecological construction and sustainability and a conscious way of life that further extends to ecological food cultivation in a permaculture garden.

For the last two years we have been looking for an adequate location for the Project e+HH, which would satisty not only the natural environment but also the adequate size of the plot for the construction of a permaculture garden.

Synergies of Associations Studio 8, which provides its techical support to company Studio 8 d.o.o., which invest and renounces its profits, and the private investor closed the financial construction of the first phase of Project e+HH.The private investor, a member of Associations Studio 8, sold his exclusive family house and invested money in land purchase, obtaining project documentation, settling public utility charges, and settling part of the cost of building an object. However, during the construction of the house, due to the use of fungicide intended for wood protection, there was a fire that destroyed the foundation until then built. Despite the financial loss, we do not give up on the project of building the eco-friendly house e+HH, but this challenge has only strengthened us in our desire to promote the construction of eco-sustainable houses. We want to share our experiences with other users who also want to build an eco-friendly house of wood and straw. The funds from the Indiegogo action are intended for the completion 1st phase of the Project e+HH and, above all, for dealing with the loss caused by the fire.

Apart from promoting the construction of eco-friendly house and environmental protection, the additional benefits of Associations Studio 8 and company Studio 8 are:

  • implementation of information on energy efficiency and energy savings – energy costs are expected to decrease and maintenance costs will be reduced
  • implemantation of comparison of the cost of building an ecological house in relation to a conventionally constructed house.

In a five year study of straw construction, we belived there was a market and interest in this kind of construction. What has also been confirmed, and only in the short period of three months of contruction, with no additional investment in propaganda, there were more interested serious potential investors.

story:
Our story

Through education, science and sailing expeditions along the South African Coastline, we’re working to stem the tide of plastic entering the ocean, before it is too late.

We’ll set sail to educate school children and those with an ear to listen to become responsible users of plastic and make informed decisions about how and when they use plastic and the impact it has on our oceans.

Eight million tons of plastic waste ends up in the ocean every year.

Over 700 species of marine life are known to suffer directly from the devastating effects of plastic pollution.

The decisions we make on land concerning plastic usage ultimately end up affecting the health and sustainability of our oceans.

We’ll continue with the awareness programme we started in 2017. During 2018 we intend to set sail along the South African coastline and on the way, pay a visit to our Hope Spots. False Bay has the Cape Peninsula on one side and stretches from Cape Point (the most southern tip of Africa after Cape Agulhas) to the small village of Rooi-Els. Fishing pressure in unprotected parts of False Bay is significant and ocean pollution is as always prevalent in the area. Part of False Bay is reserved as a marine protected area and ‘no-take’ zone, creating a sanctuary for large reef fish, abalone and small sharks within an area of dense kelp forests. Rich in biodiversity, False Bay also supports a vibrant tourism economy with a wealth of cultural history.

We’ll continue our voyage along a stretch of coastline called The Cape Whale Coast (also a Hope Spot) which stretches from Rooi-Els to the picturesque town of Gansbaai. Mountains meet the sea through an intricate patchwork of estuaries, beaches and bays. Offshore, the temperate south coast currents meet cold west coast swells. These nutrient-rich waters host the African Penguin, Great White Shark, Cape Fur Seal, and three species of whale and dolphin in addition to many endemic bird species. Unfortunately, ocean pollution threatens the very existence of these ecosystems. We need to make people be aware of this – your contribution will bring us one step closer.

To learn more about Hope Spots listen as Dr Sylvia Earl explains the concept…

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

To make these annual voyages possible we need $45 000.

Your contributions will go towards the following causes:

  • help subsidize our volunteers to become Ocean Ambassadors
  • help us to produce literature to distribute at schools that we'll visit during our voyage.
  • we'll be able to attract the participation of researchers and marine biologists to help collect data that can be used to determine the state of our ocean.

Yacht Boaz aims to lead by example. Your contributions will allow us to implement some and eventually all of the following technologies to ensure that Yacht Boaz is self-sustainable:

  • install solar photovoltaic panels to produce our own electricity, a small wind turbine for when the sun isn't shining, a basic desalination system to generate our own clean drinking water from the ocean and a plastic burning furnace that will generate additional power from plastic collected from the ocean

To this end Yacht Boaz supports initiatives such as those of Racing for Water and The African Marine Waste Network to name but a few.

Our awesome rewards for your contribution are as follows:

  • Our contributions start from as little as $1 - we’ll personally thank you on Facebook
  • $5 gets you a Yacht Boaz Badge
  • For $20 we'll send you a signed copy of Gunter Pauli's 'Water Fable' 
  • $35 gets you a Yacht Boaz T-Shirt made from recycled plastic as well as badge
  • Corporate contributions for $1500 to $2000 will give you global exposure on our social media platforms and advertising on Yacht Boaz.
  • The voyage is all about our paid volunteers. For $1200 you'll sail with us for 15 days, travelling over 300 nautical miles and visit 5 harbours.

Should you join us as a volunteer you can look forward to the following unforgettable experiences:

  • We'll sail to the following harbours and explore the surrounding areas: City of Cape Town (our base camp), Houtbay, Simon’s Town, Gordon's Bay and Gansbaai.
  • You'll acquire the following skills: basic seamanship including navigation, radio procedures, knot skills, safety procedures, first-aid, introduction to snorkelling and learn to prepare and give presentations to our kids.
  • You'll learn more about:
    • the biodiversity of our ocean
    • ocean pollution and the devastating effect it has on our environment
    • yourself and how to be the best Ocean Ambassador you can be!

The Impact

Our aim is to make a difference one nautical mile at a time. The future of our oceans and the fight against plastic pollution is in the hands of our youth and Yacht Boaz will bring a message of hope and inspiration to them.

Risks & Challenges

The risks are that we don’t act! The challenge is to create as many Ocean Ambassadors as possible. Please contribute – every bit helps!

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the news and share our campaign and like our Facebook Page https://www.facebook.com/blueeconomyfund/

help us to produce literature to distribute at schools that we'll visit during our voyage.
we'll be able to attract the participation of researchers and marine biologists to help collect data that can be used to determine the state of our ocean.

Yacht Boaz aims to lead by example. Your contributions will allow us to implement some and eventually all of the following technologies to ensure that Yacht Boaz is self-sustainable:
install solar photovoltaic panels to produce our own electricity, a small wind turbine for when the sun isn't shining, a basic desalination system to generate our own clean drinking water from the ocean and a plastic burning furnace that will generate additional power from plastic collected from the ocean
To this end Yacht Boaz supports initiatives such as those of Racing for Water and The African Marine Waste Network to name but a few.
Our awesome rewards for your contribution are as follows:

Our contributions start from as little as $1 - we’ll personally thank you on Facebook
$5 gets you a Yacht Boaz Badge
For $20 we'll send you a signed copy of Gunter Pauli's 'Water Fable' 
$35 gets you a Yacht Boaz T-Shirt made from recycled plastic as well as badge
Corporate contributions for $1500 to $2000 will give you global exposure on our social media platforms and advertising on Yacht Boaz.
The voyage is all about our paid volunteers. For $1200 you'll sail with us for 15 days, travelling over 300 nautical miles and visit 5 harbours.

Should you join us as a volunteer you can look forward to the following unforgettable experiences:

We'll sail to the following harbours and explore the surrounding areas: City of Cape Town (our base camp), Houtbay, Simon’s Town, Gordon's Bay and Gansbaai.
You'll acquire the following skills: basic seamanship including navigation, radio procedures, knot skills, safety procedures, first-aid, introduction to snorkelling and learn to prepare and give presentations to our kids.
You'll learn more about:
the biodiversity of our ocean
ocean pollution and the devastating effect it has on our environment
yourself and how to be the best Ocean Ambassador you can be!




The Impact
Our aim is to make a difference one nautical mile at a time. The future of our oceans and the fight against plastic pollution is in the hands of our youth and Yacht Boaz will bring a message of hope and inspiration to them.
Risks & Challenges

The risks are that we don’t act! The challenge is to create as many Ocean Ambassadors as possible. Please contribute – every bit helps!
Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the news and share our campaign and like our Facebook Page https://www.facebook.com/blueeconomyfund/

story:
Thanks to everyone who contributed to our Aquaponics Project Part 1 (https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/aquaponics-f...).

Your contributions helped us build phase 2 and partially, phase 3.1  of the proposed plans for the shelter's Greenhouse and convert it to Aquaponics.

Your donations for this will be used to further our campaigns and partially fund the ongoing project we're currently building at Bukid kabataan shelter, an orphanage created by Caritas Manila as a response to the growing number of Filipino children lured to prostitution. The increasing number of young street dwellers and the urgent need to put up a shelter for them in a long-term program, thus requiring also a long term funding and the reason why we came up to the idea of building their own, sustainable, urban farm. 

The orphanage is located at Mahogany, General Trias, Cavite, Philippines and we're currently building an aquaponic farm for them. This indoor farm, once finished, will help the locals who's been living there benefit from the crops yields and the fish that will be produced by the system and also provide us with further research data on on topics like food security and climate resiliency, knowing that Philippines is very susceptible to earthquakes and typhoons because of its geographical location along the Pacific region near the Equator.

Here's the current status of the project, we started from Phase 2 and 3.1:

PHASE 2 INSTALLATION OF METAL SIDINGS

 

 

PHASE 3.1 - GROUND LEVELING

 

As of now, the current Phase was halted on 3.1 due to budget limitations. This aquaponic system has 7 major phases, 5 of it was all about construction and the remaining 2 phases will be dedicated for training of the people who will maintain and operate this system.

Aside from the farm from Bukid Kabataan Shelter, we will use the fund to further our marketing campaigns and build more farms like these starting in Central Luzon, Philippines, the rice capital of the Philippines in an attempt to test produce urban-grown, vertically farmed rice (specifically PSB Rc10 variant, a drought-tolerant rice which matures as fast as 106 days with a maximum yield of 7.5 tons per hectare) and fish, specifically Nile Tilapia.

We are currently working with different individuals and companies who are looking for corporate social responsibility that would be interested with our sustainability projects and we are still looking for people that could help us construct these vertical farms as soon as possible.

Once constructed, these vertical farms would only not ensure food security and revolutionize food production here in Philippines, but would be a great help to the 12-million Filipinos who's currently living in extreme poverty.

story:
English version is below

 

Hello, c'est Benjamin et Liga.

 

On est en train de développer une ferme résiliente sur l'île de Tenerife aux Canaries.

Notre but est de créer une forêt nourricière en plantant 10 000 arbres fruitiers avec les principes de la permaculture.

 

Grâce à votre participation nous allons pouvoir financer une grande diversité d'arbres et marquer ensemble d'une empreinte verte notre passage sur terre.

Vous avez la possibilité de choisir de planter des arbres spécifiques suivant notre petit catalogue et l'option (gratuite) d'avoir une étiquette personnalisée pour l'arbre, qui matérialisera votre geste pour la nature.

Notre catalogue d'arbres

Bananier

Papayer

Manguier

Palmier-Dattier

Avocatier

Kaki

Citronnier

Pomelo Rose

Macadamia

Notre but ultime étant de proposer des retraites à thème en reconnexion avec la nature, nous voulons que ce lieu soit un berceau paradisiaque où l'on transmettra notre passion du vivant. Pour se faire nous adhérons au label "Green The Desert" créé par Myriam et Jacky Boisset (voir descriptif plus bas).
 
 
 
 
 

Benjamin en bref :

 

Anciennement ingénieur aéronautique, son objectif est d'être maintenant au contact quotidien avec la terre, de cultiver des produits de qualité et d'échanger de l'énergie positive autour de lui. En créant un lieu éco-responsable où la nature est omniprésente et respectée, elle donnera le plein potentiel d'une forêt nourricière abondante. Pour ce faire, il suit actuellement un cours de conception en permaculture avec un professeur bien connu. Sur le terrain, il sera en charge d'intégrer toutes les connaissances au potager et à la forêt fruitière.

Liga en quelques mots :

 

En mettant de côté les vieilles habitudes culinaires qui étaient ancrées depuis la plus jeune enfance, elle s'est ouverte à une nouvelle passion pour la cuisine végétale vivante crue qui a également suscité un fort intérêt pour la culture du potager. Elle choisit toujours de mettre de la VIE dans l'assiette où les ingrédients proviennent d'un sol riche, vivant, organique et respectueux pour tous les êtres vivants. Elle est naturellement douée d'un grand sens du goût et de la qualité. Elle aime passer du temps en cuisine et à chaque fois c'est comme un voyage différent… comme une oeuvre d'art. Elle aime associer les couleurs, les motifs, l'abondance…

 

 
 
 

Les créateurs du label "Green the Desert" :

 
 

Nous sommes deux athlètes professionnels, passionnés de sport, de santé et d’écologie…
… et avec le désir de parcourir le monde.

Nous sommes les plus performants dans notre discipline, deux fois champions du monde.

Notre voyage nous a fait prendre conscience de l’importance de protéger notre planète et nous avons renversé toutes nos habitudes occidentales pour vivre plus harmonieusement avec notre environnement. Aujourd’hui, nous vivons dans une petite maison au milieu d’un jardin de permaculture avec zéro déchet.

Notre rêve et notre projet est « Race to Green the Desert ». Nous voulons partager nos expériences avec vous… alors bienvenue dans ce monde d’aventure cru !

 

Cliquez pour plus d'info sur le label

 
Hello, it's Benjamin and Liga.
 
We are developing a resilient farm on the island of Tenerife in the Canaries.
Our goal is to create a fruit forest by planting 10,000 fruit trees with permaculture principles.
Thanks to your participation, we will be able to finance a wide variety of trees and you will have the opportunity to draw green footprint.
You have the possibility to choose to plant specific trees according to our small catalog and have the option (free) to get a personalized tree label which will materialize your good for the nature.

Our tree catalog

Banana Tree

Papaya Tree

Mango Tree

Date Palm Tree

Avocado Tree

Persimmon Tree

Lemon Tree

Pink Pomelo Tree

Macadamia Tree

Our ultimate goal is to offer thematic retreats in reconnection with nature, we want this place to be eden garden where we will transmit our passion for life. To do so, we are in partnership with the label "Green The Desert" created by Myriam and Jacky Boisset (see description below).
 
 
 
 
 

Benjamin in brief:

 

Formerly aeronautical engineer, who found that his true goal is to be in daily contact with the earth, grow quality products and exchange energy with people. By creating an eco-friendly place where the nature is omnipresent and respected, it will give a full potential of producing an abundant edible food forest. To do so, he is currently attending a permaculture design course with a well-known Master. On the field, he will be in charge of integrating all the knowledge to the kitchen garden and the fruits forest.

Liga in a few words:

 

By letting go old culinary habits which has been part of her since birth, she opened up a new passion of plant-based raw living food which also lead to strong interest of gardening practices. She always chooses to put LIFE on the plate where ingredients come from organic rich living soil and is beneficial to all living. She is naturally gifted with great sense of taste and quality levels. She enjoys her time in kitchen, every time it is like a different journey… like an art. She loves colours, patterns, abundance…

 

 
 
 

The creators of the Label "Green The Desert":

 
 
We are two professional athletes, passionate about sport, health and ecology…
…and with a thirst to travel the world.

We are the most successful performers in our discipline… twice World Champions.

Our journey has made us aware of the importance of protecting our planet so we turned all our western habits upside down to live more harmoniously with our environment.Today we live in a small house in the middle of a permaculture garden with zero waste.

 

Our dream and our project is “Race to Green the Desert”. We want to share our experiences with you…
…so welcome to this Raw Adventure World!

 

Click for more info about the label

story:
We have just been told by a sponsor that for every $1 you contribute, they will match the contribution - meaning that if we reach our target of $30,000 we will get $60,000!

This includes money already pledged.

The sponsor has agreed to continue their generous support up to the end of this campaign!!!!! 

 

Who we are:

The Southern Ocean Carbon Company is building a seaweed farm to combat climate change, and we need your help to get it established. 

We are an ambitious start-up company based on the wild and beautiful island of Tasmania, and we are building a kelp farm to confirm what all of the research is suggesting: that seaweed has great potential to capture carbon on a significant scale in order to fight climate change. 

 

Our mission to Save the Planet:

It is clear that action needs to be taken to combat climate change, and one of the key strategies is to reduce the amount of excess carbon in the atmosphere.

That, in a nutshell, is what we are about: we establish a seaweed farm, grow seaweed that draws carbon from the atmosphere, and then measure and process the carbon we capture – thus reducing carbon emissions and helping in the fight against climate change.

 

How we are fighting Climate Change:

The plan is simple: first, we grow spores of temperature tolerant giant kelp on small strings in our hatchery, which are then put onto larger, non-plastic sisal rope and put into the sea at the farm you help us to build. We then let nature take its course - using only sunlight and the nutrients in the ocean and watch it grow, grow, grow!

When the seaweed is fully-grown the magic happens - the critical step to lock in the carbon we have captured.

This will be done through one of three methods: biochar, biofuel or our preferred method: reintroducing our rope directly into the areas where kelp forests once were; giving back to the environment whilst capturing and locking in carbon.

But first we need the means to create/scale our seaweed farm and produce crops year-on-year, and we need your help to make that happen.

We have 5km of rope ready to go in the water, and have earmarked over a thousand hectares of potential lease sites for our seaweed farm, as well as the lease we have currently in the D’Entrecasteaux Channel. We have already put 900m in the water on our trial site, and are seeing incredible growth of endemic algae species. 

We have started, but there is work to be done!

 

Your Contribution:

A contribution to our Indiegogo campaign will mean that we can start the process of establishing a farm on a decent scale, putting large numbers of anchors, buoys and rope in the ocean to grow the seaweed, which will capture and lock in the carbon.

We estimate that we need $30,000 to get the farm established in a sustainable manner, to purchase the equipment and the infrastructure, as well as pay for the work that has to be done. 

With your contribution, we will begin to place rope in the water - how cool is that? With each dollar you donate, you will directly be placing non-plastic sisal rope into the ocean to grow seaweed. The more money you donate, the more rope we can place in the water; and the more carbon we can capture!

Your contribution will help to get the farm properly established, producing on a scale to get meaningful results.

 

How does Seaweed capture carbon?

Photosynthesis captures carbon dioxide from the atmosphere; the captured carbon is stored in the body of the seaweed. Seaweed absorbs a huge amount of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere – research has found that balanced coastal ecosystems can capture up to 20 times more carbon per acre than land forests!

In fact, its calculated that 200 million tons of carbon dioxide is being locked in by seaweed every year!

Unlike carbon sequestration through land forests, there is no risk of fire and land usage is reduced with seaweed farms. Seaweed farms also provide critical habitats for fish species, uptake nutrients from the environment and produce oxygen. Scientists have estimated that marine algae produces anywhere from 50% to 80% of the Earth’s oxygen supply.

 

Join the Fight Against Climate Change

Climate Change is real and happening, the evidence is clear: the planet’s average surface temperature has risen by about 1.14 degrees Celsius in the last 200 years, and most of this warming occurred in the last 40 years. The warming of the ocean has been readily apparent- evidence can be seen in the decrease of ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica, a loss of 279 billion tons and 148 billion tons (respectively) of ice per year! Where does the ice go? Well sea levels are also on the rise, globally the sea has risen around 20 cm in the last 100 years, but in the last 20 years it has nearly doubled that of the previous years. On top of all this we are seeing the increase of natural disasters and extreme weather events such as heat waves, cyclones, bushfires and flooding.

We still have time to make a difference. To avoid more impacts to our earth we need to limit warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius by 2030, to do so we need to reduce the amount of excess carbon entering the atmosphere. We have a way to do that!

Currently in Australia, the average carbon footprint for a person in a year is the equivalent of 15.39 tonnes. To beat climate change, we need to limit it to only 2 tonnes.

That is why we want to build this seaweed farm – to reduce the amount of carbon entering the atmosphere, and help in the fight against climate change.

We are ready to start but we need the funds to support us in doing that.

 

Risks and challenges:

  • Ensuring that we select the correct seaweed species for a particular sites characteristics and that we do not create an imbalance in doing so. In working closely with marine scientists we will be looking to expand on the level of knowledge in this respect and commit to share our results freely.

  • Community opposition to seaweed farming. What we are doing will not be visible from above the water; our ropes will be attached to buoys, and as the seaweed grows it will drop deeper in the water column. We are aware that we are placing a man-made object in the water, but the rope we are using is non-plastic-sisal rope and if it does come unattached (we will do our utmost to ensure it doesn’t) the rope will eventually disintegrate, and will leave no plastic in the ocean.

  • Carbon re-entering the atmosphere. Key to our activity is that the carbon stays locked in long term, our aim is to have it locked in as long as any land based sequestration activity does. We are actively looking at biochar production as an effective win/win, which we are prioritising as part of our early work.
  • Getting sufficient biomass from our leases to effectively lock in carbon. This is why we are engaging marine scientists to assist us, and committing to learning and adjusting as we evolve.
  • Making sure that we are ourselves carbon neutral in our efforts. To this end our vessels, workshops and other inputs all need to have as little impact as possible.

 

Other ways you can help

If you can't afford to contribute now, we understand, times are tough in many places. But please spread the word and share our story with your friends! The more people who know, the more effect we can have. We truly think we can make a positive difference for the planet - but we do need help!

Share our Indiegogo page and spread the love for the planet.

We are ready to start but we need the funds to support us in doing that.
 

Risks and challenges:

Ensuring that we select the correct seaweed species for a particular sites characteristics and that we do not create an imbalance in doing so. In working closely with marine scientists we will be looking to expand on the level of knowledge in this respect and commit to share our results freely.
Community opposition to seaweed farming. What we are doing will not be visible from above the water; our ropes will be attached to buoys, and as the seaweed grows it will drop deeper in the water column. We are aware that we are placing a man-made object in the water, but the rope we are using is non-plastic-sisal rope and if it does come unattached (we will do our utmost to ensure it doesn’t) the rope will eventually disintegrate, and will leave no plastic in the ocean.
Carbon re-entering the atmosphere. Key to our activity is that the carbon stays locked in long term, our aim is to have it locked in as long as any land based sequestration activity does. We are actively looking at biochar production as an effective win/win, which we are prioritising as part of our early work.
Getting sufficient biomass from our leases to effectively lock in carbon. This is why we are engaging marine scientists to assist us, and committing to learning and adjusting as we evolve.
Making sure that we are ourselves carbon neutral in our efforts. To this end our vessels, workshops and other inputs all need to have as little impact as possible.


 
Other ways you can help
If you can't afford to contribute now, we understand, times are tough in many places. But please spread the word and share our story with your friends! The more people who know, the more effect we can have. We truly think we can make a positive difference for the planet - but we do need help!
Share our Indiegogo page and spread the love for the planet.

story:
Meet NUMA'LO-  a zero waste refillery van based in Guåhan. Numa’lo provides a new and exciting earth-friendly shopping experience, where you “weigh and pay” for products without the wasteful packaging. We refill your containers with locally-made and eco-friendly soaps, cleaners, detergents, and so much more! We also sell “zero waste” accessories to replace the single-use plastics in your everyday life. Our mobile business will operate “pop up” style at various locations around the island every week. We make it even more convenient for you with our home delivery service, where we refill your containers right from our van to your doorstep. 

Zero Waste = Environmental Advocacy:

(picture taken by Cami Egurrola for Micronesia Climate Change Alliance)

Our goal is to provide you with the ease and accessibility of adapting “zero waste” habits. Zero waste is not a trend. It’s a lifestyle change that is being adopted across the globe as more and more people make the connection between waste pollution and our environment.

(If you aren’t familiar with the devastating effects plastic has on our lands and waters, please educate yourself by watching the From Our Nånas, For Our Nenis video series). 

We aim to be a “zero waste” business, which simply means we try our best to produce as little waste as possible by making small changes to our everyday routines and habits. Our hope and vision is to inspire you to embark on your zero waste journey! It is only through our individual actions that we can build collective resiliency and ripple communal change. Guåhan is not a big island, but our community has a big heart- for our lands, our waters, our culture, and more important- our people. Zero waste is in favor of our island, and joining us on this mission is one step towards securing a safe and healthy island for our next generations to come.

Mission & Vision:

Our vision is rooted in the CHamoru concept of INAFA'MAOLEK, meaning to restore harmony with respect & responsibility for i taotao-ta, i tåno'-ta, i hanom-ta, yan i tåsi-ta (our people, land, water, and ocean). NUMA'LO is also the CHamoru word for revive, do again, or return. We believe that being stewards of our island is an ancestral practice that we must revive within the community through environmental advocacy and activism. We envision a Guåhan that is protected, secure, and safe from the threat of climate crisis.

Our mission is three-pronged: educate the island about the plastic pandemic, inspire the community to be conscious consumers, and uplift local businesses as our primary vendors. 

It is also crucial to mention this business is being initiated by Micronesia Climate Change Alliance (MCCA), a grassroots non-profit seeking to create community-centered solutions to the climate crisis. This business would not be possible if not for their abundant support and guidance.

Rewards:

With every donation above $15, you'll receive an award! We've partnered with Maisa, a local social entrepreneurship aimed at promoting waste consciousness and mindful consumption- and we have some of their beautiful zero waste starter products to gift our donors. We also recently partnered with Eco-Friendly Options, a business that provides affordable eco-friendly alternatives to single-use plastics and styrofoam. Check out the "Perks" section of our page!

We're excited to share our first in-house product: the Numa'lo grocery tote! Made out of Global Organic Textile Standards (GOTS) certified cotton with pockets customized to hold bottles, bulky containers, and all the refill containers galore! 

 

***IMPORTANT INFORMATION*** After your donation, you will receive an email within 24 hours detailing how your rewards will be received. Guåhan residents must pick up rewards at MCCA's office in Tamuning. All non-Guåhan donors will have rewards shipped to the address provided. All details will be provided in the email.

How Your Donations Help:

We're asking the community to help us forge this amazing opportunity for our island with a fundraising goal of $10,000. With these funds, we plan to purchase and outfit a van, build startup inventory, and pay our small two-person team. 

  • We're immensely grateful that MCCA has agreed to lease us a van! Funds from this campaign would mainly go towards the van build, which includes flooring, walls, shelving, and storage (including cost for material, tools, and installation).
  • We also need to purchase special containers and accessories to hold and handle our refillable products, including barrels, scoops, funnels, cleaners. etc.
  • As mentioned, we aim to source local businesses as our main vendors, so paying them fairly for their creative efforts and products is vital.
  • Lastly, our small team offers a tenacious willingness to build this amazing opportunity for our community, so starting salaries are in mind too.

Other Ways to Help:

We understand that not all may be able to make a financial contribution, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  •  Share our campaign to spread awareness about our mission and service!
  • Follow and share our Instagram @numalorefillery
  • Connect with us if you have any suggestions/recommendations about products we should stock or local companies we should source!
  • Embark on your plastic-free journey today! It doesn’t take buying new things or reusable items to begin this lifestyle. It starts with a firm decision to refuse and reduce plastic and reuse and repurpose what you already have. 

Conclusion:

(picture taken by Cami Egurrola)

The peril of plastic is often underestimated because we do not understand how we directly contribute to this system. We purchase, we toss, then we purchase again. We don’t see where our trash goes after it is cast into the garbage or how this waste is processed- but here on our island, there is something we do see: We see our beaches littered with trash. We see our jungles cluttered with waste.

Numa'lo is just one solution we can provide to the plastic pandemic on our island. Our mission invites people to become protectors of our island by treating the materials we use and create as valuable gifts to be honored and repurposed— not like trash. We believe that change is possible for Guåhan when we work together and act earnestly in favor of our community and our island as one.

We don’t see where our trash goes after it is cast into the garbage or how this waste is processed- but here on our island, there is something we do see: We see our beaches littered with trash. We see our jungles cluttered with waste.
Numa'lo is just one solution we can provide to the plastic pandemic on our island. story:
Together, Let's Make the Change

Let's replace the plastic-packaged products we use every day with modern, organic, plastic-free skin and body care. 

Your pledge will help us create new aluminum and paper packaging so that we can deliver our organic (and vegan!) products to you plastic-free. 

We recommend THE ESSENTIALS, which includes everything you need to get clean AND green – body wash, shampoo, conditioner, deodorant, hand sanitizer and lip balm.

Why?

Only 7% of all plastic is ever recycled – and can only be recycled 2-3 times.  

In the last century, we’ve dumped over 150 million metric tons of plastic into our oceans. That’s enough plastic waste to cover the ENTIRE SURFACE of the MOON. And at our current rate, we will add 8 million metric tons (equivalent to 32,000 jumbo jet planes) this year, and the rate continues to accelerate. 

 

Life After Plastic: Help Save Our Oceans. 

Let’s support the massive efforts underway to clean up and restore our oceans by ceasing to fill them with plastic in the first place.

 

 

 

We stand behind your pledge.

We offer 100% money-back guarantee on all of our pledges if you are not happy with the quality of our products.

We'd love to share some reviews about our products currently sold in 100% post-consumer plastic. Products that – with your help – will soon be sold only in aluminum and paper. 

Here's a few of the hundreds of 5 star reviews you can find online:

 

 

About The Products:

 

 

Lather it Forward

In this moment of a global pandemic, some of us are in a better financial position to support others and give them access to Alpine products. Each LATHER IT FORWARD pledge makes more COMMUNITY PACKS of essentials available to those most financially impacted by these times – so if you have the means, please consider making a “Lather It Forward” pledge so that others can live a #LifeAfterPlastic.  

 

 

Aluminum: Durable. Rust-proof. Lightweight. 

Plastic can only be downcycled but aluminum can be recycled almost infinitely. And because it’s so lightweight, shipping aluminum saves millions of pounds of carbon emissions per year.  

 

Why Paper and Paperboard? Renewable. Recyclable. Compostable.

The American forest products industry typically plants five trees for every one harvested. Paper and Paperboard are easily recycled, are two of the most commonly recycled materials, and of all packaging materials, are the most compostable. 

 

 

OceanKind: 
A Symbol For Change.  

The OceanKind symbol signifies that the packaging it’s on is completely plastic-free. That means no plastic bottles, seals, or even labels. We envision the OceanKind symbol uniting like-minded brands to commit to the same goal and proudly communicate that commitment to consumers through packaging, advertising, social media, and websites. 

 

 

TWEET THIS NOW:

Plastic has been polluting our planet for too long. Help @AlpineProvision Repackage the Future and create a #LifeAfterPlastic bit.ly/2KcZZqc

story:
Hi everyone, I’m Aaron! Let me make you some tea and tell you about this BEHEMOTH of a project I've been working on for a year.

I've been using nature as a free backdrop for my creativity since I first bought a camera.  I decided it was about time to return the favor to two of nature’s most important community organizers: trees and sea turtles. Enter MY DEBUT ALBUM, Notes of Nature. An album created specifically ABOUT and FOR nature. I couldn’t think of a better way to support the planet other than making some art and getting everyone involved in the effort and contributing to the cause. This is why 100% of the proceeds are being donated to save sea turtles and plant a bunch of trees! The donation campaign begins Earth Day and will run through the release of the album on May 14th and beyond! With as little as $5, you have planted 2 ½ trees and helped save a sea turtle!
And I’ve even made some rewards of my own for those of you that come on this journey with me. See below or click on the donation link, to see a full list of rewards for contributing to the cause.


You can also help by streaming and sharing the album when it comes out! No effort is too small and I am thankful for all your support for me and this project. 

More about Notes of Nature:
Notes of Nature takes 10 compositions from different composers and cultures and combines them with 40 of my musical friends from all over the world, to create an album that takes us on an Aaron-themed adventure through nature as seen through the eyes of these artists/me. From a symphony orchestra made largely out of iphone recordings, to turtle adoptions, to exploring my own 501(c)(3) desert startup, to a friend of a Peruvian shaman, inspirations by Yo-Yo Ma in China, non-stop messages to and from Indonesia, Iran, Spain, the US, Argentina, Australia, Kazakhstan etc. and so so many more fun stories to tell from this project. I can't thank enough this collective of musicians who donated their time on this album, I am utterly grateful and honored to call them my friends (don't worry I'm going to thank you all way harder later). It would have not been possible without their help. Notes of Nature is in complete alignment with the sustainable goals of the UN, by seeking to make a small impact environmentally by performing/informing through music . Notes of Nature is global in its music, it’s musicians, and it’s mission to aid organizations that plant trees and help turtles all over the world.

Song List:

Icaro - Aaron Sinclair / Carolina Araoz 

Air - Hiromi Uehara

Storm - Antonio Vivaldi 

On A Quiet Lake - Florence Price

Between Ice - Aaron Sinclair  

Fire Dance - Manuel De Falla 

One Summers Day - Joe Hisaishi

Ocean Sky - Aaron Sinclair 

Garden Song - Hidatsa Tribe/Keith Bear

Lark Ascending - Ralph Vaughn-Williams
