story:
Tubbataha Reef is one of the last refuges for sharks remaining on the planet.  It provides protection to critically endangered species, serves as a sanctuary where a variety of species thrive, and redistributes life into the surrounding waters. This rare beacon of hope in Southeast Asia represents an oceanic oasis at the heart of an overexploited, overfished desert. It is a vestige of what the oceans once were, and a brilliant model for what they should be again.

Despite all of this, we know very little about the sharks that call this unique UNESCO World Heritage Site home, and a research expedition is desperately needed to unlock its potential.  Our team, which includes an intrepid researcher spending four months at the ranger station on this remote atoll, will conduct the first comprehensive shark survey within Tubbataha Reefs Natural Park.  Our expedition will explore the secrets behind the stunning biodiversity of this reef, revealing the key to repopulating the sharks of the Coral Triangle and uncovering information that can help keep our oceans alive. Is Tubbataha home to Asia's most productive tiger shark nurseries? Where do the whale sharks that frequent this reef travel, and are they venturing into the dangerous waters of the South China Sea to reproduce?  This expedition represents an unprecedented effort to understand these animals so we can work for their protection.  Join us now and be a part of the solution.

#SharkEden

What is Expedition Shark?

On May 7, 2015, a team of the world's top shark scientists will travel to Tubbataha Reefs Natural Park to conduct a groundbreaking assessment of sharks and rays within the park. Tubbataha is a remote tropical atoll located in the Sulu Sea, Philippines approximately 150km from the nearest port.  Lying directly in the heart of the Coral Triangle, Tubbataha is an essential sanctuary for the rapidly disappearing sharks of Southeast Asia. With your help, our experts will accomplish the following:

  • Conduct a comprehensive survey and a full assessment of shark biodiversity in the park using non-invasive methods such as Remote Underwater Video (BRUV/RUV) and Underwater Visual Surveys (UVS).
  • Determine and track the undiscovered migration patterns and behavior of sharks. If our data proves that threatened sharks travel outside the boundaries of the park and into the dangerous waters of the South China Sea, we can push for international protection against target fisheries, bycatch, and oil and gas exploration.
  • Figure out why Tubbataha is one of the only places in the Philippines where tiger sharks are seen regularly. These sharks are all juveniles, suggesting that Tubbataha is potentially a rare tiger shark breeding ground.  Our research will help to determine where these sharks come from, and where they are going.
  • Learn where whale sharks migrate and reproduce using sophisticated satellite tags.  This information is essential to the survival of these animals, as without a safe and healthy place to breed, they stand little chance at ongoing survival.

The Explorers

Alessandro Ponzo - Alessandro is the director of the Large Marine Vertebrates Project (LAMAVE). He has worked hard to conserve marine wildlife around the planet for almost 20 years, and is the brains and passion behind the expedition. Dedicated to ocean conservation, his only distraction is finding the best pizza in the world.

Gonzalo Araujo - Gonzalo joined LAMAVE in July 2012 to help protect the world’s largest fish. His focus is studying the whale shark populations of the Bohol Sea, including their migratory patterns and feeding ecology.  

Jake Levenson - Jake works to design and build mobile apps, marine animal tags and unmanned aerial vehicles for ocean conservation. Armed with an array of tech-gear and an infectious enthusiasm for marine conservation, Jake will be on hand to analyze and calibrate all our equipment, deploy behavioral recording tags and lead acoustic monitoring efforts.

Marissa Fox - A surfer and corporate lawyer turned dive instructor, Marissa heads up the policy and conservation work for LAMAVE. When she’s not taking photos of fish, Marissa enjoys yoga, all things spicy, and not sitting still. 

Ryan Murray  - An Irish man with saltwater in his blood, Ryan is a LAMAVE marine biologist with a passion for conservation, curry and adventure.  His adventure to Tubbataha will also be yours as he brings you face to face with the sharks and provides an intimate look at the castaway life of the Tubbataha ranger station.

Sally Snow - Zoologist, Filmmaker, Presenter, Blogger – A broadcaster in the UK but a shark researcher in the Philippines, Sally first studied whale sharks with WWF-Philippines before joining LAMAVE in 2012. She has set up and run several projects and is responsible for the production of LAMAVE’s media content. When she's not freediving, she's blogging on SHARK TAILS.   
Simon Pierce - Simon has studied sharks and ray all across the world. Founder of the Marine Megafauna Foundation, he has been collaborating with LAMAVE since 2013 (in a greater plan to conquer the world!) A leader in whale shark conservation, he is deploying satellite tags all across the globe to better understand their migration. www.simonjpierce.com
Steve De Neef - Steve is an award winning photojournalist and videographer specializing in conservation, documentary and underwater stories, and LAMAVE's chief photographer. He is an avid scuba and free diver, surfer, all-round waterman and Belgian chocolate lover. www.stevedeneef.com


FAQ
  1. How important is Tubbataha Reef?  

    As keystone species, sharks maintain a balance in the oceans, and are essential to the health of marine ecosystems and coral reefs.  Tubbataha is rare a shark nursery and represents the last refuge for sharks before a dangerous expanse of ocean where sharks are still regularly hunted for their fins, meat, and oil.  

  2. Will this expedition help sharks? 
    Absolutely! Tubbataha is protected, but it represents only a small area in an overfished oceanic desert.  If we can establish why Tubbataha is such a productive location for sharks and where these sharks breed and migrate, we can use this information to push for international protection that can make a huge difference for shark populations worldwide. The data we collect will also help mitigate oil and gas activities that are encroaching on this sensitive region.

  3. What makes your team qualified to lead this expedition? 
    Our team represents the next generation of internationally acclaimed shark scientists, conservation experts, professional journalists, and technology junkies.  We regularly work with international authorities on conservation policy, our work has been featured in top scientific journals, and we have a combined 70 years of experience in the field. Most importantly, we're all full-time shark researchers or conservationists who love what we do and are totally committed to the protection of these animals.

  4. What happens if this expedition is not funded?
    Without this expedition, we won't have access to information essential for the conservation of this shark eden. Is Tubbataha a tiger shark nursery?  Do sharks migrate from Tubbataha into the unprotected South China Sea? Answers to these questions may mean the difference for the future of sharks and a healthy ocean in Southeast Asia.

  5. What happens after the expedition?
    Analysis analysis analysis! We will work hard to analyze the data we collect during the expedition so we can push for the targeted protection of important shark habitats in Southeast Asia. We'll also publish any findings and release several films documenting the expedition. 

  6. Can I join the expedition?
    Yes! Join our expedition crew and help us make history for sharks.  Two spots are available on our research vessel -- see our "Perks" section for information on how to to join. If sailing the high seas isn't your cup of tea, you can join the expedition remotely by sponsoring an underwater video system, donating a satellite tag that we'll attach to a whale shark, or making a donation to our campaign and following our regular updates.  Anything helps!

  7. Are there any terms and conditions associated with the perks?
    Yes. Please visit our Terms and Conditions page.
story_txt:
Tubbataha Reef is one of the last refuges for sharks remaining on the planet.  It provides protection to critically endangered species, serves as a sanctuary where a variety of species thrive, and redistributes life into the surrounding waters. This rare beacon of hope in Southeast Asia represents an oceanic oasis at the heart of an overexploited, overfished desert. It is a vestige of what the oceans once were, and a brilliant model for what they should be again.Despite all of this, we know very little about the sharks that call this unique UNESCO World Heritage Site home, and a research expedition is desperately needed to unlock its potential.  Our team, which includes an intrepid researcher spending four months at the ranger station on this remote atoll, will conduct the first comprehensive shark survey within Tubbataha Reefs Natural Park.  Our expedition will explore the secrets behind the stunning biodiversity of this reef, revealing the key to repopulating the sharks of the Coral Triangle and uncovering information that can help keep our oceans alive. Is Tubbataha home to Asia's most productive tiger shark nurseries? Where do the whale sharks that frequent this reef travel, and are they venturing into the dangerous waters of the South China Sea to reproduce?  This expedition represents an unprecedented effort to understand these animals so we can work for their protection.  Join us now and be a part of the solution.#SharkEdenWhat is Expedition Shark?On May 7, 2015, a team of the world's top shark scientists will travel to Tubbataha Reefs Natural Park to conduct a groundbreaking assessment of sharks and rays within the park. Tubbataha is a remote tropical atoll located in the Sulu Sea, Philippines approximately 150km from the nearest port.  Lying directly in the heart of the Coral Triangle, Tubbataha is an essential sanctuary for the rapidly disappearing sharks of Southeast Asia. With your help, our experts will accomplish the following:
Conduct a comprehensive survey and a full assessment of shark biodiversity in the park using non-invasive methods such as Remote Underwater Video (BRUV/RUV) and Underwater Visual Surveys (UVS).
Determine and track the undiscovered migration patterns and behavior of sharks. If our data proves that threatened sharks travel outside the boundaries of the park and into the dangerous waters of the South China Sea, we can push for international protection against target fisheries, bycatch, and oil and gas exploration.
Figure out why Tubbataha is one of the only places in the Philippines where tiger sharks are seen regularly. These sharks are all juveniles, suggesting that Tubbataha is potentially a rare tiger shark breeding ground.  Our research will help to determine where these sharks come from, and where they are going.
Learn where whale sharks migrate and reproduce using sophisticated satellite tags.  This information is essential to the survival of these animals, as without a safe and healthy place to breed, they stand little chance at ongoing survival.

  The Explorers




Alessandro Ponzo - Alessandro is the director of the Large Marine Vertebrates Project (LAMAVE). He has worked hard to conserve marine wildlife around the planet for almost 20 years, and is the brains and passion behind the expedition. Dedicated to ocean conservation, his only distraction is finding the best pizza in the world.
Gonzalo Araujo - Gonzalo joined LAMAVE  in July 2012 to help protect the world’s largest fish. His focus is studying the whale shark populations of the Bohol Sea, including their migratory patterns and feeding ecology.  
Jake Levenson - Jake works to design and build mobile apps, marine animal tags and unmanned aerial vehicles for ocean conservation. Armed with an array of tech-gear and an infectious enthusiasm for marine conservation, Jake will be on hand to analyze and calibrate all our equipment, deploy behavioral recording tags and lead acoustic monitoring efforts. 


Marissa Fox - A surfer and corporate lawyer turned dive instructor, Marissa heads up the policy and conservation work for LAMAVE. When she’s not taking photos of fish, Marissa enjoys yoga, all things spicy, and not sitting still. 
Ryan Murray  - An Irish man with saltwater in his blood, Ryan is a LAMAVE marine biologist with a passion for conservation, curry and adventure.  His adventure to Tubbataha will also be yours as he brings you face to face with the sharks and provides an intimate look at the castaway life of the Tubbataha ranger station.

Sally Snow - Zoologist, Filmmaker, Presenter, Blogger – A broadcaster in the UK but a shark researcher in the Philippines, Sally first studied whale sharks with WWF-Philippines before joining LAMAVE in 2012. She has set up and run several projects and is responsible for the production of LAMAVE’s media content. When she's not freediving, she's blogging on SHARK TAILS.   


Simon Pierce - Simon has studied sharks and ray all across the world. Founder of the Marine Megafauna Foundation, he has been collaborating with LAMAVE since 2013 (in a greater plan to conquer the world!) A leader in whale shark conservation, he is deploying satellite tags all across the globe to better understand their migration. www.simonjpierce.com


Steve De Neef - Steve is an award winning photojournalist and videographer specializing in conservation, documentary and underwater stories, and LAMAVE's chief photographer. He is an avid scuba and free diver, surfer, all-round waterman and Belgian chocolate lover. www.stevedeneef.com




 FAQ
How important is Tubbataha Reef?  As keystone species, sharks maintain a balance in the oceans, and are essential to the health of marine ecosystems and coral reefs.  Tubbataha is rare a shark nursery and represents the last refuge for sharks before a dangerous expanse of ocean where sharks are still regularly hunted for their fins, meat, and oil.  

Will this expedition help sharks? Absolutely! Tubbataha is protected, but it represents only a small area in an overfished oceanic desert.  If we can establish why Tubbataha is such a productive location for sharks and where these sharks breed and migrate, we can use this information to push for international protection that can make a huge difference for shark populations worldwide. The data we collect will also help mitigate oil and gas activities that are encroaching on this sensitive region.

What makes your team qualified to lead this expedition? Our team represents the next generation of internationally acclaimed shark scientists, conservation experts, professional journalists, and technology junkies.  We regularly work with international authorities on conservation policy, our work has been featured in top scientific journals, and we have a combined 70 years of experience in the field. Most importantly, we're all full-time shark researchers or conservationists who love what we do and are totally committed to the protection of these animals.

What happens if this expedition is not funded?Without this expedition, we won't have access to information essential for the conservation of this shark eden. Is Tubbataha a tiger shark nursery?  Do sharks migrate from Tubbataha into the unprotected South China Sea? Answers to these questions may mean the difference for the future of sharks and a healthy ocean in Southeast Asia.

What happens after the expedition?Analysis analysis analysis! We will work hard to analyze the data we collect during the expedition so we can push for the targeted protection of important shark habitats in Southeast Asia. We'll also publish any findings and release several films documenting the expedition. 

Can I join the expedition?Yes! Join our expedition crew and help us make history for sharks.  Two spots are available on our research vessel -- see our "Perks" section for information on how to to join. If sailing the high seas isn't your cup of tea, you can join the expedition remotely by sponsoring an underwater video system, donating a satellite tag that we'll attach to a whale shark, or making a donation to our campaign and following our regular updates.  Anything helps! 

Are there any terms and conditions associated with the perks?Yes. Please visit our Terms and Conditions page.

story:
Making EV charging practical: a cross-country drive for the record books

We need your help to take us all the way across the country!  The M-BEAM project is run at the University of California, San Diego in the Jacobs School of Engineering with a small team of students, one professor, and a few local engineers. We are planning to demonstrate a new solution to electric vehicle (EV) charging with a record-setting trip across the USA in 47 hours with only 2-5 min. stops (beating the previous record of 59 hours by a Tesla).

Our trip is scheduled for Fall 2015. We will trek 2,700 miles from San Diego, CA to Washington DC in a converted 2002 VW Golf modified with M-BEAM modular battery technology. We will simulate battery exchange stations with stops along the way lasting 2 to 5 minutes to complete each battery exchange. This exchange is analogous to switching out depleted propane tanks.

We envision a world where the electric car is practical for everyone. A world where everyone can benefit from lower vehicle operating and fuel costs while also improving their environmental impact. 

M-BEAM battery technology has the potential to set the standard for modular battery exchange and to redefine the battery storage marketplace with exchangeable modules that can be used in many applications, potentially adding value to consumer solar energy solutions.

We need your help!

The cross country EV challenge is a chance to prove the M-BEAM concept on a major stage.

We need to continue to raise another $100,000 to pay for spare parts, more battery modules, generators, chargers, chase vehicles, trip logistics, and event promotion. In addition, your contribution will fund further lab work to shrink our module design to the size of a tissue box and develop better designs for placement in vehicles.

We have raised $41,000 for this project through UCSD’s new crowd-funding platform, CrowdSurf, from 119 donors. Let’s continue the momentum! Please contribute today and spread the word!

The Problem

Environmental Impact

The need for electric vehicles is increasingly clear. Why is the electric vehicle a superior alternative to gas cars?

  • Gas automobiles are now the largest net contributor to climate change pollution (NASA) and produce significant amounts of air pollution, even with strict EPA standards.
  • Electric vehicles potentially offer a lower overall operating cost than gas vehicles.
  • The electric vehicle is a much more elegant design with fewer complex mechanisms and no emissions or tailpipes.

It is becoming pretty clear to many people that electric vehicles over the last few years are no longer some futuristic fantasy. A revolution is happening using clean, renewable, de-centralized energy, with battery electric vehicles playing a key role.

Battery electric vehicles do not emit any greenhouse gases. Battery electric vehicles also do not emit toxic pollutants which adversely affect our health. We should not be faced with the choice of dependency on Middle East oil or fracking. Over one billion new cars will be on the road in the next 10 years due to growth in China and India, more than doubling the cars already on the road! We ALL need these to be clean electric cars.

Today’s Electric Cars Are Not Practical

Electric vehicle charging stations are not a scalable solution to the adoption of electric vehicles. Most people do not want to wait for at least 30 minutes a small amount of added range (Level 3 charging can take up to 30 minutes for an 80% charge, and Level 2 charging needs four or more hours). In addition, 50% of drivers in the U.S. do not have access to a garage or 240 volts for home-charging.

Batteries currently used in EVs are heavy and large, impossible to replace at home and require specialized equipment only a service station would have. They are also very costly, some comprising about half the value of the total car cost. One of the largest pitfalls of the EV is the range of the battery. The average EPA electric range of most affordable EVs is about 70-100 miles per charge, while some of the higher end cars advertise 265 miles per charge. Additionally, it takes a significant amount of time to charge these batteries to full range. The combination of small range and long charging times pose a significant deterrence to the adoption of EVs as an alternative to gas vehicles.

The M-BEAM Solution

M-BEAM (Modular Battery Exchange & Active Management) technology flips the large battery design on its head by creating a safe and reliable system of interchangeable modules. The implications are tremendous. With the correct infrastructure, modular exchange would provide virtually unlimited range without long charge periods. Imagine stopping at 7-Eleven to grab coffee and a few battery modules to extend your trip.

The M-BEAM solution is analogous to a flashlight: remove your depleted batteries and put in fully charged ones quickly! M-BEAM is a modular battery exchange system designed with this concept in mind. How is it superior to common EV charging technology?

  • People living in urban environments could bring modules into their home to recharge or conveniently go to an exchange station for quick refueling.
  • The active battery management of our modular system is designed to make electric vehicles safe for first responders, preventing electric shock during accidents.
  • The costs savings of modular exchange will make the car significantly cheaper than a gas car, around $10,000. The car owner would not need to own a battery, but rather lease the battery, and only pay to charge it up at home or exchange for new ones.
  • As the connectors corrode and modules age, the system is actively balanced to improve reliability. This also allows for the partial exchange of battery modules.

The battery modules we’ll use for this trip are working prototypes. The technology currently exists to make them at about half the size and weight. In the future, they will be about the size of a tissue box. The small size will them ideal for urban dwellers who would be able to charge modules in their apartment homes.

  1. Exchanging a battery module is as easy as removing the empty battery and exchanging it with a fully charged one.

Following our cross-country challenge, our team will go back to the lab to design smaller battery modules and research car designs where the modules would be easy to access and more practical for mass production. 

Imagine having a bank of batteries that you can use for solar energy storage and running the lawn mower, motorcycle, or any other electric motorized device using the module technology. Think about storing the energy you produce from your solar system, further lowering electricity costs and fulfilling any lapses in power from the grid.

See technical details and frequently asked questions on our website, www.modularexchange.com.

We believe that our trip will have a lasting impact on this energy revolution, just like the first flight by those Wright Bros had a lasting effect on aviation. We plan to continue this work in the labs at UCSD and elsewhere. This trip gives us a nice head of steam and puts the discussion into the mainstream consciousness. We just don’t believe that all of our interests are well served by the auto industry, oil companies, or yes, even the government. This is truly a grassroots effort, and your support will help start and keep this research going.

We will keep you updated as we move forward. The trip is tentatively planned for Fall 2015. We will have live updates throughout the trip so you can follow us real-time as we journey across the country and into a new EV reality.

In the Press

The M-BEAM project has been garnering interest. Let's spread the word. 

Top Gear, October 22, 2014

ABC10, March 11, 2015

FOX5, March 12, 2015

Union Tribune, San Diego, March 17, 2015

Our Team

An Educational Experience

This project is all about education and the students helping with the project are getting some very good first-hand experience with the problems of vehicle electrification. These students are working hard on building and testing the car and battery system, and will be a part of the cross-country trip.

The Perks

Pictures coming soon.

story:
ONLY 3 HOURS' TRAINING TO POSITIVELY CHANGE SOMEBODY'S LIFE:
ETHICAL, ENVIRONMENTAL, HEMP FESTIVAL BANDS
Getting Vital Capacity Building Initiatives to the Most Vulnerable of East Timor

THE BACKGROUND
Hi I'm Andrea.  I've a background in Theatre, Film and Marketing.  For those that don't know, East Timor is the eastern half of a small island between Indonesia and Australia.  They gained independence from Indonesia in 2002 and have since been struggling to re-establish.  Over the past few years I've been funding two small initiatives in East Timor and have acquired a reasonable insight into the people, their culture and history, and the vast array of challenges they face. 

I believe in treating people ethically and in giving them real opportunities to improve their lives.
I get stuff done,
I do it well,
and I care about those I influence along the way.

Recently I was approached by a small Australian festival who'd heard of my work.  They were wanting Ethical, Environmental, NON-TRANSFERABLE Wrist-Bands TO use for their festival.  These would replace the plastic, factory produced variety which are an unnecessary pollutant in our environment.  Plus festival goers would leave their event wearing a reminder of their great festival experience!  Win-win.

I agreed to do a trial run of 2000 wrist-bands to see if it was feasible.

Well.......2000 Enviro-Festival Bands later - YES WE DID IT!!!
From woe to go in less than 4 weeks!!!  Woohoo!!!!!!!
After only 3 hours' training this small initiative had 15 (or so) participants making viable income.  As with the other initiatives, the work is home-based, creative, and offers skills they can also use in their daily lives.   All involved were totally wrapped and it was exhilarating to see the immediate and positive impact this small initiative made to their lives.   We all hope our Enviro-Festival Bands will set a new precedent for festivals worldwide.  And not JUST because it will help us financially.  Environmentally speaking, these Festival Bands are a real winner!!!

Already we've been contacted by two other festival organisers which we hope are only the first of many. 

HURDLES
As a result of the inevitable 'glitches' involved in establishing any ethical business in a developing country, my funds are stretched to the max. I'm only just seeing light at the end of the financial tunnel regarding the vast investment I've made in the first 2 initiatives, one of which now gives viable employment to 7 women and the other of which (HUFF - a recycling initiative) I shall never draw income from.  For further insight into this, please follow this link:

https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.606539852715404.100000781855253&type=3

East Timor certainly has its challenges. 
Due to unreliable shipping, most materials required I still bring in with me and all product leaves via the same means.  (I seriously look like a large game smuggler).  However, we've been offered assistance from a local Fairtrade Co-Op who have recognised the capacity building work I'm doing, so we hope this situation shall soon improve. 
Despite UN and other large NGOs' (Non-Government Organisations) having now vacated East Timor, accommodation is still surprisingly expensive.  Fortunately, wherever I am in the world, I tend to live rather simply.  When there I work from the small house I rent (and share with one other) at almost local prices. Training for all initiatives is done either at our residence or that of participants.  Getting around without a vehicle can be difficult, but we find the means. 
Again, establishing costs have left me out of pocket (which I expected) but the hard work's done, participants can now train other participants, and so we're on our way. 

THE FOREGROUND
Every problem has a solution.  The past few years in Dili have taught me a great deal and tenacity is something I am recognized for having buckets of.  

Tenacity, innovation, passion...yeah they're all great, but we need funds to keep this initiative afloat long enough for it to become self-sustaining.  Materials (hemp yarn and bulk beads from Indonesia) need to be purchased and shipped.  Tools have to be purchased and stocks maintained.  Excess baggage and airfares have to be addressed until such time as we can find more viable means of transportation.  And wages, viable and fair, need to be covered, meaning their is a thin line of profit between paying ethically and pricing our product too high to remain competitive.  But a profit, nonetheless, there is. 

This initiative has the potential of employing entire districts, impacting in an amazingly positive way on both participants and their extended families. We hope to see it continue.  And so we ask for your assistance.

Feel free to spread the word on this far and wide. 
You can share it by using the Indiegogo Share Tools. 
Go on, give it a go....go.....

Warm Regards

Andrea Mandal




  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

 either at our residence or that of participants.  Getting around without a vehicle can be difficult, but we find the means.  Again, establishing costs have left me out of pocket (which I expected) but 
the hard work's done, participants can now train other participants, and so we're on our way.  THE FOREGROUNDEvery problem has a solution.  The past few years in Dili have taught me a great deal and tenacity is something I am recognized for having buckets of.   
Tenacity, innovation, passion...yeah they're all great, but we need funds to keep this initiative afloat long enough for it to become self-sustaining.  Materials (hemp yarn and bulk beads from Indonesia) need to be purchased and shipped.  Tools have to be purchased and stocks maintained.  Excess baggage and airfares have to be addressed until such time as we can find more viable means of transportation.  And wages, viable and fair, need to be covered, meaning their is a thin line of profit between paying 
ethically and pricing our product too high to remain competitive.  But a profit, nonetheless, there is.  This initiative has the potential of employing
entire districts, impacting in an amazingly positive way on both participants
and their extended families. We hope to see it continue.  And so we ask for your assistance.Feel free to spread the word on this far and wide.  You can share it by using the Indiegogo Share Tools.  Go on, give it a go....go.....Warm RegardsAndrea Mandal

Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you. Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.  Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?   What We Need & What You Get Break it down for folks in more detail:  Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.  Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited! Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.    The Impact Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:  Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world. Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one). Make it real for people and build trust.    Risks & Challenges  People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.  Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles. Describe your plan for solving these challenges.    Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:  Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign. Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!   And that's all there is to it.

story:
Erosion Prevention Awareness Campaign

Today, two terrible human-driven disasters are threatening Nigerians from two directions: From the Northern States  we have "the Islamic fundamentalist Boko Haram" and from the South Eastern States, it´s "Boko Erosion"   In recent times, The  EuroAfricaCentral Network Germany has been getting constant reports on these erosion incidents. We can no longer wait and see many villages in Eastern Nigeria crying for help, languish in erosion agony. Our professionals  have identified a host of factors which are responsible but the key factors are still ignorance and lack of ecological awareness which are reversible, if we take action. We have therefore launched this campaign to ask the World Community to support us to end or alleviate the sufferings of the people of Eastern Nigeria through a concerted, professional, effort  to stem soil erosion and landslides.

The Problem
People living in villages that spring up around larger towns in Nigeria, often build houses or raise structures in an uncontrolled fashion – they are put anywhere room exists. There is no building code or enforcement is lacking. The "greatest irony of the whole story" is: Many State Governments in East and Southern Nigeria in a frantic, unprofessional effort to check soil erosion and landslides, have been spending millions of Dollars over the past 10 years building roads, pavements, drainages without attending to the crux of the matter: 1) Rain water from roofs,  2) people´s  attitudes towards raising structures and 3) Environmental/ecological awareness Training .

The Result:
The main culprit is that the roofs of such buildings/structures are not provided with rain-collectors so within minutes of little rainfall, the entire rain water from all houses converges and pours through streets and trails (which are unpaved). At the very least this results in ruts and minor floods, at worst this rainwater runoff from major storms often in seconds, turn into a large floods which many times have claimed thousands of lives and properties.

Depletion of the Rain Forest

Consequently, on many occasions the roads leading into the town are washed away and the villages are cut off. Normal life that is already difficult is even made worse for the people. The trails left by these gully erosion in Eastern Nigeria are great threats to nature and the preservation of the rain forest as the humus soil is washed away. The rolling debris from the erosion floods fill up, contaminate and block local streams and rivers creating irreparable ecological imbalance. Through this process, large acres of rain forest and with its flora and fauna are washed away and lost forever daily!

Our researches show that more than $120,000 USD worth of property and  human resources  are lost  every year in Orlu Imo State Nigeria, through soil erosion, landslides, flooding and other land disasters. The prevalence of ignorance, poor understanding of the rain forest ecology, poor building infrastructure, and lack of the needed, skilled manpower like trained multiplicators and other educators adds more fuel to the burning problem. The misery that is inflicted on the community is immeasurable.

The Solution
All adults, students, and, indeed, the dwellers of the entire village must be educated on the importance of erosion control using proper methods for building houses and other structures. Our training programmes will help people in affected areas to learn the simplest, cheapest and effective methods of erosion control.

What We Need For Our Education Project in Orlu, Imo State Nigeria.
The Main Gully Erosion Sites are: Amucha, Umuaka, Akpulu in Ideato LGA Eziala Obizi in Ezinihitte, Umueshi in Ideato South, Ihioma, Ogberuru Umunneme in Orlu local government area of Imo State. We will start gradually with educational seminars in the local schools to catch the young who will carry our messages home. We will build in these schools "Erosion Control Demonstration Centers". To realize our goals, we will  produce audio-visual materials and trained educators. One of our main educational aims is teaching the people how to build rainwater harvesting systems, using available local materials.

Rainwater Harvesting Systems and other Erosion Control Systems:
Rainwater harvesting systems can provide potable and non-potable water requirements for villages throughout the year.These systems can provide water for cooking,  toilet flushes, car washes, garden and farm irrigation and so on. Villagers will be thought to be multiplicators themselves, to get what they learned across to others, They will learn how to install a locally-made catch tanks either under or above ground, to harvest the unwanted rain water from the roof, driveway or any other hard standing or paved area which otherwise would land on the streets as flood.

Advantages of our Rain-Harvesting-System to the Communities:
1) More water means Less boreholes - thus less damage to ground-water
2) More free water for household use means less cost for water bills etc
3) Less cost for materials and accessories e.g. water pumps etc
4) Most importantly, less water runoffs and on the streets, thus less erosion
5) Great for the environment and balanced ecology (flora and fauna).

Risks & Challenges
The challenge in dealing with the poor villages in any country is, quite simply, to acquire the funds and then disburse them properly to ensure that villagers can build these systems, and implement their knowledge to improve their lives

We have the technology, we have the people, we have the experience, we know it works.  Now, we just need your support.

You can help us two ways:
1.  Donate here today. Help us fund this big, challenging initiative.
2. Tell your friends about this opportunity. Send our link to your Facebook, Twitter and other social media friends. Please spread the word.
Only by working together can we stop soil erosion and help preserve the rain forest.
Your help can save hundreds of lives and will be very much appreciated.
Thank you for making a difference!

story:
It's not too late to contribute or claim a sweet perk! Donate to Climate Odyssey through our Fractured Atlas page! 

___________________________________________________

In June 2015 we, hydrologist and climate science researcher Zion Klos and environmental artist Lucy Holtsnider, will embark on Climate Odyssey, a year-long sailing expedition spanning the Atlantic coast and northern Caribbean. 

What's the problem? 

Climate change impacts are worsening all across the globe and adaptation, particularly in coastal areas, is crucial to spare life and property. However there are many barriers to common sense adaptation efforts and one of them is communication. According to the results of a 2014 IPSOS survey , only 54% of Americans agree that “...the climate change we are currently seeing is largely the result of human activity.” [1]

What is Climate Odyssey? 

Climate Odyssey is our answer to this gap in understanding. We will use our complimentary skills in art, science, and communication to bring the urgency of climate change adaptation to new audiences throughout these regions. 

But we need YOUR help! If you've ever felt discouraged by climate change projections, then help us use a novel form of communication to reinvigorate those who have disengaged from the issue.

What do I get for my donation? 

We've worked hard to craft a list of really exciting perks centered around art and science in collaboration! 

Where does my donation go? 

When do you start? 

I live in a coastal community on your route and I'm interested in meeting you guys!

Wonderful, we want to meet you too! You can contact us via Indiegogo, or use the contact form on our For Teachers page. 
[1] Global Trends 2014. Rep. Ipsos MORI, 2014. Web. 10 Nov. 2014

story:
Short Summary

This isn't easy for my sister & I.  While we're passionate about food, the environment and education, neither of us likes being in the spotlight and we really don't like asking people for money.  That said, here's the situation...

We moved to a 1280 acre regenerative agriculture farm 18 months ago and our family recently became a Savory Institute Hub (one of 30 in the world, it is huge opportunity with a lot of responsibility).  As a Savory Hub, it is our role to restore health to grasslands across Idaho & Montana using regenerative agriculture practices.  As the "Science/Techno" geek of the family, I love learning how we can sequester carbon in the soil (thus increasing water storage), improve soil health & grow nutrient dense food.  I also like doing video and flying drones.  My sister, Katelyn, loves working with animals and writing.  We made a good team!

Our attending the Savory Training in Africa is an opportunity that only came because we were selected to be a Savory Hub.  Going to Africa is critical to our future.  We'll learn from Allan Savory (one of the top agrarians in the world) what we can do to holistically manage land, improving the environmental, economic & social health of the region.

 The magnitude is huge.  We will be the first youth to attend the training!  We are committed to learning all that we can.  After we return, we will apply our learning (and learn from that) and then teach others.  We are the future agrarians... we have to learn & help other kids to learn.  They are critical to changing the health of our region in the future.

Here's What We Need... & How We Can Help You.

We need $7000 to cover the cost of our flight, visas & training in Africa.  Our flight alone is almost $4,000 and will take us over 24 hours each way due to long lay-overs.  The rest of it covers the cost of our training (education, room & board).  If we can reach our stretch goal of $7,700, we can provide get the camera & audio set-up we need to shoot & share our experiences from Africa with you.  I like being behind the camera, not in front of it! 

We really like to give, rather than receive.  Here's what we can do (even though we're only 14 & 11... we can do a lot)!

  • $20 donation- Sosoni Africa blog posts (hopefully with video!)
  • $30 donation- Blog posts + a Sosoni Institute baseball cap (nice, not plastic).
  • $50 donation- Blog posts + a Sosoni Institute Organic Cotton T-Shirt .
  • $100 donation- School/Organization 1 Hour Presentation (in person or online).
  • $200 donation- 1 Hour Farm Tour +/or Hands-on Small Chicken Raising Education (I'm certified in Sustainable Poultry Production).  Learn to optimize your laying rates & the nutrient density of your eggs.
  • $300 donation- 2-hours of fishing for two (with us) for Small Mouth Bass.
  • $500 donation- Everything above +  an overnight stay with us on the farm -OR- class on Sustainable Backyard Poultry Production
  • $1000 donation- 5-day stay where you  "learn to farm with us".  Bring your dirty duds & get ready to farm!

Your Impact

We have increasing issues with desertification, animal health & human health.  My sister & I have both traveled enough to have personally seen what happens when we farm regeneratively... and when we don't.  Desertification is increasing rapidly as we continue to see worsening droughts.  As youth, we are concerned and know it is up to us to make a difference.

I am already certified in sustainable poultry production and have advised multiple farms on how to improve their poultry health & profit.  We have the only certified sustainable poultry flock in Idaho.  I did my training at 12.  I'm almost 15 now and ready to step fully into learning Holistic Management from the Savory Institute.  My sister (12 this summer), is looking to write about the experiences from "a kids view", telling the stories that will engage kids her age (and maybe us teens too).

Risks & Challenges

(Gulp).  Here's the hard part.  We're taking an entirely different approach to learning and to our future.  This trip costs a lot of money, time and study that is completely outside of a traditional school environment.  We're learning A LOT about the environment, biology, history, sociology, technology, finances, marketing, the internet, etc.  We're not sitting in school taking standardized tests or regurgitating facts. This definitely isn't your standard, "high school, college, get a job" track.  

What we are doing is extremely risky because we're not building a college portfolio or raising money for a college degree.  Instead, we're learning about regenerative agriculture and learning from those who are top in the field, those that are doing it (and not just teaching).  We will continue to take classes online and may someday take some college courses, but we don't think we'll get a degree unless something is developed that fits our learning needs. 

Our future depends on our ability to learn from those that are successful, apply that learning, prove it works, and then teach others. We know we can get there by being persistent and learning to see what is really happening, not just perceiving what we want to see.  One of the most important lessons we're learning is to "See what is there, not just what you want to see."

Other Ways You Can Help

As kids, we know that money isn't easy to come by... but getting the word out others that can help us is very easy, and greatly appreciated!  

You can help us by sharing our Indiegogo campaign on Instagram, Facebook, Twitter, etc. 

Pray for us as we travel & learn.  We know "All things were made by him; and without him was not any thing made that was made."

story:
Lifecycle Plastics has designed breakthrough technology that finally makes recycling plastic cost-effective.  

Our objective is to build a recycling facility that uses our new technology to recycle single-use plastic containers, one of the largest sources of waste worldwide. But, we can only complete this facility with your support!

Research Tells All

Currently, an estimated 12 million tons of single-use, recyclable, food-grade plastic either ends up in landfills or is exported. [Based on data from the EPA's 2012 Municipal Solid Waste report.]

Exported plastic is typically shipped to China or India, where individuals in poor communities get paid less than $1 per day to hand sort plastic. This turns their neighborhoods into waste yards. 

Problem ... and Solution!

The lack of an efficient method to sort plastic has forced US recycling centers to continue to landfill or export food grade plastic. Our team is stepping in with a new solution. 

  • We created an automated system to sort plastic by density.
  • We designed our system to cost only 1/10 of alternative sorting methods
  • Now... we can recycle plastic in a closed-loop process!


Benefits of Our Process

Curious about the Technology?

Lifecycle sorts food grade plastic by density using simple and safe water bath technology, designed by us. The water bath method causes less dense plastic to float (like wood floats in water) and more dense plastic to sink (like a rock sinks in water), therefore separating the plastic. With multiple baths consisting of different density liquids, many different plastics can be separated.

Help Us Finish What We Started!

To carry out our vision of a world without plastic pollution, we need to get the rest of our equipment fabricated and installed.  We already leased the facility and found an awesome team to manage it, but we need YOU to help complete it with the necessary gear.

Once up and running, our facility will recycle 100,000 pounds per month… AND generate more local jobs. We want you to be a part of this experience! Get involved and contribute today so we can have a better tomorrow!

Beyond the First Facility...

Establishing the country’s first Food Grade Plastic Recycling Center here in Colorado is a big step in reducing waste. But it is just the beginning.  We have a passion for getting dirty. And, we want to recycle smelly, used food and drink containers all over the world!  

  • We aim to establish our technology at 3 more sites nationally by Jan 2017.
  • We plan to begin developing international partnerships by late 2017.

Why Hasn't This Been Done Before?

To be honest, we aren't quite sure. Maybe the larger companies (with money to spend on development) haven't cared enough about the effect of waste as a pollutant in our environment. Maybe we happened to have the right mix of creative engineers and dedicated volunteers to realize this solution. In our eyes, what's important is that we are here now, and that you are here to join us! 

Meet Our Amazing Team

Lifecycle Plastics is part of Recycle Projects, a Colorado-based 501c3 nonprofit organization. To learn more about our team and experience, visit the Lifecycle Plastics website.

What is closing-the-loop?!

After putting your food grade plastic into the recycling bin it gets sent to us for processing. We have an automated system that cleans the plastic and sorts it by density, resulting in pure plastic of each type. 

Once the plastic is sorted, we can send it to manufacturers to be used as feed stock for new food grade plastic products (like drink cups, yogurt containers, or even takeout containers). 

This means plastic stops going to the landfill. And, manufacturers use less new plastic (and more recycled plastic) in their products, which saves us from extracting oil out of the ground – super awesome!

Our closed loop process is expected to save up to 50% of the energy used to create new plastic. This ultimately reduces the amount of natural resources extracted and extends the lifetime of the plastic as it gets recycled over and over again. 



Where do I find Food Grade Plastic?

Curious to see what items are food grade plastic? Enter your kitchen to find out! Or peek into a local coffee shop, grocery store, or fast food restaurant.


Let's get nerdy! Different plastic types...

Each plastic has a different number (called a resin code). The code identifies which type of molecule it is made of. Different codes equal different plastic types. A manufacturer typically only uses one type at a time, so they need to be sorted beforehand for them.


Here are examples of items made from different plastics:

#1 - (PET)  water bottles, salad/berry containers, clear in color

#2 - (HDPE)  milk jugs, plastic grocery bags, thick and milky in color, strong

#3 - (PVC) plastic pipes

#4 - (LDPE)  plastic grocery bags, lids to some yogurt containers

#5 - (PP)  yogurt/hummus/butter tubs, disposable cups, slightly milk in color

#6 - (PS)  solo cups

#7 - (Other)  anything that is not #1-6
story_txt:
Lifecycle Plastics has designed breakthrough technology that finally makes recycling plastic cost-effective.  Our objective is to build a recycling facility that uses our new technology to recycle single-use plastic containers, one of the largest sources of waste worldwide. But, we can only complete this facility with your support!

Research Tells All




Currently, an estimated 12 million tons of single-use, recyclable, food-grade plastic either ends up in landfills or is exported. [Based on data from the EPA's 2012 Municipal Solid Waste report.]




Exported plastic is typically shipped to China or India, where individuals in poor communities get paid less than $1 per day to hand sort plastic. This turns their neighborhoods into waste yards.  
Problem ... and Solution!
The lack of an efficient method to sort plastic has forced US recycling centers to continue to landfill or export food grade plastic. Our team is stepping in with a new solution. 



We created an automated system to sort plastic by density.

We designed our system to cost only 1/10 of alternative sorting methods
Now... we can recycle plastic in a closed-loop process!



Benefits of Our Process



Curious about the Technology?
Lifecycle sorts food grade plastic by density using simple and safe water bath technology, designed by us. The water bath method causes less dense plastic to float (like wood floats in water) and more dense plastic to sink (like a rock sinks in water), therefore separating the plastic. With multiple baths consisting of different density liquids, many different plastics can be separated.





Help Us Finish What We Started!

To carry out our vision of a world without plastic pollution, we need to get the rest of our equipment
fabricated and installed.  We already
leased the facility and found an awesome team to manage it, but we need YOU to
help complete it with the necessary gear.



Once up and running, our facility will recycle 100,000
pounds per month… AND generate more local jobs. We want you to be a part of this experience! Get involved and contribute today so we can have a better tomorrow!

Beyond the First Facility...
Establishing the country’s first Food Grade Plastic Recycling Center here in Colorado is a big step in reducing waste. But it is just the beginning.  We have a passion for
getting dirty. And, we want to recycle smelly, used food and drink containers all over the world!  



We aim to establish our technology at 3 more sites nationally by Jan 2017.

We plan to begin developing international partnerships by late 2017.


Why Hasn't This Been Done Before?
To be honest, we aren't quite sure. Maybe the larger companies (with money to spend on development) haven't cared enough about the effect of waste as a pollutant in our environment. Maybe we happened to have the right mix of creative engineers and dedicated volunteers to realize this solution. In our eyes, what's important is that we are here now, and that you are here to join us! 































Meet Our Amazing Team
Lifecycle Plastics is part of Recycle Projects, a Colorado-based 501c3 nonprofit organization. To learn more about our team and experience, visit the Lifecycle Plastics website. 

















What is closing-the-loop?!

After putting your food grade plastic into the recycling bin it gets sent to us for processing. We have an automated system that cleans the plastic and sorts it by density, resulting in pure plastic of each type. 
Once the plastic is sorted, we can send it to manufacturers to be used as feed stock for new food grade plastic products (like drink cups, yogurt containers, or even takeout containers). 
This means plastic stops going to the landfill. And, manufacturers use less new plastic (and more recycled plastic) in their products, which saves us from extracting oil out of the ground – super awesome!
Our closed loop process is expected to save up to 50% of the energy used to create new plastic. This ultimately reduces the amount of natural resources extracted and extends the lifetime of the plastic as it gets recycled over and over again. 


Where do I find Food Grade Plastic?




Curious to see what items are food grade plastic? Enter your kitchen to find out! Or peek into a local coffee shop, grocery store, or fast food restaurant.



Let's get nerdy! Different plastic types...




Each plastic has a different number (called a resin code). The code identifies which type of molecule it is made of. Different codes equal different plastic types. A manufacturer typically only uses one type at a time, so they need to be sorted beforehand for them.

Here are examples of items made from different plastics:
#1 - (PET)  water bottles, salad/berry containers, clear in color
#2 - (HDPE)  milk jugs, plastic grocery bags, thick and milky in color, strong
#3 - (PVC) plastic pipes
#4 - (LDPE)  plastic grocery bags, lids to some yogurt containers
#5 - (PP)  yogurt/hummus/butter tubs, disposable cups, slightly milk in color
#6 - (PS)  solo cups
#7 - (Other)  anything that is not #1-6
